Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, I present the committee's report entitled Radio and television broadcastservice ing of parliamentary proceedings, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. The report I have just tabled completes an inquiry by the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings into future arrangements for the radio and television broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. The context in which the inquiry has been undertaken includes the relatively poor appreciation the Australian community has of Australia's system of government, the significant investment the parliament has made in the production of broadcast quality radio and television signals of the houses and their committees, the current inadequate coverage of proceedings on the electronic media, and the emergence of new technologies which should enable an enhanced coverage of proceedings. With this background in mind, the committee has sought in its report to make recommendations that will give the parliament a better strategic oversight of the future of parliamentary broadcasting and enhance the coverage of proceedings at every opportunity. It is recognised that these strategies may not have an immediate impact. The committee's approach is a long-term one. To achieve a better strategic oversight of broadcasting arrangements, the committee recommends that a new act covering parliamentary broadcasting be drafted and introduced into the parliament. The new act would consolidate arrangements for electronic broadcasting of parliament and increase the role of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings. In addition to its current role, the joint committee would undertake a more strategic role on behalf of the parliament in advising on arrangements for radio and television broadcasting, regularly reviewing arrangements for radio and television broadcasting, and advising on the application of new technologies to the public dissemination of parliamentary proceedings. The committee wishes to see an increase in the radio and television coverage of proceedings. One way to achieve this would be to have a service similar to the C-span type in the United States established in Australia. Such a service would provide dedicated coverage of parliamentary proceedings. The committee will monitor developments in pay television with a view to obtaining channel capacity for the coverage of parliamentary proceedillgs at the earliest opportunity. Other approaches recommended by the committee to increase coverage of parliamentary proceedings include encouraging and funding the development of packages of parliamentary material for airing on radio and television, and investigating the provision of the audio and audiovisual feed of proceedings to not-for-profit broadcasters. On behalf of the committee I thank David Elder, the Serjeant-at-Arms; our dedicated committee secretary, Mr Bob Morris, who provided expert input into the deliberations of the committee; and my fellow committee members. I commend the report to the House. Ordered that the report be printed. Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed: That the House take note of the report. Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned. Speaker: Mr BEAZLEY
Title: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE
text: I move: That standing order 48A (adjournment and next meeting) and standing order 103 (new business) be suspended for this sitting. I foreshadowed that I would be moving this motion and the reasons for it yesterday when I think the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Reith) questioned me on what we would be doing for the rest of the day. This motion is made necessary by the fact that the Senate will be considering a range of our legislation and will be wishing to pass some of it back to us no doubt in amended form. Whilst I am not necessarily anticipatingparticularly if it becomes apparent later in the day that we will be sitting tomorrow-that we will go very late tonight, there is the possibilihere ty that we might have to. Hence we need to have this particular standing order suspended. I notice the Manager of Opposition Business looking a bit quizzical on that. We need to check with the Senate constantly to see whether or not it is necessary to have a sitting tomorrow. If it becomes patently obvious that that is the case, then I think it is probably smart to adjourn the House earlier than we might have anticipated tonight rather than try to follow the Senate down to 11 o'clockwhich is when it anticipates completing its sitting time tonight. But we need the flexibility anyway. That is why I move the motion.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE
text: I might just briefly refer to the matters raised by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). The opposition does not in any way stand in the way of the continuation of the parliament into tomorrow to complete the business before the House of Representatives and to ensure the completion of a number of matters which are currently with the Senate. The only matter which I wish to refer to is this: as we will be here tomorrow, in my view we ought to take the opportunity for a question time. In respect of the second motion which is about to be Mr Beazley interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE
text: You are going to adjourn the second motion? Mr Beazley interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE
text: I thank the Leader of the House for those remarks. I restate our position, which is that question time ought to be available tomorrow if the House does in fact sit. The Leader of the House rests his argument on the claim that there are no precedents for an extended sitting to also include a question time. I have had some research done on that, and that is not in fact the case.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE
text: Surprise.

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE
text: Surprise, surprise. The data on this matter only goes back to 1988. I am told it is difficult to obtain earlier information without a lot of research. I have not sought that further research because, whatever the precedent is, it seems to me that we are quite capable of making a decision on the merits and now as suits these particular circumstances. For the sake of completeness, in 1993 there were five extended sitting days-13, 14, 17, 18 and 21 December. On the last three there was no question time but, on the first two--13 and 14 December-there was a question time provided. Mr Beazley interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE
text: You have slipped up. I am sure that in the early 1980s we had, as a general rule, a question time on the extra sitting day when that was forced on us by dint of circumstances to complete business, but I do not rest on my own memory. I am not of a mind to seek further research at great public expense when we have one precedent. That is enough for me. I say that we ought to have that question time tomorrow. There is a particular reason for having question time tomorrow. The current account deficit is usually released via the ABS on a Thursday which does give the parliament the opportunity, when it is sitting, to debate its implications for the Australian economy. I do not know why the figure is coming out tomorrow, on Friday, but as we are here and given the expectation that the imports figure will be much higher than had been expected-and that is one component of tomorrow's figures-it seems very odd to me that, on the day an economic indicator of great significance to the country is released, we cannot have some questions put to the government. Australia's current account deficit now is worse than Mexico's. It really is reaching crisis proportions. The Australian public, who basically pay for it through higher interest rates on their mortgages, are entitled to know what the government's reaction is. The Labor government has been in office for 12 years. At the next election it will be seeking a mandate from the Australian people to be in office for 19 out of 26 years. That is the request it will be putting to the Australian people. They are entitled to ask, 'What have you done? What results have we had in the 16 years you have been in office?' When Australia's current account deficit is the highest in the OECD, as predicted by the independent OECD, I think some questions on that subJect ought to be answered by the government. It would be nothing but political cowardice for you not to give us question time tomorrow. Now that your sole argument, which is that there is no precedent for question time, has been swept from beneath your feet, I will be very interested to see what your imagination brings forth as the reason why we are not going to have question time tomorrow. Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Air traffic control facilities Darwin International Airport The existing air traffic control facilities are operationally deficient and were programmed for replacement in the 1994-95 defence medium new works program. During design the project cost estimate has been revised and the project will exceed the medium new works threshold. As a result the project requires parliamentary approval. An audit of the air traffic control services at RAAF base Darwin identified that the replacement of radar and communication equipment is crucial to safe air traffic operations at Darwin. The report also concluded that the timing of the construction of the new ATC facilities should be advanced as far as possible to ensure no disruption to the air traffic services whilst allowing the proper introduction of the radar and communications equipment. The new equipment will provide the required international standard of air safety at Darwin airport and should not be delayed. To avoid installation delays it is necessary to complete the ATC facilities by the end of 1996. If parliamentary approval is obtained, construction can commence in late 1995 for completion in 1996. In addition, the project will be reprogrammed with a cost cap of $8.4 million. I thank the committee for its support, and I commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Public Works Committee Approval of Work

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Housing development at HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin. The proposal involves the construction of 30 family dwellings at HMAS Coonawarra, Northern Territory, to reduce the serious housing shortfall in the Darwin area. The site for the proposed housing is adjacent to existfor ing family units which have been completed over the past two years. Upon completion the new houses will be allocated to families of army non-commissioned and junior officers. Included in the project are supporting community facilities. The Public Works Committee tabled its report on 20 June 1995, recommending the project and an estimated cost of $6.8 million. In its report the committee also raised some issues to which the DHA provided the following responses: the matter of air conditioning allowance for defence personnel is a condition of service issue and the authority will relay the committee's views to the appropriate area within Defence; the authority shares the committee's concern regarding the need to protect subcontractors and suppliers and will ensure that its processes conform with the best practices within the industry; and the requirement to make certification mandatory will be examined in the context of industry practices and the impact of any such measures on competitiveness for authority business and price. It should be noted that in the authority'S life there has been no serious incident involving non-payment to subcontractors and suppliers. If approved, the first stage of the project will commence in July 1995. I thank the committee for its report and commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Public Works Committee Approval of Work

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: --:-I move: That, in accordance with the provisions Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Refurbishment of Australian Embassy, Washington. The proposal to be referred to the committee comprises: the implication of a staged program of internal refurbishment providing tenancy conditions which meet the requirements of occupational health and safety, the replacement of outdated and obsolete equipment and the provision of office accommodation which meets current data and communications needs. Physical security protection will also be improved. The original building which houses the Australian Embassy in Washington was constructed in 1969 with an extension added in 1976. It is now in need of substantial refurbishment. Subject to the normal Public Works Committee process, the government has approved expenditure of $16 million over a two-year period to undertake a comprehensive program of internal refurbishment. The building is well located but now has many internal deficiencies. It lacks suitable fire protection and egress, major building services have reached the end of their design life and require replacement and office layouts are inefficient. There is a need therefore for a complete refurbishment of the building to ensure the protection of the Commonwealth's investment and to provide a standard of accommodation appropriate to the function of one of Australia's most significant embassies. The embassy in Washington services some 19 government departments and organisations, including diplomatic, defense, immigration and trade. It is also the hub of the communications network for Australia's diplomatic missions in North and South America. Economic evaluations have been carried out on all practical options and the most cost effective solution for Australia's representative accommodation in Washington is the retention and upgrading of the current premises. In addition, the importance of Australia's bilateral relationship with the United States is of the better reflected in a major refurbishment rather than selling the premises and moving from a prominent location. The total cost of the proposed refurbishment is estimated at $16 million on November 1994 prices. I commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Public Works Committee Reference

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of 45 apartments Embassy staff, Jakarta. Exceptionally high rents and unavailability of suitable accommodation to meet the increased Australian based staffing allocation at the Australian Embassy in Jakarta has resulted in the need to increase the owned estate. Investigations undertaken by the Overseas Property Group have shown that it is more economical to purchase land and build rather than to continue to endure escalating rents for Abased offices. Free standing leased accommodation to the Australian. standards is difficult to locate and expensive when found. Rents are increasing at the rate of approximately seven per cent annually. The proposal to be referred to the committee comprises construction of a 16storey apartment complex incorporating 45 apartments, underground car parking and recreational facilities plus a swimming pool and a children's playground. Total cost of the proposed development is estimated at $25.73 million at June 1995 prices. The project will be refinanced off budget under a deferred payment arrangement. I commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Public Works Committee Reference

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of 10 apartments Consulate-General staff, Shanghai. Leased residential accommodation at Shanghai suitable for expatriates is at a premium with lengthy waiting lists, no room to negotiate rents and a steep escalation clause of 10 per cent included in all leases. Landlords have taken advantage of the favourable position they find themselves in by increasing rents significantly on each lease renewal. Renewals in 1994 saw rents more than double on twoyear leases. On this basis of short supply and rapidly rising costs, the Overseas Property Group for undertook a review of its property strategy in Shanghai, including options for ownership. Early evaluations indicated a simple payback period for a development option in the designated consular district was less than six years. The proposal to be referred to the committee comprises construction of a five-storey building of 10 apartments, plus underground car park and associated recreational facilities including a swimming pool and a tennis court. Total cost of the proposed development is estimated at $10.529 million at May 1995 prices. The project will be refinanced off budget under a deferred payment arrangement. I commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Public Works Committee Reference

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of 20 apartments for Australian High Commission staff, Kuala Lumpur. Kuala Lumpur is fast becoming another Asian city where most expatriates can no longer afford to live in free standing houses as opposed to apartment townhouses. Existing owned accommodation is either beginning to age or has proved unsatisfactory for the postproperty requirements. The sustained demand for properties in Kuala Lumpur has made the cost of leasing residential accommodation expensive. Rents for are increasing at the rate of eight per cent annually. A free property market operates in Malaysia. There is a wide variety of condominium and free standing residential accommodation available for renting or purchasing. However, the standard of buildings generally is not good, resulting in rapid deterioration accelerated by the tropical environment. The average life span is considered to be 10 years. The proposal to be referred to the committee comprises the construction of a three storey complex of 10 apartments, including one for the deputy head of the mission, and the construction of another 10 unit development on a site to be identified. Recreational facilities, including a swimming pool, will be defined as part of each complex. The total cost of the proposed development is estimated at $11.345 million at May 1995 prices. The project will be financed off budget under a deferred payment arrangement. I commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Public Works Committee Reference

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of new chancery, Geneva. The proposal to be referred to the committee comprises the construction of office accommodation capable of meeting the foreseeable operational needs to replace the present inadequate office of the Australian Mission in Geneva, which includes representation for the UN, GATT, World Trade Organisation, disarmament and environment in addition to the normal consular functions. Speaker: Mr LES SCOTT
Title: COMMITTEES
text: On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the following report-Report 337-Review of Medicare Auditor-General's Report, 1992-93. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr LES SCOTT
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-It gives me Primary pleasure today to table on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts the results ·of the committee's review of 1992-93 audit reports, titled Report 337: a focus on accountability. Report 337 reviews 37 reports of the Auditor-General which were tabled in the financial year 1992-93, and is prepared in accordance with section 8(1)(ab) of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951 requiring the committee to examine all reports of the Auditor-General. . In reviewing these reports, the committee has not canvassed in detail all of the issues raised by the Auditor-General, but instead has focused on the key recommendations in his reports. The committee's review has shown that, in the vast majority of cases, agencies the have responded positively and promptly to the Auditor-General's recommendations. In some cases, however, it is clear that agencies have disagreed with the recommendations or have not taken appropriate or effective remedial action. It is these cases which are commented upon in report 337. The report is in four parts. The first part explains the scope and nature of the committee's review. The second part considers, on a portfolio by portfolio basis, each of the audit reports tabled in 1992-93. The third part considers the various cross-portfolio audit reports presented in 1992-93. The final part gives detailed consideration to a number of the issues raised in Audit Report No. 22 199293, Department of Defence, New Submarine Project. Report 337 contains 15 recommendations for further action by the government. The committee's recommendations address various matters including the need for the Department of Employment, Education and Training to take further steps to reduce the levels of debt associated with the Austudy program, which amounted to $60.3 million in early 1993-94; Report the need for the Health Insurance Commission to continue to develop and implement strategies aimed at identifying and discouraging fraud and overservicing, which have the potential to be a significant drain on Commonwealth resources; and, the need for the Joint Coal Board and the Department of Industries and Energy to clarify the method of valuing the coal board's future liability for workers compensation insurance, which is in the order of $225 million. In reviewing the audit report on the new subinarine project, the committee has taken a forward looking approach. We have not reviewed in detail the nature of the contract for the construction of the submarines, nor have we commented on the rather colourful debates that took place around the time the audit report was tabled. Instead, we have focused on some of the risks facing the project and have considered whether steps can be taken to improve the management of these risks for the remainder of the submarine project and for future defence projects. In taking this approach the committee acknowledges that the Department of Defence has managed many of the risks successfully. For example, evidence to date indicates that the project office has taken responsible steps to ensure that submarine construction and perforinance standards will be satisfied. Arguably, these are among the most significant of the risks facing the project. However, there are areas where project management improvements can be made. Some of the audit findings in relation to financial and scheduling risks, for example, warrant close attention by the department. The committee has made what I believe are a series of constructive recommendations which, if implemented, will help ensure that the submarine project and future defence projects of similar size are managed in an effective and most cost-efficient manner. Report 337 is confirmation that the Public Accounts Committee is committed to ensuring that the reports of the Auditor-General receive close parliamentary attention. By reviewing each audit report that is tabled, the parliament signals to government agencies that the process of accountability and scrutiny is continuous and proceeds beyond the tabling of an audit report. In concluding, and on behalf of the committee, I express our thanks to those people who have contributed to the review by preparing submissions and giving evidence at public hearings. I also take this opportunity to thank the staff of the secretariat for assisting the committee in preparing the report, in particular Laura Gillies, John Carter and Grant Harrison. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: COMMITTEES
text: by leave-I join with the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott), to comment on report 337 entitled A focus on accountability. I am sure honourable members have noted that the committee's reports now have titles. Perhaps in the near future, or possibly in the 38th parliament, the reports will be done in a more interesting colour scheme than the black and red used now. It has been a very interesting exercise to review over recent times the Auditor General's reports. The Auditor-General plays a very important role in watching the expenditure of public funds throughout the Commonwealth of Australia. Some of the reports that come through are fairly standard, basic reports that border on mundane, but others are sizeable and have an enormous impact on the outlays of the Commonwealth. One such report was the Auditor-General's report on the submarine project being conducted by the Australian Submarine Corporation. The Auditor-General was not able to dig into the contractual arrangements and see how the contractor was conducting the contract, but he was certainly able to look into how the Department of Defence negotiated the contract and how it was executed. Some concerns about this project were raised in the audit report. Concerns were also raised when the committee took evidence on the subject and visited the ASC plant in Adelaide. At the outset, the construction and purchase of six new submarines for the Royal Australian Navy represent a significant investment by the government in Australia's defence capability. The project will cost the Commonwealth nearly $5 billion. I think that figure may be closer to $6 billion. The government hopes to acquire six state of-the-art submarines. Its other goals are to achieve the capability in Australian industry to support them for 30 years, to achieve a major transfer of technology to Australian industry, to have local involvement in design construction; to have a major saving in expenditure overseas and to have significant export potential as the only useful sub-arine builder in the region. They were admIrable goals that the government set out when it embarked on this project. That is why the risk contract that was drafted was unique in comparison to other commercial contracts. That was not only due to its size but also to the in-built possibility of future benefit for reads: the Commonwealth. The jury is still out on that. We will have to wait until the project is completed and see done, what benefit an Australian company or a later partly Australian company gets from what has been developed so far. My personal belief is Committee. that not only the Australian National Audit Office but also this parliament, through the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, should maintain a watching brief on the project as progresses towards completion. One of the important recommendations with regard to the ASC in this report is recommendation No.7, which reads: In future projects of comparable size and nature, the Department of Defence should ensure contracts contain provisions which: (a) limit or prohibit the repatriation of dividends until the major project risks have been overcome; (b) require careful assessments to be made of the quantum and timing of advance payments; and (c) allow the Commonwealth to recover advance payments which have not been used in accordCorporation. ance with the contract. Due to the nature of the contract and the way payments have been made in sync with .the completion of parts of the contract, there view that at times the Commonwealth exposed to unnecessary risk with regard to the completion of the contract and the like. is why that particular recommendation made. I believe the Australian Submarine Corporawhich tion was paid too much of the contract price too soon. Some 86 per cent of the contract price had been paid by 31 December 1994. As all members would be aware, to date we have one submarine that is doing sea trials, yet 86 per cent of the contract price has already been paid out. The shareholders in ASC have received some fairly healthy dividends. ASC has invested money in a 747, which is on lease:to Qantas. On that basis, I believe the Commonwealth is bearing too much of the financial associated with this project. There is a bit too much exposure. On that basis, in· this report we have suggested that the ANAO due should maintain a watching brief. Page 167 Given the magnitude of the new submarine project, and the fact that much work remains to be it would be appropriate for the Australian National Audit Office to revisit the project at a date. It is likely that any follow-up audit conducted by ANAO would be of interest to the I am sure it will. If I and the member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who is also taking a keen interest in this particular project, are members it of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts at the time, we would be keen to revisit this project to see how it goes. In the lifetime of this committee of the parliament we may not see another contract like this. We should draw on the experience of what has happened-the that way this project has been overseen and developed and the conduct of the contract. In our public hearings, we were waiting to take evidence from Dr Don Williams, who was the chief executive officer of ASC. We found out a day later that he did not turn up because he had left the Australian Submarine Many questions surrounding that surprise resignation of the ASC's chief executive were left unanswered. It raises the question: did he have concerns about the way the contract was being managed? It would be Is.a interesting to know what those concerns may IS have been. Was the ASC becoming too competitive in the Asia-Pacific region for its That parent company, Kockums, in Sweden? Did was Dr Williams fall or was he pushed? There are some very important questions are partly addressed in report 337. As the chairman of the committee, the member for Oxley, just said, the new submarine project makes up only a quarter of this particular report, but it is a very important element because it contains nearly $6 billion worth of expenditure by the Commonwealth. As I said, the Australian National Audit Office must continue a watching brief on that project. I believe the Joint Committee of Public Accounts should also maintain a watching brief on that project until its completion. With those short remarks, I commend the report to the House. It has taken a lot of work, particularly by the staff at the secretariPublic at. I thank them for their support and their consideration in dealing with the members of the committee from time to time as well. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr HAVILAND
Title: COMMITTEES
text: -by leave-I am very pleased to speak to this report No. 337 of the Public Accounts Committee entitled A focus on accountability. The title sums up the role of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and also the role of the Auditor General's office. It is clearly of the Public Accounts Committee to examine Auditor-General's reports. The Auditor General's office plays a very important role in our democracy and our public sector but there is not much use having an Auditor General writing lots of fancy reports unless the recommendations are implemented, unless someone takes notice of them. I see the role of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the parliament being very important in ensuring that federal agencies and, indeed, governments take notice of recommendations made in Auditor-General's reports and in ensuring that they are implemented as far as possible or certainly considered to ensure that improvements to our administration in whatever agency are made as a result of Auditor-General's reports, which cost a lot of money to produce. The PAC has a very important role in that area. The particular report that I am interested is the Auditor-General's report No. 17 of 1992-93, entitled Medifraud and excessive servicing-Health Insurance Commission. I recall that report was tabled in this House in December 1992. I remember hearing about it on the radio when we were in the middle of the last election campaign. It certainly reminded me of my previous involvement in that issue, which I have spoken about many times in this House. My introduction to the activities of the Public Accounts Committee was back in 1982, 1983 and 1984 when the PAC was conducting an inquiry into medical fraud and overservicing. That is why I was quite distressed initially to hear some of the comments in this Auditor-General's report. The report refers to the fact that in the mid-80s the Accounts Committee issued a number of reports dealing with fraud and overservicing by medical practitioners and they revealed a number of problems which affected the Commonwealth health budget. The report states: At that time, the extent of fraud and overservicing was estimated by the then Department of Health to be ' ... at least 7% of the total medical benefits expenditure by the Commonwealth and health funds'. This figure 7% represented $100m in the 1981182 financial year ... a legitimate role Further on it says: The pressures on the Medibudget are just as great, if not greater today with the advent of new medical procedures and the growth of entrepreneurial medicine. Today, the same estimate of fraud and overservicing could well still be appropriate. There is no evidence to believe it has changed for the better. That was in 1992. Of even more concern to me and also to the committee, I believe, is that the report said: Since the JCPA hearings on fraud and overservicing in the early to middle 1980s, with the exception of the last 12 months or so, there has been little if any improvement in combating fraud and overservicing. Clearly this is a serious issue. If you base that seven per cent figure on annual Medicare benefit schedule expenditure figures in the 1990s, you are looking at something between $300 million and $400 million a year in in potential abuse. The report says, and I actually have no reason to doubt what the report says, that there is no evidence that that has improved. Since the Public Accounts Committee took some interest in this report, we did have the Health Insurance Commission at a public hearing at which we asked a lot of questions. The results of those questions appear in this report. I will read recommendations Nos 2 and 3 of this report No. 337. Recommendation No. 2 says: The Health Insurance Commission should continue to develop and implement strategies aimed at identifying and discouraging Medicare fraud and overservicing. Recommendation No. 3 says: The Australian National Audit Office should monitor the performance of the Health Insurance Commission in its efforts to combat Medicare fraud and overservicing. They are fairly obvious recommendations to make, but they are fairly important ones. The year of 1985 came after a fairly difficult period-the introduction of Medicare and a fairly turbulent period in relationships between the Commonwealth government and the AMA. The AMA, of course, changed its position a bit after Medicare came in and after a change of government. It changed its attitude towards the issues of fraud and overservicing and other issues to do with Medicare. It was an interesting period. We had a doctors dispute in New South Wales and major problems to overcome. One of the ways in which the government sought to overcome them was to transfer the responsibility for combating fraud and overservicing from the health department to the Health Insurance Commission. The Health Insurance Commission was given a specific mandate in 1985 to carry that out. That is why it was of particular concern that in 1992 an Auditor-General's report should say the things I quoted beforebasically, that there has been no improvement. In fairness to the Health Insurance Commission, I think it is fair to say that the legislation it has had to work with-the legislation the department of health previously had to work with-going back 20 years, was not really strong enough to enable federal agencies to effectively police or combat the abuses of the Medicare schedule or the payment of Medicare benefits. That is why I am quite pleased that the government has passed at least two relevant pieces of legislation in this term of parliament-the Professional Services Review Act 1993 and the Powers of Investigation Act 1994. There have been subsequent amendments to those acts. I am confident that both of those pieces of legislation are the best attempts yet in terms of legislation to overcome this problem, which is a major drain on the federal budget. I have always supported Medicare. It is the finest health insurance system we have ever had in Australia and it is one of the best in the world. But, of course, it does cost money. Any responsible government, or any politically sensible government, will do whatever it can to ensure that those costs are reduced while not impeding the access and equity to medical services for all Australians. To do that, we have to ensure that the best possible attempt is made to stop abuses by professionals, by medical practitioners or specialists, of the Medicare system. I believe that now, as a result of reports like the Public Accounts Committee report in the 1980s-a lot of those recommendations have taken a long time to implement-and the Auditor-General's report, and as a result of legislation introduced by this government in this term, we might finally be on the way to some real solutions and some real procedures put in place to overcome or to reduce the incidence of abuse of Medicare. I commend the report to the House. The Auditor-General' s report was, of course, just one of the reports the PAC report deals with. The PAC has a very important role. I will be keeping a close watch on the performance of the H-alth Insurance Commission in relation to this particular issue and on its progress for the rest of my time here and subsequent to that as well. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr SAWFORD
Title: COAST
text: When I was interrupted last night because of the adjournment debate, I was remarking that the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) in his motion before the House had acknowledged that the new work opportunities program is a key element in ensuring that 1995 the job compact can be delivered to all eligible job seekers, particularly if they live in areas where employment opportunities are limited. As the government's Working Nation paper points out, there is no doubt that the new work opportunities program will also be the most appropriate employment option to meet the needs of some job seekers. A crucial part of. the job compact is the facility for the new work opportunities proprogress gram to accommodate the concerns, needs and initiatives of local communities. It is important that the program be regionally organised and managed. This provides an opportunity for local communities to assist unemployed and for unemployed people to very contribute to their communities, as well as business and community organisations. There is certainly scope for innovation and since 1983. flexibility in project design. New work opportunities proposals have also been developed at the national level. These proposals will include jobs to reverse environmental degrathe dation along the lines proposed by Greening Australia, jobs in human services such as personal care of the aged and work based assistance to people with a disability, and as literacy education officers in primary schools. On this latter matter, I had the privilege several weeks ago to launch the first proposal for literacy education officers in South tralia at the South Australian Institute Teachers. Trainees for literacy education officers, who were previously unemployed nearly persons, have been allocated to primary schools, several of which are in my electorate of Port Adelaide. It is important that these literacy officers recognised. One of the great problems with unemployment is the lack of literacy and numeracy skills among some job seekers. Obviously, a child who lacks literacy numeracy skills grows up to be an adult. Those problems first arise in primary schools. Hopefully, literacy education officers can some part in addressing those issues for children who have those problems. New work opportunities projects also include specific provision for people with a disability and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander particularly in rural and very remote communities. In the few minutes remaining, I will briefly refer to the Accord as it relates to the labour market. As both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the President of the ACTU, Martin Ferguson, have pointed out, the Acmotion cord is much more than a labour market instrument; it is also an agent for industrial and a vital element of trade policy. The partners of the Accord are committed to very both growth and employment as the prime objective of economic policy. The Accord has always been about wage constraint for emthe ployment and its success is reflected in two telling statistics: two million jobs and a 40 per cent increase in household disposable income-20 per cent in per capita termsOne of the Accord's visions identifies the essential role of training to underwrite long term competitiveness in addition to improving life chances of the disadvantaged. But it importantly recognises that skill formation encourages the adoption and the adaptation of new processes and equipment, and is a princijobs pal agent of technical change, which is, in tum, a principal agent of productivity on which the nation's prosperity depends. The partners in the Accord believe unemployment represents our greatest social challenge and it Ausis a matter of great satisfaction that the of partners in the Accord have met each unemployment goal-and in this period met it a year early with the addition so far of specific more than 600,000 jobs. In conclusion, I again congratulate the member for Lyne, supported by the member be for Cowper (Mr Nehl), for bringing on this debate. It is a bit of a pity that, during their contributions, they both resorted to making negative comments like so many of their and colleagues when it comes to employment, education and training matters. Nevertheless, I wish his Mid-Coast Area Consultative play Committee every success in its 1,000 jobs campaign. Like our campaign in Port Adelaide, I am sure that-with goodwill, with business and with community organisations, for along with the members involved-they will peoples, achieve their laudable goals. By the actions of the member for Lyne and of the member for Cowper prior to framing that motion, both members acknowledge that the initiatives of the government's Working Nation programs are working. There is no doubt about that: you could not frame that unless you believed that. Importantly, Working Nation is growing in momentum not only in Australia's cities but also in important areas in regional Australia. It is, of course, great pity that the bulk of the opposition bench does not share this important national interest issue as do all government members and, I suspect, the member for Lyne and the member for Cowper.

text: Well, I want to to mention one in particular, and that is the (Mr Whitsunday area of North Queensland and North Queensland in general. But, fair enthe ough, the money is there. In this partnership, the government-and I think it is putting the cart before the horse-is educating people after they have passed through their educational program. I understand that the program comprises educational for six weeks out of the whole 26 weeks and the rest of the time is taken up in training. As has been said in this debate, it has been acknowledged that, at the end of the 26 weeks, seven out of 10 people somewill still be unemployed. With Australia as young and as vigorous as it is and with as much opportunity it possesses, the most frightful statistic we have is the underutilisation of our labour resource. Before we can even embark on this, we have figures before us that nobody really understands. Title: COAST
text: They are hiding/the unemployed. As I understand it, a job can be classified as a job on as little as eight Hours a week. In real terms, five people are peing absorbed from the unemployment queues whereas only one job is being filled. I would like to address my remarks to where real jobs, real labour, can be provided: small business. There are many impediments to small business. At a time of a state election in Queensland, it is not uncommon to see small businesses in my area closed. They are closed because of government impositions. For instance, the difficulty employers have today in terminating employment makes them think twice about putting on people. The state's payroll tax has long been acknowledged as an impediment to employment. The stiver guarantee levy and the fringe benefits t- are add-ons to the impositions on small business to employ. Small businesses have rec9gnised there are many impediments to employing labour, such as high taxes, and they\are not employing. A farmer I spoke to the other day can hims6lf maintain a farm which harvests 11,000 tonnes of cane a year. He contracts harvesters, but on a farm which harvests 11,000 tonnes of cane a year he is the only person who needs to be employed for all 12 months of the year.

text: It is amazing. In my day my father had a 700-tonne to a 1,000tonne farm. We had a permanent hand and two cane cutters-and of course dad had a tribe of kids who helped out too. Taking the example of this II,OOO-tonne farm, we know society and this government have passed by the needs of small business people. They will not be good employers. They will not soak up those thrown out of current employment in small businesses. In that regard, I do not think the federal government, or the Queensland government, can claim any credit for creating jobs. The Queensland government is closing down railways. Public Service employees on the railways are diminishing in number-not in just ones and twos but by the thousands. Government services are also being closed down-this is true for not only the Queensland government but the federal government-such as those carried out by the CPS, police and the education sector. In my area numbers of post office staff are declining. This is diminishing the opportunities for employment in small country towns. According to the Local Government Association, these are the areas where work will be providenough. ed. We may as well close down the towns if jobs in the railways, the police force, the CPS and a whole multitude of other areas are ripped out of towns. The lack of major works projects in Queensland also worries me. They could be great employers.
