Just think of the job opportunities going to waste. No new dams have been constructed. No programs have been put in place except the user-pays system. Again, these are areas that could provide real labour. No more roads will be built at the public's expense. Roads are now being built in the form of toll ways. Many rip through the most beautiful parts of Queensland, particularly in the south. It will be interesting to find out the reaction of Queenslanders in the coming state government election. Could I talk about tourism because that is It what the motion refers to-jobs on Australia's holiday coast. We have just completed an exercise in the banking, finance and public administration committee looking at the aspects of taxation on the tourism industry that put it at a disadvantage compared with other industries. The user-pays principle that is now coming into tourism, whether it be in regard to the use of the Barrier Reef, the use of a national park or the use of a waterway, is decimating the tourism industry. The government says that it is not putting up or introducing new taxes but there has been an abnormal increase in the aspect of how it funds its money. This is just one way. In regard to fuel tax excise the industry complains bitterly that it is not subject to a rebate because all the fuel it uses on the water is never used on a road back on the mainland. The fringe benefits tax was a particular worry. The committee criticised the government's latest moves in that regard to try to simplify it because they had not gone far Thankfully, the committee did make recommendations both on the payroll tax and the fringe benefits tax. The sales tax was a particular impediment. People in business are being asked to pay sales tax on the equipment they use on a day-today basis. Employment opportunities in the health services in Queensland are being diminished day by day. The private hospital system and the private providers are being discouraged from taking up the slack. So, while I again commend the movers of this motion, the member for Lyne and the member for Cowper, on their foresight and commend the people of their region for their assistance, I say that the government ought to go back to the fundamentals and look at where these jobs Olre being lost. It should be honest about where the new jobs are. It should be honest about unemployment and try to form some solution. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: COAST
text: I would like to answer a couple of things that the member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) had to say. The difference between each side of the House can come up in these debates. The term the honourable member used was the 'under-resource of our labour force', which true. On our side of the House we believe that with unemployment comes a great deal of social cost as well. High levels of unemployment disrupt our society greatly and cause great hardship to individuals. I guess that is why the long-term unemployed have been targeted for special assistance with some of the programs this motion deals with. The member for Dawson raised the issue of retention rates. He was missing the point. When we look at retention rates and young people staying at school and endeavouring to gain skills at that level, we find that many the jobs that the previous generation would have been engaged in have now gone. The jobs are not there. So the best thing those young people can do is to gain further skills to enhance their entry into some of the jobs that are coming on, which require many more skills than probably a 15or a 16-year-old would have required even in my day and even in your day, Mr Deputy Speaker. Those jobs have gone, so it is not a simple task to say that there should be another system and that those kids should not be at school, that they ! should be out there working. The jobs t4t they used to take up are not there any longer. If you look deeper into some of the 10grams that are starting to come into play land some of the policies of this governmellt to encourage school-to-work programs, tHen I think the honourable member would probably reach a different conclusion. The memQbr for Lyne (Mr Vaile) moved this motion yesterday in the House. He talked about new· work opportunities. He had some criticisms of the programs and labour market programs' generally, but I felt he was missing the point with his criticism that we were targeting the long term unemployed people who had been out of work for 18 months. The old argument of why we are doing that comes from statistics that show that after each recession or downturn in our economy we pick up people who have been out of work for a longer period. The recent downturn that we have had caused a high number of people to be out of work for a long period. The probiem is that, if you do not get back into the work force in is the early months of unemployment, you find it even harder to get back in after you have been out of work for 18 months. Employers do not pick up people who have been out of work for 12 months or more unless those people have a special skill. Employers will pick up somebody who has been out of work for two or three months in front of somebody who has been out of work for 18 months. The government's employment policy is targeted at assisting those people who have been out of work for a long period. The honourable member for Lyne talked about whether the employment programs were of successful. In Tasmania, 38 per cent of our labour programs resulted in people getting into work. I think that is an excellent statistic, although it could be better. The programs could work towards getting more people into work-and of course they are doing that. They also get people into the working mode by giving them a six-month opportunity to get back into a job or to get a job for the first time. It enables them to get a pay packet, get into the regular habit of going to and from work and take part in the socialisation associated with that sort of activity. rhere is no doubt that the Working Nation program has been one of the most successful programs in recent times in addressing the problems of the long-term unemployed. I think other countries have looked at that program as well. They are looking at our progtams to see how we tackle those issues in Australia. In my state there have been 6,000 outcomes for job compact clients-those are the people who are unemployed for 18 months and in receipt of the newstart allowance. That is an excellent start on solving the long-term unemployed problem in Tasmania. We have achieved an overall reduction of approximately five per cent in the total number of people in receipt of social security unemployment benefits-including the jobsearch and news tart allowances-and a 5.5 per cent reduction in the number of people on the job compact register in the last 12 months. If the program had not been instigated in Tasmania, we would have had no growth in employment. These improvements have occurred in what is still a very difficult labour market, which shows that Working Nation is on track and ahead of schedule in some parts of the state. We have a state government which has not been able to boost job growth at all. All employment has been created by one or another of the federal government programs and can be attributed to the Working Nation initiative. No investment is coming into the state. Our tourist figures are down, and no jobs are being created through the policies of our state government. The only growth in employment in the state is through the new work opportunities program, Working Nation programs and labour market programs. There has been a slight problem with the new work opportunities program in Tasmania, with some community concern that it will displace the wages and conditions of other workers. There is some resistance to training wages. I believe that these beliefs and feelings are ill-founded. There is an answer to this, and I am currently working closely with a number of the key players to try to help this program progress further. I know of many labour market programs that have helped people into training and assisted them back into the work force. Many people in my state have achieved their goal of getting back into the work force, and I can think of several of them. When the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) was in Tasmania, Incat, the ferry maker in Hobart, helped people who had been out of work for three years develop the new skill of welding aluminium. That is a high skill and those people were as keen as mustard because they were in a new field that was going to keep their work prospects alive for many years into the future. The programs have also given local government and communities an opportunity to bring forward works that may not have been done for some time, that were just on the list of work that could be done and really needed to be done. Some of those works included developing additional tourism structure and tidying up particular long-term problems, even down to our war memorials. We have restoration work being undertaken on some of those. I have been particularly keen to ensure that the electorate of Lyons has been well represented in making sure that we have achieved what we can from these programs. One such program is the wetlands project, which assisted the local municipality through an innovative program to develop a series of filter ponds for the sewage, and it used jobskills to assist it to achieve its goals. This has now become a first-class tourist feature for the New Norfolk municipality, providing a great visiting and recreation spot. The bird life is establishing there, even the platypi are taking up residence within those ponds that were created through the labour market program. Another such program was developed at Chauncy Vale, which had 15 young LEAP people working in a natural sanctuary restoring and preserving the site which was the home of one of Tasmania's great writers, Nan Chauncy. There were a few problems with this, and I think it was caused by the lack of information given to participants when they started. We have now sorted that out. I am sure it will be a very successful program. Orielton Lagoon, which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) visited recently when he was in Tasmania, also had a component of 25 LEAP participants over two stages preparing the wetlands and assisting in restoring the lagoon to get it back to its original state and in getting over some of the really bad environmental problems associated with that lagoon. The Bridgewater High School farm had 15 jobskillers assisting in making the farm into a fine educational tool for training rural workers and also giving work experience in country skills to some of the tough young kids from the urban areas. There is nothing like grooming a cranky bull at 6 a.m. before a show to test the real mettle of some of those youngsters. It gets them to think about who is the strongest. Queenstown has 10 jobskills people working on their weeds to wilderness project. The Lachlan River at New Norfolk also has 15 people working on weed removal and restoration of river banks in order to restore that river to some of its past glory. As of 23 June 1995, the commencements in Lyons are 257 jobskills and 65 LEAP people. The 53 new work opportunities have been agreed to in principle, and I hope we can get them started very soon. Further places have been created and will be filled in the new financial year. I am looking for employers who can provide access to ongoing employment once the training period has finished. There are a number of industries in the electorate of Lyons that may well help us reach this goal, including the forestry industry which, with new methods of planting and caring for young trees, requires a lot of manual assistance. a good place to learn the essence of the industry literally from the ground up. People now need to have greater skills than they did in the old days. As I mentioned earlier, the timber industry is a far more precise and technical industry today than it was many years ago. You need to know what you are doing and you need to know why you are doing it. Thus job training under jobskills or NETTFORCE would ensure that young people can gain these skills on the job from the professionals while helping an industry deal with a cyclical work demand. I think members will agree that labojir market programs, such as the one mention,ed in the motion moved by the member of LY)1e, play a significant role in getting people back into the work force in Australia and also adding to their skill levels. I wish those from the Mid-Coast Area Consultative Committee well in their endeavour to create 1,000 jobs. I am sure that they will achieve that goal. From what the member has said, there seems to be some enthusiasm for achieving that goal. I also wish other members well in helping people in their electorates get back to work with the help of these labour market programs. I look forward to seeing more successes with this program. I congratulate the minister for developing this program and making it work in this country. I also congratulate him for his dedicated interest and ongoing support of Working Nation.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: COAST
text: I have followed this debate with a great deal of interest because my electorate of Moncrieff has a very high rate of unemployment, particularly youth unemployment and long-term unemployment. I have also followed the new work opportunities program with a great deal of interest. Unfortunately, I was not able to be present when the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean) visited my electorate to launch the program simply because, as usual, I got only two or three days notice that he was going to do this. Members will understand that it is almost impossible to go to public functions It is with that sort of notice. That is what happened in my case on that occasion. It was not that I did not want to be there. However, whilst I have followed this program with some interest, I am now following it with some concern. I was interested to listen to the speeches other members have made in this debate on the motion moved by the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), and I congratulate him on it. Since the debate started yesterday and the Hansard was available today, I was interested to check the speeches in Hansard to see what members said about programs in their electorates. I have to say that the story I have to tell quite different from the stories that other members have been telling in relation to their electorates. When I was acquaiNted yesterday with the fact that this motion, quite unexpectedly, would be brought on today, I sought to get some information on the matter so that I could make a contribution to the debate. I had a member of my staff contact the Department of Employment, Education and Training. I gave him no guidance, so he went through a slightly tortuous process of identifying the right person. I just told him the sort of information I needed. He was referred to the regional office in control of the Gold Coast, which is at Mount Gravatt. When he contacted that DEET office he was told that the person who was responsible for that area was on the telephone and unavailable. He explained that he was seeking general background information and requested, of the staff member he spoke to, the following information, which is what I had requested: how many new work opportunities programs are operating on the Gold Coast-by that I also meant any plans that might be in hand-what industries are involved and how many people are currently, or will be, taking advantage of this scheme? My staff member was told that the person to whom he was speaking did not know but would find out and call back. Shortly afterwards, a Geoff Green telephoned and stated that he had been advised by the Parliamentary Liaison Officer and the department that he could not provide any information. He went on to say that we would have to request this information through the minister's office and that an electoral brief had been prepared. Later, my staff member spoke to the DEET office at Southport. Southport is the centre of my electorate and it is also where my electorate office is located. Whilst my electorate has changed a great deal since it was first established in 1984, Southport has always been the core of it. I therefore have a long standing working relationship with federal government department agencies which are located on the Gold Coast-and most of them happen to be in Southport. There has never' been any is problem between me and my office and any government office within my electorate or anywhere else. Again, the sort of information that was being sought was conveyed to a Sue Horne, who is, I believe, the manager. The same sorts of questions were asked. She indicated to my staff member that the people who had the information were in a meeting and that she would call back with it. She contacted my office shortly after 5 o'clock to say that she could not supply any information without the authority of the area office and that she would attempt to get someone to telephone me with the information required. It would seem that when the people who had the information came out of their office, they told her that this information could not be supplied to me by this office. Dr Kemp-Quite extraordinary.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: COAST
text: Yes, it is quite extraordinary when one considers I am a member of parliament trying to find out what is happening about the long-term unemployed in my own electorate and I keep being fobbed off. This morning the matter was pursued with this Sue Horne, who confirmed that someone would be contacting my office. It was stressed that I needed this fairly quickly because the debate on the subject was scheduled for this morning. A short while after that, a telephone call was received from a Rod Booth, with whom I have a very long standing working relationship through his senior position in CES. I have always worked very closely and very cooperatively with him, and I have always found him an excellent person to work with. In another telephone call a little later, after the sort of information that I wanted was detailed to him, he informed my staff member that he had been instructed that the only way information could be provided to me was through the minister's office. He said that he had discussed it at some length with the area manager but the ruling was firm. He did not say what his conversation was with the area manager. I would hope and trust that he indicated to the area manager-whom I do not know-that I am not an irresponsible person when it comes to these matters. Dr Kemp-You are a member of parliament.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: COAST
text: Yes, I am a member of parliament trying to find out about public moneys being spent within my own electorate. That is what my role is. To end that story, I can say that contact has been made with the minister's office. However, the person who has the information I have been requesting is on three weeks leave. When my staff member indicated that I really needed this information and that I had exhausted every other source, he was told that they would do their best and ring back. As at the time that I came into the chamber-l1.00 a.m - no contact had been made with my office by the minister's office. Yesterday I put my name on the speakers list for this item, hoping to talk about happening with taxpayers' money under government programs in my electorate, and I come almost empty-handed. Someone may ask: why did I not contact the chairman of the consultative committee? The chairman of the consultative committee from my region is a person called Peter Lawlor. I have known Peter Lawlor for about as long as I have been the member for Moncrieff. I have been in the electorate for 11 years and I have been the member nearly that long. I have no problems with him-he is a very pleasant fellow and we get on very well. However, he is the Labor candidate for Southport in the forthcoming state election. He is not a businessman-although I suppose he is in a certain sense-he is a solicitor, but he is not the sort of person that I would have expected to be chairing the consultative committee on the Gold Coast. Some people may be aware that the Gold Coast is the small business capital of Australia. If you look at all the statistics on employelection ment, self-employment and so on from the Bureau of Statistics, you will find that the electorates of MCPherson and Moncrieff have the highest number of self-employed people, or of people employed by a very small enterprise, of all the electorates in Australia. So when I make the claim we are the small business capital of Australia. I do not do so lightly. It is an area of entrepreneurship. It is at the cutting edge of the Australian economy. Tourism, which is our major industry, is a small business industry. There are few large businesses. People tend to look at enterprises like Conrad International Hotel and Jupiters Casino, see that it is a fairly substantial employer and think that it is typical of the Gold Coast. Those sorts of concerns are absolutely atypical of the Gold Coast. We are a small business economy. One would have expected to have had as chairman someone more in line with the sorts of people we are being told about from other tourism areas. For example, the member for Lyne, who raised this matter, mentioned in his speech that the chairman of his committee is a proprietor of MCDonald's Family Restaurants in Taree and Port Macquarie. We have what is some very successful franchises of McDonald's restaurants on the Gold Coast. There are quite a few of them on the Gold Coast and some people have more than one MCDonald's restaurant. I noticed that when the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) spoke he indicated that the appointed chairman of his consultative committee was the chairman of a bank in Western Australia. Not too 'surprisingly the chairman of the committee for the electorate of Page, which is a Labor electorate, is from the North Coast Combined Unions Committee. There is nothing wrong with that. He would probably have a pretty broad experience, although I do not know what his experience of business is. The member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) told us that the chairman of his committee was a president of a football club-he is also a very prominent businessman-as chairmen of football clubs sometimes are. I think members will understand that in an climate I had some diffidence about contacting a Labor candidate. Peter Lawlor has been the Labor candidate for quite some months, since Christmas in fact. At the moment he is campaigning very hard to defeat a coalition member of the state parliament, Mr Mick Veivers, who is the shadow minister for tourism-and a very good, hard working member he has been, too. In that climate alone, it is difficult for me to be contacting him; I say that by way of some explanation. I also wonder whether someone who is a candidate for an election at the time of appointment-as far as I know-as chairman was the appropriate person for the minister put in this position. Generally, there is great goodwill in community, particularly amongst business people in the community, to do something about the unemployed. Dr Kemp-That's my experience.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: COAST
text: Our shadow minister ed indicates that that is his experience. It certainly been mine. Rotary, for example, a very high-powered drive-and has had for some time on the Gold Coast-for combined Rotary clubs to get their members involved getting jobs for unemployed people. They have been working very hard at it. They have thrown themselves into it with great enthusiment asm and commitment. So the commitment and interest is there. It is utterly inappropriate that there should be these political overtones attached to chairmanship of these consultative commitby tees. As I said a few minutes ago, I say with some diffidence because I know and personally like Peter Lawlor, although I will not be voting for him in the state election. am sure he does not vote for me either in federal elections-in fact, I know he does not. For this sort of program to have been put the hands of a Labor Party candidate was not wise. Given the experience that I have had in last 24 hours-the obfuscation, the runquestion around, the blocking, the dry gullies, office has been trying to find out what is happening in my electorate with taxpayers' money on this-I am very much inclined to agree with the statements by the member Goldstein, who has very recently and very properly pointed out the shortfalls in Working Nation programs and raised the question: is this just another way of fiddling the figures prior to an election? We all know there is a federal election imminent. We only disagree on how immiearly nent, whether it is a matter of weeks or months away. All of us who contested the last election remember how the unemployment figures were bodgied by transferring a whole his lot of people from unemployment benefits into training programs and the governm-nt to then saying that meant unemployment had fallen. What it meant was that recipients of the unemployment benefits had fallen. However, they had only been transferred to another type of unemployment benefit which was called something else. Frankly, the 'don't knows' that I have had and the muddle that appears to have surroundthis particular program seems to be of a has piece with the shortfalls that have already has occurred in other Working Nation programs. I say that with quite a degree of sorrow. I am pleased that the member for Lyne was able to in detail when speaking to his motion the type of cooperation and success that he has encountered in the efforts to reduce unemployin his electorate. I just wish I had the information to give the House to be able to say the same in relation to Moncrieff.

Speaker: Mr GRIFFIN
Title: COAST
text: Corinella) (11.20 a.m.)the We are here today to debate a motion moved the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), sponthis sored also by the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), on one of the programs under the Working Nation initiative: new work opporI tunities and use of the area consultative committee process in the mid-coast area. It is also an opportunity to discuss in general, as in many speakers have, the question of the operation of Working Nation and the question of, I suppose, the development of initiatives the on behalf of government to assist with the of unemployment, with what can be as my done from a government perspective. The role of government in a practical sense has changed significantly in the last 15 years in relation to job creation. Historically, job for creation from government usually meant major public works or increased public sector the employment through existing departmental channels. The attempts at assisting private sector employment through government programs were minimal and often inapproprivery ate. As a response to the recession of the 1980s and the continuing above average levels of unemployment that followed during the recovery-that is, above average given our postwar experience of the 1950s and 1960s-the government started to develop a range of programs and subsidy arrangements to assist people to gain skills and to assist business to employ. The success of these initiatives was mixed for a range of reasons. Firstly, the implementation of some programs proved to be extremely costly, making the unit costs prohibitive. Departmental structures and personnel were often not well equipped to handle problems dealing with long-term unerpployed people or with the private sector that would be employing them. The Department of Employment, Education and Training and its forerunners were never really designed for the task they have faced over the last 15 years. The massive increase in unemployment levels led to increased resourcing for the department, but real difficulties have continued with respect to having the right structure to respond to the challenges faced, the ability to react quickly and with innovation to changing demands, and getting enough of the right sort of staff to perform the various roles required. For example, working with small business people and convincing them of the scope available for assistance via government programs is not a role many public servants would be comfortable with. Administrative competence comes secondary to role of advocate and salesperson on these occasions. The private sector also had a general suspicion of government. By that I mean that many business people, particularly in small business, were unwilling to believe that the government could actually be there to help them. Visions of bureaucracy, red tape and armies of clerks and accountants were difficult to overcome in terms of convincing employers that real practical assistance was available. Some programs just were not successful or, rather, not as successful as was hoped when dealing with diverse areas of labour market demand, both in terms of the opportunity for sustainable employment growth and also regarding the skills required. Government has found it difficult to accurately predict and anticipate regional needs and provide appropriate program delivery. The role and interaction between the three levels of government have also been problematic with respect to some programs. Parochialism and political partisanship have at times hampered practical policy outcomes. Most of these difficulties can also be related to the problem of developing policy nationally for implementation locally. By that I mean that any employment generation policy that seeks to practically influence diverse local labour markets has to be able to not only appeal to the vagaries of a particular area but also understand the psychology of the various players involved; for example, prospective employers, the unemployed· and the various bureaucrats at state, federal and local level. The 1980s and early 1990s have seen various initiatives being tried with some being discarded and others refined. The government's white paper, Working Nation, essentially builds on the experience of the last few years. In terms of labour market programs and the role they can play in job creation, the emphasis is on subsidy support for employers to employ. This occurs via traineeships with the continuation of jobstart and also under the job compact with the new work opportunities program. The nature of these programs is to encourage employers to employ, to give them an opportunity to tum a marginal job opportunity into an ongoing position via government subsidy. The subsidy provided assists while a new employee is being trained and helps minimise the economic cost to business of employing new staff. Attempts are also being made to assist the unemployed to establish their own businesses under the new enterprise incentive scheme, known as NElS. Under NElS, managing agents accredit training in small business management and planning skills. Participants also receive business advice, mentoring and an allowance during the critical first year of establishing their businesses. The emphasis on improved training programs and practical on-the-job training seeks to ensure potential employees have relevant skills in terms of labour market opportunities that are available. This has always been the aim with training programs. However, with better business links, improved coordination, greater flexibility around what courses are available-when they are available-and how quickly they can be developed, better outcomes are expected. One of the most important themes in Working Nation in terms of its practical initiatives is its localism. By that, I mean the consistent approach of trying to structurally address the difficulties faced by national policy being implemented at the local level. For an employment generation policy to be successful, it has to be adaptable to local circumstances and be capable of implementation by those responsible. The government is doing this in a number of ways. Firstly, the government is doing this through the co-option of industry and union representation at all levels. This occurs through national bodies, such as NETTFORCE; through industry related activities, such as industry training boards; and at a local level, via DEET area consultative committees and the boards of regional development organisations. The intention is to ensure that initiatives are implemented with broad support because there is broad agreement on their appropriateness. This will help to make sure that initiatives are successful and, hopefully, undermine the suspicion of government's role at the local level. Attempts are also being made to improve the service delivery options available to government. The CES is being revamped, with an increased emphasis on outcomes through the individual case management approach for the unemployed. This should help ensure unemployed people get better, more effective advice and assistance with respect to appropriate training and job opportunities. In addition, private sector providers are also being introduced to provide case management services. This will provide an alternative to the CES and is already placing pressure on CES staff to improve their game. Area consultative committees should also assist CES management to be better in touch with the needs of the area they serve. One initiative that I believe could be very successful is the use of CES officers to lobby local employers to put people on. Although the CES currently has business service centres whose role is to perform this task, they tend to concentrate on larger employers. By dedicating staff to knock on doors and convince employers that they can afford to employ someone, I am confident that many small employers can be convinced, and the net increase in employment could be significant. The success of the strategy I have briefly outlined is difficult to quantify accurately, but the available information is encouraging. For example, the success of NElS is demonstrated by the fact that 84 per cent of NElS participants are still in employment 15 months after starting their NElS businesses. NElS businesses also create jobs by employing additional people. For those on traineeships, the retention rate in unsubsidised employment is 84 per cent some three months after the subsidy period is completed. It is also possible to compare the success of labour market programs for participants with the circumstances faced by those who have not taken part in any program. Evaluations of jobstart, job clubs, jobtrain and skillshare, which accounted for about 75 per cent of all labour market program commencements in 1994, showed that they greatly improve the chances of getting a job. Participation in a training program increased the likelihood of getting a job by 50 per cent, while participation in a wage subsidy program doubled the chance of getting a job. Importantly, the programs have had an even greater impact on the job prospects of the long-term unemployed. For example, for jobstart people who had been unemployed for 12 to 24 months, there was a 60 per cent outcome rate; but for people not in jobstart who had been unemployed for 12 to 24 months there was only a 27 per cent outcome rate. Preliminary data on former jobstart participants shows that outcome levels for the long-term unemployed are sustained for at least a year after program participation. However, I believe that the development of a comprehensive and effective system is an ongoing process-and that process is continuing. In their speeches on this motion, the member for Lyne and the member for Cowper congratulated and recognised the work of the Mid-Coast Area Consultative Committee. The member for Lyne though was keen to make clear that his congratulations and recognition were an endorsement of the local area committee's work rather than ail overall endorsement of the program. In his speech yesterday the member for Lyne said: . . . this motion is not a ringing endorsement particular government program but a recognition of local people being innovative and entrepreneurial in .an attempt to strengthen a major local industry He continued: The jobs program, which this group of regional leaders has put in place, has the unqualified endorsement of business and community groups throughout the region, as the motion says. Essentially, what has happened in the midcoast area is what is happening allover Australia through this program. In the debate on this motion we have had the Mid-Coast ACC mentioned by the members for Lyne and Cowper; the Perth Area Consultative Committee was mentioned by the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith); the member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford) pointed out yesterday that he thought the Gold Coast ACC was 'on the right track', although there were some concerns raised about who might be the chairman; the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) talked about the Northern Rivers ACC and the work it was doing towards job creation in that area; and the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) spoke in some detail about the development of worthwhile programs in the Port Adelaide area. So examples in New South Wales, Western Australia, Queensland and South·Australia were raised through the debate in this House. They are part of some 60 area committees that are in place. You just cannot drop them on the ground and get them going. Obviously, it takes time to get them to work properly and successfully. It is occurring all over the country on a regular basis and the improvements are there in the statistics for us to see. Members of parliament from both sides are recognising that those programs are successful in their areas. The government's overall target in Working Nation is to reduce unemployment to five per cent by the year 2000. We still have a long way to go. As someone who has been unemployed in years gone by, during the last recession, I know that it is difficult for people who are in that situation to see that there is a chance in the future. Since the release of of this Working Nation we have seen the rate of unemployment drop from a peak of 11.2 per cent to 8.5 per cent. You also have to look at what Working Nation is about and what the role of area consultative committees is. It is a question not only of generating employment but also of ensuring that we do not have a situation that occurred in previous recessions where the long-term unemployed were left behind. If you look at the last recession and the recovery that came after that, you will see that with employment growth there was minor impact on the number of long-term unemployed. If, say, 430,000 people went back into employment, only 10,000 or 12,000 were long-term unemployed, because they were left behind. The circumstances resulting from this recovery are very different. Now about 25 per cent of the new jobs created have gone to the long-term unemployed. That is a major endorsement of the rationale and the strategy behind this program. We have also seen a major drop in the number of long-term unemployed youth-an issue close to my heart-of close to 30 per cent over this period. Again, that is an area that is a key to this. When we are debating this issue we also have to look at the coalition's record in these circumstances. The recent headland speech from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made no mention of employment, education and training. Even The Things That Matter farce that occurred some months ago had a whole chapter devoted to that, but it has now dropped off the agenda. In the last two years, we have created over 600,000 new jobs through the government's policies and through the overall economic recovery. When the current Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer in the coalition government, the record was 262,000 jobs created in 5Yz years. A big part of it all is productivity improvement, which also has an impact on the economy in an overall sense. We have had four per cent productivity improvement in the labour force, while the best the coalition achieved when the Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer was 1Yz per cent. There are clear differences there for all to see. Although it is some years ago-and that is often the point made by the opposition-the fact is that it is the only record we have on which to judge the performance of the Leader of the Opposition, because for so many years he has been isolated from real power, even within his own party. On the question of area consultative committees, we are also talking about the issue of regional development-that localism that I mentioned earlier-how you develop a real local identity, process and energy to develop agreements on a local basis. Yesterday the member for Page talked about the memo that was produced by the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) on the question of regional and rural development. It was very insightful of the actual process being followed by the coalition. He talked about the need to have big figures and the need to try to set an agenda which was based on statements rather than on action. He stressed the fact that, after an election, one can always back away from it. The government's policies have been endorsed by the OECD. The minister has spoken about that on a regular basis. The situation we have here is that we are doing something. It is working and it should be commended by the House. (Time expired) Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Mr CAMERON
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I welcome the opportunity to debate the topic of a republic. It is a topic more relevant to our children and the generations to follow than to us. For that matter, notwithstanding our respect for and consideration of the views of our older Australians, we must bear in mind that the decisions we make regarding the constitution will be for our younger Australians, and our decisions should be in their interests. Despite being a young nation, Australia has a long and proud history. Since Federation in 1901, we have endured, among other things, two world wars and a depression. In spite of this, our nation has remained a united and free democracy, the envy of many nations throughout the world. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) pointed out in his reply to the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating): Australia has been one of fewer than 10 countries that has been continuously democratic for the whole of the 20th century. It cannot be denied that our stability is due, in part, to our stable constitution. Our constitution has rewarded our nation with continuous democracy, freedom for our people and stable government for our nation. However, I should point out that stable government does not give us honest government, and the members opposite are a testimony to that. The Prime Minister's statement outlined his republican agenda. He tried to give the impression that his statement was based on the recommendations of the very expensive Republic Advisory Committee, but the speech we heard from the Prime Minister was his republican agenda, and his alone. In April 1993, the government established a Republic Advisory Committee headed by Malcolm Turnbull. It was made up of an elite group chosen by the Prime Minister and, I should add, it was a group certainly not representative of mainstream Australia. It is ironic that, when the Leader of the Opposition announced that the coalition would allow the Australian people to be involved in the process of constitutional reform and that we would hold a people's convention-the make-up of which would be 50 per cent appointed and 50 per cent elected, and 10 per cent of those appointed would be in the age bracket of 18 to 25-the member for MCEwen (Mr Cleeland) questioned the fact that we would appoint half the membership. He questioned the fact that half the people's convention would be appointed; yet the Prime Minister's advisory committee was 100 per cent appointed, unrepresentative of mainstream Australia and lacking in representation of young people. The question must be asked: did the member for MCEwen question the Prime Minister about his appointing the whole of the Republic Advisory Committee? In his speech, the Prime Minister outlined his republican agenda. The major characteristics of the Prime Minister's plan are for Australia's head of state to be appointed by a two-thirds majority of a joint sitting of houses of parliament; that that person is nominated by the Prime Minister after consultations with the opposition; that the head of state has the same powers as the Governor General-however, those powers will not be codified-and, finally, that no serving or former politicians are eligible to become head of state until five years have passed since their departure from parliament. One characteristic of the republic debate is that the Prime Minister seems to think that this debate is about whether we want an Australian as head of state. He gives the impression that anyone who supports the present constitution is a lesser Australian than he. Nothing could be further from the truth. Many supporters of the present constitution fought for our nation, risked their lives for our nation, and if the Prime Minister is going to suggest that he is a better Australian than they simply because he wants an Australian head of state then he ought to think again. This debate is not about whether we want an Australian as a head of state. If we were writing the constitution today, it would be inevitable-probably the first point-that Australia's head of state be Australian. The fact is, though, that we are debating a constitution that was prepared last century, we are dealing with the complexities of change that are associated with that constitution which was written all those years ago, and therefore the topic of debate is not how do we just delete any references to the Queen but, if the Australian people are not adverse to changing the constitution to deleting references to the Queen and her heirs and successors, how do we find out if that is what they want and, if it is what they want, how we do it while giving them the same or better certainty, stability and freedom that exists with our present constitution. On that point, it should also be remembered that over the past 30 years the Governor General has become Australia's constitutional head of state. That position has been occupied by an Australian since 1965. I cannot foresee any future government, so long as we have the Governor General, appointing anyone both other than an Australian to that position. The government, and I note various elements of the media also, have condemned the coalition for advocating a people's convention. I take exception to their criticism. Firstly, the government's Republic Advisory Committee, on which the government's position is based, does not represent mainstream Australia. A people's convention will. Secondly, the government Republic Advisory Committee only looked at the minimalist approach of constitutional change. It did not, as the Leader of the Opposition said, consider items such as the basis on which new states, in particular the Northern Territory, would be admitted; whether we should introduce fouryear terms of the parliament; and the allocation of legislative and executive powers and functions between state and federal governments, including areas of overlap and duplication. These are issues which are pertinent to Australia becoming a republic and which were ignored by the Keating committee but which will not be ignored by a people's convention. Finally, a people's convention will ensure that if the people want constitutional change then the constitutional changes which are proposed will be those decided by the people and not the Prime Minister, his office, the Keating committee or the Australian republican movement. The Keating committee was expensive, considering it was a smokescreen. Hundreds of thousands of dollars were expended by the government on the Keating committee, and there is little evidence from the Prime Minister's statement of him taking note of their recommendations. For all we know, the statement could have been prepared before the committee commenced any deliberations but only made by the Prime Minister afterwards. A people's convention will give the people the constitution they want, not the constitution the Prime Minister demands. The Republic Advisory Committee is hardly a people's convention. Look at the 22 public forums it held around the nation. In a population of 18- million people, a mere 1,479 persons attended the public forums held by the Republic Advisory Committee. That is an average of 67 people per meeting-hardly representative of mainstream Australia. Because I truly want to hear the people's view, I organised a public forum within my own electorate of Stirling. We had an attendance of 200-three times the average attendance the Keating committee could manage. A people's convention will ensure the will of the people shall prevail. The Prime Minister wants a referendum on his proposal, not the people's-and that is the only question that will be put at a Keating referendum. Looking at all the referenda held in our nation, one thing is perfectly clear: referendum proposals will only get through with bipartisan support. The coalition will not support the Keating proposals until there has been further, more detailed consultation with the public. Our view is-and this is what we will do when we win government-that a people's convention should be held to debate the various aspects of the constitution and what changes, if any, should be made. That way, if there is a strong consensus for change, we know that the referendum question put to the people will be supported because it will be their referendum proposal, not the proposal of a megalomaniac sitting in isolated imperial renaissance splendour in the Lodge here in Canberra. Our approach keeps the people involved at the beginning, at the middle and at the end. It lets them debate the constitution the whole way through-not after the Prime Minister has put forward his proposal at the beginning and said, 'This is what I'm offering you. It is that or nothing.' If there is not general consensus from a people's convention, the various options which were preferred at a people's convention is what will be offered, including the status quo which many in the community maywant. Presently, if the Prime Minister had his way and put forward his proposal and it was rejected, there would not be any constitutional debate for many years under the guise that the public have recently considered the topic and do not support another debate. The message to the Prime Minister, therefore, is: if you really want to change our constitutional head of state, allow the people to decide the approach we take to doing this, from the beginning to the end. If you try having your way, it will be rejected. The Prime Minister does not want the proposed new head of state's powers codified. The thing is that the people might. In fact, I am sure the people would. If we take the Keating approach, the opportunity of considering codifying the head of state's powers and how that would be done will not be presented because we are having only the Prime Minister's agenda followed and not the people's. We are debating probably the most significant and historic change to our constitution, indeed to any law, in Australia's history. The changes we are debating seek to change our constitution and, for that matter, the running of government. The great thing about our present constitution, to the credit of our forefathers who wrote it, is that changing the constitution requires the support of the majority of Australians in a majority of states. Therefore, for Australia to become a republic, we need the support of the people. That will come about only by involving them in the process of change, from the beginning to the end. The Prime Minister's proposals are only his. A people's convention will put forward the proposals of the people for the people to vote on. It will ensure any referendum which arises from that carries bipartisan support, ensuring the referendum has maximum support and ensuring that, if we do change our constitution, it is the people's changes that are made. I will support only constitutional changes that carry the support of the majority of Australians after they have had the opportunity to consider all options throughout the whole debate, and that can be done only through a people's convention as proposed by the coalition.

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I listened with great interest to the contribution by the member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) to this debate. In the interests of the good order of the House, I exercised great restraint during some of the comments he made. One needs to take up a few of the points the member for Stirling and I know many of his colleagues are running in this debate. First, the member for Stirling, like all of his coalition colleagues, keeps trying to avoid the fundamental question-a question that has been asked of those opposite for quite a while now and which the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), has failed to answer and continues to fail to answer: does the coalition believe that an Australian should be our head of state? That is the question opposition members must answer. The fact is that we on this side of the House do believe that. We believe that an Australian should be our head of state, that we are an independent nation entitled to have our own head of state from our own people. That has been the essence of the debate on the republic since the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) first raised the issue in 1991, and that is the question the coalition continues to refuse to answer. No amount of obfuscation, delaying tactics and avoidance rhetoric by the member for Stirling, the Leader of the Opposition or any of their colleagues on the opposition benches will hide the fact that the people of Australia are asking for an answer to that fundamental question. The attempt to hide from the question by saying that Australia has been selecting its own governors-general for the last 30 or 40 years and that they have been Australiansmost of them have been outstanding Australians and have done the job very well-does not answer the question. The Governor General is not our head of state; the Governor General is the representative of our head of state. According to our constitution, the head of state is Queen Elizabeth II, and her children and grandchildren will hold the position as our head of state. I, as a democrat, believe that we the people should choose our head of state and that noone should have a right to be our head of state because of the family they were born to or who their parents are. I fundamentally reject the concept of a monarchy because I am a very strong democrat and I believe the people should choose our leader and our head of state. I believe fundamentally that the people of Australia, when they get the opportunity to directly participate by voting in the referendum that will be held in 1998 or 1999, will make that decision as well. They will show they believe in having an Australian as our head of state. At the moment, whenever our head of state travels overseas, she travels as the Queen of England. She represents British industry, British commerce, British people's values. She does it very well. She is an outstanding representative for the people of Britain, but she does not represent the people of Australia. When she went to Russia or when she went to Canada or when she went to Europe, she did not go there saying, 'I am the Queen of Australia. I am here to tell you that Australian goods and services are great and you should be buying up more of these things and you should come and visit Australia.' She goes there representing the people of Britain. When Bill Hayden travels overseas

Speaker: Mr GIBSON
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: When the Governor General travels overseas, most countries do not understand what his actual status is; they are quite confused about him. Is he the head of state or not the head of state? By our constitution, no, he is not. He is not the. head of state. He is the representative of the head of state. It is something of great confusion. You just have to ask the Governor General yourself and he will tell you that. When the Governor General has travelled in Asia and in other places around the world they are unsure what his actual status is because he is not really our head of state. He is doing a great job as Governor General. He is an outstanding Australian and I have the utmost regard for his work and the opportunities that he has advanced for Australia in his work as Governor General, but he is not there in his own right. He is there as the Queen's representative. So that is the first question to be answered by the opposition. I will be interested also to hear from our newly independent member, the member for Moore, as to whether or not he has more courage than the rest of his former coalition colleagues and whether he is prepared to stand up in this chamber and make the clear statement that he believes that an Australian should be our head of state. That is the challenge that the member for Moore has to answer, and that is the challenge for all members of the coalition, his former colleagues, who treated him in such a dastardly way by dumping him for preselection. It will be interesting to see whether he has the courage now as an independent member of this parliament to be truly independent and to say, 'Yes, I agree an Australian should be our head of state.' The Leader of the Opposition has attempted to confuse the question by pulling the stunt which he pulled out of the former opposition leader's bag of tricks called a people's convention. He is saying, 'We will have this people's convention and that will be the most democratic way that we can determine the process of reforming our constitution.' Let us look at the question of the people's convention because the member for Stirling was raving on that this will be the will of the people; that this will be an expression of the views of the people. I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker, but 400 members out of a population of 18 million does not to me represent necessarily the will of the people any more than this parliament represents the will of the people. This parliament is a far more democratic process for representation of the will of the people than the people's convention will be because the Leader of the Opposition intends to appoint half the members of the people's convention, whereas all the members in the House of Representatives and the Senate are elected by the people of Australia each three years, or each six years for the senators. So they actually do truly represent the will of the people. We are here to express the views on behalf of our constituents in our electorates. The parliament is the appropriate place to have the debate about what form the referenthat has dum should take and whether or not we should move forward with constitutional reform. The reason we had to have people's conventions in the 1890s was that we did not have a national parliament. We did not have a properly constituted national body representing the will of the people to go through the process of debating a constitution. It did not exist. That is what the people's convention was about-creating those structures and forms to enable the democratic will of the people to be expressed continuously over the next few centuries. We do not need a people's convention. We certainly do not need a people's convention which is half appointed by the member for Bennelong, should he become Prime Minister. That would not represent the democratic will of the people. The process would be just as exclusive as the one used to select the parliament, but it would be much less democratic because half the members of the people's convention would be appointed. The people will have ample opportunityand I hope they will partake of all the opportunities over the next few years-to participate in the debate on this question. This is about Keating's republic, as the obsessionists-Ied by the member for Stirling-try to make out. Opposition members are absolutely obsessed with one man rather than with talking about the issue. They constantly attempt to move away from the real issues that are under consideration. No amount of name calling or grand description of the Prime Minister in those colourful phrases that the member for Stirling uses is going to hide the fact that the question of the republic is the issue that we are on about-the question of whether or not we want an Australian as our head of state to take us forward into the 20th century as a truly independent nation. That is the issue the people of Australia will be talking about. We will give them that opportunity through a referendum, which is the most democratic way the will of the people can be expressed. Our constitution makes it very clear that we need a majority of Australians to express that view. It is not going to be decided by a very narrow result-such as 50 per cent plus onebecause our constitution says that we need a majority of people in a majority of states to have a successful referendum. That ensures that, to decide a referendum question, a clear majority of all Australians needs to make the same decision. I have yet to have anybody tell me why we need this people's convention. I believe that it is just a delaying tactic and an avoidance mechanism by the Leader of the Opposition, because he refuses to come clean to the people of Australia and tell us what he actually represents. There has also been some considerable public discussion about the recommendation in the Prime Minister's statement on the republic that the president should be elected by the parliament, not by a direct election involving all the people of Australia. Some people have confused the issue by saying, 'Why should politicians pick one of their own or one of their mates to be the president? We the people want to make the decision.' On the other hand, they are saying, 'We certainly do not want a politician as our president. We want somebody who is a great leader, somenot body who attracts widespread support across the whole spectrum of society.' We on this side of the House definitely want that. We do not want to go through the process of having a political campaign to select the president, but that is what we will have if we have direct elections. If we had a popular election, we would have an enormously expensive campaign, with candidates barnstorming around the country in an effort to be elected president. I can assure you that, if we have a popularly elected president, the Labor Party would put up a candidate, the National Party would probably put up a candidate, the Liberal Party would want to put tip a candidate, so too that would the Greens and the Democrats. We would have five, six or eight candidates running around the country spending tens of millions of dollars bombarding people in their newspapers and on their televisions, saying, 'Please elect me for president.' Having that type of campaign would be the most divisive way we could ever select a president. If we were to go down that path, it would totally undermine the fundamental structure of our parliamentary system of government. It would be totally anathema to the Westminster system that we have in this parliamentwhich says that the parliament is paramount, the Prime Minister and the government ace accountable to the parliament, and the parliament, through the election process, represents the will of the people. If we have a fully publicly elected president, who has his or her own mandate, barnstorming the country saying, 'If I'm president, I will do this and this,' we will have a divisive campaign with people having to choose between whatever party's candidate they want for president. Once we have elected a president, we will have this individual with a mandate he or she has gained through that popular election. The Prime Minister and the government in the two chambers of the parliament will have their own mandate because they would have been elected at a different time. There would be massive confusion and conflict between those two institutions. That is not the way the Westminster system of government operates. If we were to have a popularly elected president, it wOlIld totally change the political structures of the national government of neighbours Australia. That is why we do not want to have a popularly elected president. We want to retain for the role of president role as we have for Governor General-that is, a formal role as head of state having· the reserve powers that our constitution puts in place, and the conventions which are put in place, which determine that the president has the role to administer the legislative program and to supervise the operations of the parliavast ment but does not have his or her own manretain date. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I am pleased to speak. in this debate in response to the statement on the the model for an Australian republic by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is vital that this side of the House inject some common sense and perspective into this discussion about the future of Australia's constitution. It is equally important that the debate is not hijacked by those, such as the Prime Minister, who are pushing the republic for their own selfish, political objeche tives. We must not lose sight of the real issues and how well the existing constitution has served us up until now. The overwhelming issue is what system of government will best deliver a united, stable and tolerant Australian nation. It is also about what constitutional billion. arrangements Australians feel most comfortable with. We on this side of the House recognise that attitudes in the Australian community are changing, and that attitudes towards the constitutional monarchy are different from those which existed 30 or 40 years ago. change is to occur, it is important that it occurs in a united, not a divided, fashion. It is essential that if the Australian people reject change the issue is not allowed to fester and to detract from the matters that should really concern this nation such as the economy, our standard of living and the future opportunities for the next generation of Australians. It is also important that any change occurs for the right reasons. In this context, many of the arguments put forward by the Prime Minister do not pass the credibility test. The suggestion that our Asian are less likely to respect us, or to even trade with us, because of our constitutional system, demeans our trading partners the same and the Prime Minister. The problem is that the Prime Minister suffers from constitutional cringe. That is his problem, not the nation's problem. Similarly, the Prime Minister is mistaken, or just downright disingenuous, when he implies that the majority of, Australians who want to the monarchy do so because they want to retain constitutional ties with Britain. This demonstrates that the Prime Minister has no understanding of the role the monarchy has played in Australia's constitutional system and its traditions. Many generations of Australians have respected and cherished the role that the constitutional monarch has played in their daily lives and those of their ancestors. This has provided a role model for the Australian nation. If the Prime Minister is really concerned, as pretends, about Australia's independence, he would do something about our critical balance of payments situation. There are many people who believe that, no matter what our constitutional set-up, Australia cannot see itself as truly independent if it continues to labour under its enormous level of foreign debt, which is currently in excess of $160 We also have the outrageous situation where the Australian democracy continues to be overridden by international treaties, which automatically become part of Australian law and have been used in that manner. This is a far greater threat to our independence than the If Australian constitutional monarchy, which has, in fact, helped to guarantee the freedoms that we take for granted. The Prime Minister is also wrong in criticism of the origins of the constitution. July 1993, in his speech to commemorate centenary of the Corowa conference, the Prime Minister described the constitution as 'complex, legalistic and virtually impossible to relate to contemporary Australian life'. This is simply not true. The Australian constifor tution continues to provide the nation with effective system of governance-a system the Australian people are remarkably reluctant to tamper with. If there are problems, they result from inability of politicians to agree on solutions problems such as the imbalance in revenue raising and spending powers and on where specific functions should lie. The Prime Minister went on to say that the constitution 'was framed as a routine piece of 19th ry British imperial legislation' . In July he told a group of school children that the constitution was designed by the British foreign office to look over the Australian government's shoulder. The Prime Minister not even averse to misleading school children on this issue. What he told them is untrue. I can do no better than to refer to the opinion of Ms Anne Twomey; the author of the Parliamentary Research Service publicathis tion The constitution:· 19th century colonial office document or a people's constitution? In this publication she wrote: While the Colonial Office did exert some influence on the Constitution, it is still the case that almost could all the Constitution was written in Australia, Australians and for Australia. We have learnt to expect no better from the Prime Minister. His knowledge of Australian history has proven time and time again to be parliament. defective. Have we ever heard him say that the constitution has served us well? I chalthat lenge those on the other side of the House tell us when he has said that the constitution has served us well. I do not think they could find a single instance when he has said that. Has the constitution ever failed to deliver us stable government, a safe democracy for all and a cohesive federation of states? The main test for a constitutional system is whether it promotes democracy. The AustralAct Ian system passes this test with flying colours. states. his We have witnessed 95 years of freedom, In political stability, cohesion and tolerance that the other countries envy. A nation should not tamper lightly with this remarkable heritage. It is tragic that the Prime Minister has tried to use the republican debate his own political purposes. Only he could an turn a constitutional debate into a point that scoring exercise. The Prime Minister has misled the Australian people about the difficulties inherent in moving to a republican system. According to him, this momentous the step can be taken by changing a few words into the constitution. This is simply not the case. Eminent constitutional lawyers of the calibre of Sir Robert Garran, H. B. Higgins, Professor Geoffrey Sawer and Professor Colin centuHoward have raised grave doubts about 1994, whether a referendum under section 128 of the constitution can create a republic. The constitution is itself clause 9 of an imperial enactment, the Commonwealth of Australia is Constitution Act 1900. While clause 9-that is, the constitution-can be amended by referendum, the other clauses in this act, which envisage the continuation of the monarchy, may not be amenable to amendment in manner. This includes the preamble to the act, which refers to the agreement of the people of the various colonies to unite in one indissoluble federal Commonwealth under the Crown. In the past, these covering clauses probably have been amended by an act by of the United Kingdom parliament. However, quite properly, this possibility was removed with the passage of the Australia Act in 1986 by the United Kingdom and the federal . The effect of this legislation appears to be all state parliaments will be required to to agree with any proposal for a republic. The difficulties of securing this agreement should not be overestimated. Another issue is the possibility that some states might choose to retain their monarchies. Each state has a separate crown, legislature and judiciary. Each state constitution is preserved by section 106 of the Australian constitution. The Australia preserves the monarchical system of the Some state constitutions have provlSlons designed to make changing them very difficult. For example, Victoria requires an absolute majority in both Houses, Queensland requires a referendum, and Western Australia requires both of these. Under the Prime Minister's preferred model, it is up to each state to decide how it would appoint its head of state. The prospect that Australia might end up a federal republic with one or more of the states continuing links with the monarchy is not an outcome that would be in the overall interest of the Australian nation. Nevertheless, it is one that the Prime Minister appears comfortable with. The Prime Minister has underestimated all of these obstacles to change. He has also taken for granted that, if we were to have a republic, Australians would support his preferred option of parliamentary election of a President. On this, like so many matters relating to the republic, his position is badly flawed. In the latest poll, 74 per cent of Australians support popular election of a head of state, while only 16 per cent support the Keating model. Those Australians who are assessing for themselves the merit of Australia moving to a new constitutional framework are affronted at the shallowness and insincerity of many of the Prime Minister's arguments. Quite obviously, much of his rhetoric about the reasons for change are just wrong. The coalition does, however, recognise that many Australians are attracted to the idea of a republic-most of them not for the reasons put forward by the Prime Minister. To enable the issue to be addressed by the people for the people, the coalition in government will establish a people's constitutional convention. If a consensus emerges from the convention, that consensus will be promoted by the government at a referendum. If no consensus emerges, the Australian people will be asked to vote on a series of options for constitutionthe al change to establish which of them they desire. These options will include electing the president by popular vote or by parliamentary vote, or any other method of election that emerges from the discussion process. The option of retaining the present system would be included in any vote. The Prime Minister's first priority in pushing the republican cause is to cement his place in history. However, the partisan and ingenuous way in which he has handled this issue will only cement his reputation as the most divisive Prime Minister in this nation's history. If the Prime Minister were really interested in fostering a national consensus on the question of the republic, he would immediately stop tampering with the symbols of our current system of government. Many of these, while the Labor Party has been in power, have been fiddled with to the direct detriment of this nation. I am pleased to make a contribution to the statement by the Prime Minister on a republic. There is a great deal more I would like to say about the issue. Time prevents me from doing that. I am interested to hear, though, the comments of a former minister of the Crown, the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who is going to follow me in this debate. Having been a former minister under the Crown, I am sure he will be an independent arbiter of the worth of the Prime Minister's statement. I hope he is. I look forward to his comments on this subject.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Like the member who preceded me in this debate, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak in a debate which will be one of the very significant rungs in the development of Australia's nationhood. At the end of the first century of the six colonies which made up what became known as Australia, those six colonies decided that the time, 1 January 1901, was appropriate for them to join together as the Commonwealth of Australia. In the process of Australia developing its national character, its nationhood, Australia continued as a constitutional monarchy with head of state the Queen of England. Subsequently, as a result of legislative changes, the Queen was identified as also being the Queen of Australia. I believe the response on the part of the Australian people is such that there is overwhelming support for the proposition that we use the tum of the next century as a symbolic occasion to add further to the national character of the Australian Commonwealth and determine firmly that Australia, like the overwhelming majority of countries of the world, will have one of its own as its head of state. Let me emphasise that, whatever else might be said about this question, there is one core issue which must be addressed and which must be answered. It is central. It is fundamental. That question is this: is Australia sufficiently mature, proud and independent, and does Australia have sufficient sovereignty, self-pride and dignity, to have one of its own as its head of state? Or is Australia to continue, as it has now for over 200 years, as six colonies for the first 110 years, and subsequently as the Commonwealth of Australia, to have as its symbolic head of state a person who belongs to another country? That is the simple question. Members of the opposition have not answered that question. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) did not answer that question. Those opposite continue to avoid the question because they know that the sentiment of the Australian people is such that they believe we are sufficiently proud, we are sufficiently developed, we are sufficiently independent and we do have sufficient self-dignity to say that the Australian head of state should be one of our own. It is simply appalling, to my mind, that anyone could ever possibly assert to the contrary. I repeat the first question. The core question we must answer is: do we want an Australian as Australia's head of state or are we so fawning as to require a person from another country to be the top symbol of Australia as a nation? Once we have answered that question in the only way we can; the next question automatically falls into place. You cannot have an Australian head of state unless you have an Australian republic. It is as simple as that. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) quite correctly said that he and the government would support a minimalist approach. That is the approach we all endorse as well. There would be no fundamental changes in the way in which Australia operates, except that we would have as our symbolic head an Australian. There would be no other fundamental changes. That is the essence of the minimalist approach. The approach which has been suggested by the opposition would create fundamental, far-reaching and very significant changes in the way in which our parliamentary system operates. This point was made by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), who spoke earlier for the government.
