When we refer to that minimalist approach, we mean that the simple change that would be enacted would be that the Governor General, in effect renamed a president, would replace the monarch as Australia's head of state. The Commonwealth of Australia would continue to be the Commonwealth of Australia. It would not even be renamed the Australian Republic. The powers and responsibilities of the head of state would remain exactly the same as they are at the present time. There is not even any intention on the part of the government to seek a codification of the reserve powers of the Governor General. It has been indicated that that attempt will not be made. That is an approach I endorse absolutely because of the intractable problem of codifying those powers--of defining them, of clarifying them, of making exactly clear how and in what circumstances they are to be used. There will be no change in the powers. I emphasise a point which has not always been made. Let us be perfectly clear about it. At the present time, the Governor General is appointed by the Prime Minister-full stop. The Prime Minister has that single exclusive right, that single exclusive power and authority, to nominate to the monarch the person who will be Governor General in Australia. What has the Prime Minister proposed? He has proposed that, instead of one person in Australia appointing what the opposition chooses to call our head of state, the Governor General, the election of a president will require a two-thirds vote of the combined numbers of the House of Representatives and the Senate-people who are elected by Australian electors to represent them. That is the essence of the Prime Minister's proposal. Obviously, the position is not, as has been suggested, that the power to appoint a president is being grabbed by politicians. In fact, the opportunity for the elected representatives of the people to participate in deciding who that head of state should be is being broadened to require election by two-thirds of the combined numbers of the House of Representatives and the Senate. The 148 members of this chamber and the 76 members of the Senate would sit together, with at least two-thirds of them being required to vote in support of who was to be president. It is obvious that, if we are to have two-thirds of the combined numbers of the national parliament determining who the head of state should be, there would need to be discussions, negotiations and agreement between the opposition and the government. If we have agreement, we have a bipartisan decision-and we would not have a political figure becoming the president of Australia. I know that the opposition would not approve of Gough Whitlam, nor would we approve of Malcolm Fraser. But we might approve of a Ninian Stephen, a Zelman Cowen, a Lois O'Donoghue or a Dick Smith. The head of state would be bipartisan. But if the proposal of the opposition were adopted, we would have a vote over the whole of Australia by 11 million people. In those circumstances-and let us be perfectly clear about this-the Labor Party will nominate its political candidate, the Liberal Party will nominate its political candidate, the National Party will nominate its political candidate, as will the Democrats, as will the Greens, as will any of those very rich AustralOpposition ians who could afford to finance their own individual campaigns. But I will tell you what: there will not be a Ninian Stephen or a Zelman Cowan among them, because neither of those two gentlemen would ever have access to the funds that would be necessary to fund a political election campaign across the whole of Australia. But we will nominate our political candidate-let us be perfectly clear about it-and the person who is elected will be a political president. That is precisely what we do not want. What about the authority of a political president, a person who is elected by 11 million Australians? What if we were to say to that person, 'Look, we want you to do for Australia what the Queen does for England and what the Governor General has been doing for Australia; we want you to be a symbolic figurehead.' That president would say, 'Hey now, listen, you just hold on a minute. I've been elected by 11 million Australians. The Prime Minister has been elected by his colleagues within the parliament and by a maximum of 80,000 people within his own electorate.' The president would say to the Prime Minister, 'My mandate is a national mandate; yours is a single electoral mandate. Don't you tell me that I have no powers. My authority rests with the nation.' Perhaps the president would say to Mr Keating, ' Mr Keating, your authority rests with the electors of Blaxland; my authority, Mr Keating, rests with the nation.' If we want a fundamental change in the way in which this system of government operates, we would adopt the absurd and dangerous proposals that have been. put forward by the opposition. Quite apart from the fact that they are dangerous, they are not genuine. What have those proposals been? First of all, the Leader of the Opposition said that they would have a people's convention in order to determine the nature of a possible future republic. But he said that he would appoint 50 per cent of that people's convention and that the other 50 per cent would be elected. I am not real smart at mathematics, but I know arithmetic. If the Leader of the cannot control a convention when he appoints 50 per cent and another 50 per cent is elected, he is not even trying. He also said that, once that convention considers all of the issues, if there is consensus, if there is general agreement, that a republic should be established, he would be prepared to pursue that. He was asked, 'What does that mean-51 per cent of the people in the convention?' He said, 'No, that is not enough.' When asked how many was enough, he replied, 'Oh, at least 60 per cent.' So he would appoint 50 per cent of the convention and the other 50 per cent of the convention would be elected. He would control it absolutely-and he still says, 'Unless there is 60 per cent supporting the proposition for a referendum, we would not proceed with it.' He was then asked, 'If the convention cannot come to a consensus about a republic, what will you do?' and he replied, 'We will have a referendum.' When asked what the questions would be, he said, 'We will give the people multiple-choice questions.' Mr Bruce Scott-That is democracy.

Speaker: Mr ROBERT BROWN
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: A democracy! You will get a sheet of paper as long as this building with all the multiple-choice questions and you will have to fill in the boxes. Someone said it is a pick-a-box system of determining our system of government. The Leader of the Opposition said about his proposed convention: . . . it can examine a number of issues. It can examine the role of the head Ian constitution, including implications of change for the role of the states. It can examine the allocation of legislative and executive powers and functions between federal and state governments, including areas of overlap and duplication. It can examine the use of the external affairs power of the constitution. It can examine the question of whether we should introduce four-year instead of three-year terms for the federal parliament. It can examine the basis on which new states, in particular the Northern Territory, would be admitted to the federation. It can examine any other matters which the convention members would themselves determine. That is a deliberate, appallingly cynical and fraudulent proposal because he knows as well as everyone else that such a convention would get bogged down. I do not have time to go into all of the quotes supporting my claim, including one from Zelman Cowen, who is not a member of the Labor Party, but a former great Governor General. The Leader of the Opposition's proposal for a convention is obviously a sham. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise to speak on the republic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Before I make any comments on his statement, I make a couple of observations about some public comments that have been made about two of our existing vice-regal representatives-the Governor General, the Hon. Bill Hayden, and the Governor of Western Australia, Major General Michael Jeffery. It seems a little amusing that the very same people who leapt to Bill Hayden's defence and said that Bill Hayden ought to be able to speak out on issues on which he feels strongly-I agree with that, although I heartily disagree with his comments about homosexual adoptions and euthanasia-have been very critical of the Governor of Western Australia, Michael Jeffery, for making comments of his own. I must say in order to be consistent that I agree with some of the things that Michael Jeffery says and disagree with others. I make the point that I agree with the sentiment that governors-general and governors ought to be able to make observations and public comments so long as they do not bring their offices into disrepute. I would like to defend the rights of both gentlemen to make those of state in the Australstatements. May I make a couple of observations about the so-called republican debate. Republicanism in its latin usage means the public thing. In the final analysis, there is not a great deal of difference or, for that matter, a great deal of effect being proposed by either side in the republican debate, because the real nub of the dilemma facing Australians in their political system in the 1990s is the domination of the parliament of the people by the executive. It is my view that all of the issues that have been raised in the republican debate-the consequences, et cetera--ought to be put back within the confines of that important debate; that is, the struggle of the Australian people to become sovereign again in their own nation. Quite clearly, as we have seen the development of the Australian model of the Westminster system, we have seen, particularly over more recent years, the extraordinary domination of the political system by the executive, to such an extent that the Prime Minister or the state premiers have all the powers to rival medieval princes in their standing vis-a-vis the parliament and other facets of our political democratic system. It is important to bring the whole debate baok into that context, because not to do so is to betray the interests of the very people to which we are referring-the Australian people-and their rights, responsibilities and duties as Australian citizens. It is also important to reflect that many of Australia's instituexecutive tions are already essentially republican instituia tions. The debate revolves around the question of whether the head of a state should be a constitutional monarch-in our case, the Queen of Australia and her vice-regal representative, the Governor General. In the final analysis, will the change that being proposed by the Prime Minister in his statement make a great deal of difference to the power and, I suppose, the rights of the people of Australia? I would say, 'No, it would make very little difference.' I see the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) nodding-in fact, the Prime Minister conceded that this is a minimalist difference. The people of Australia are not going to get much out of this at all because, in essence, there will be no change to the essential relationship between executive power and the people of Australia. In other words, the people of Australia will continue to become more and more oppressed in that relationship to such an extent-as we know within this particular chamber-that, as much as we care to debate about the issues of the day affecting our nation, at the end of the day the real decisions are made in executive cabinet. The decisions can be made at the whim of the Prime Minister who enjoys the majority of support within that cabinet room. That makes debate in this chamber less and less relevant to the decision making process. By making parliament-the House of Representatives and the Senate-less and less relevant to the decision making process, it is progressively withdrawing the power and the authority of the people of Australia. The people of Australia have been referred to in this particular debate but, unfortunately, only in an abstract way. In a way, their relationship with executive power is less definable but, at the conclusion of the Prime Minister's proposal, it is probably no different from the situation in which they find themselves right at this moment. I am indebted to Professor Patrick O'Brien from the University of Western Australia for his observations on these matters. I point out that the best illustration about the abuse of power occurred in Western Australduring the 1980s. Professor O'Brien wrote: It is now clear that former Premier Brian Burke and his cabinet established almost complete control over parliament, over wide sections of the economy, and over the public purse. Nearly a billion dollars of taxpayers' funds were lost on extraordinary and mainly secret business deals involving is donors to the Labor Party. Parliament was never infonned of the truth; decisions were made on the run and in concert with conclaves of favoured business people at late-night meetings in private offices and homes; cabinet documents were altered; crucial departmental files either disappeared or were shredded. And that is not all. Secret funds donated by grateful entrepreneurs were used to make large WA contributions to Labor federal election campaigns; in the '80s, federal Labor out-advertised and outcampaigned the coalition at every election. Secret funds were also used to invest tens of thousands of dollars in stamps, gold and property. Burke and several of his ministerial colleagues spent the money solely at their own discretion, and acts of parliament were changed to give ministers power over the boards of all government agencies In theory, parliament is supposed to be master and the executive the servant. The system no longer works that way, and hasn't for a long time. In reality, premiers and their cabinets-not to mention prime ministers and theirs-now fonn a sort of "elective dictatorship," with vast, and often unchecked powers. When it comes down to it, much of the talk about the consequences of the changes proposed by the Prime Minister and, for that matter, the responses from the opposition have not addressed the significant problem, the dilemma facing the Australian people: how to restore their sovereignty; how to get back people's power in the Australian democratic system; and how to restore the power of the people in particular to this body, the parliament of Australia. As I mentioned earlier, if you look at the relationship now between the people, the parliament and the executive, it is quite clear that the executive is the master while the parliament and the people are its servants. I would also like to highlight some of the irrelevancies that have occurred in the republican debate-in particular, the so-called sentiment of the Prime Minister that somehow by Australia's becoming a republic, or his talking about it, people will take him more seriously. I ask honourable members: at a time when one of the oldest republics in the modem political world-the republic of France-is thumbing its nose at the views of Australia and treating Australia in a very offhand and dismissive manner, did President Chirac for one minute consider the proposal by the Prime Minister and allow that to alter his point of view? Of course not. It made no difference whatsoever, and neither will it. Much of the talk about somehow increasing Australia's standing by becoming a republic is not only irrelevant but also ludicrous. That sort of talk is patently absurd, particularly when the Prime Minister talks about improving our standing in Asia when we know that many of our surrounding nations have monarchs as their heads of state. I suppose they must look in wonder and bewilderment when the Prime Minister uses overseas trips in order to publicly criticise Australia's institutionsin countries which may well respect the institutions he is dismissing as irrelevant or out of date. Changes need to be made to our system to make it a more democratic and responsive system. At this stage, I wholeheartedly support the proposal by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for a people's convention. But this ought not to be merely a people's convention to determine who ought to be the head of state. This must be a people's convention to look at the fundamental ways in which we can make the Australian people more powerful in their own political system. We must look at relationships of the parliament, the executive, the balance of power, checks and balances and also political parties. As we know, political parties were not mentioned in the Australian constitution when it was written. However, in the evolution of the Australian parliamentary system since the constitution, we have seen the political party system become more and more entrenched within our political processes. There are some advantages to that-and· I have no doubts about that-but there are some substantial disadvantages. We have seen them in the context of the Western Australian Labor Party and the WA Inc. years. We saw how the political process, entrenched and dominated by the executive, fed and nurtured by the political party system, was able to give the Burke and successive governments unfettered executive power at the expense of the people. There is also a fundamental responsibility on the part of the great political parties of this nation to ensure that their processes are democratic, constitutional and relevant to the people. If that unfettered power is going to be given to political parties-and I must say· that I want to see that change-then, in order for the system to be democratic and relevant to people's interests, the political parties must also make themselves democratic and relevant to people's interests. We need to look at political parties in recent years. I have already mentioned the WA Labor Party. I could also mention the New South Wales Labor Party and some of its excesses in the early part of the 1980s. Mr Bilney-What about the Western Australian Liberal Party?

Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I would also like to mention the Western Australian Liberal Party-a subject dear to my heart-because recent history of the Western Australian Liberal Party has shown conclusively that it is undemocratic, irrelevant and thoroughly in need of reform. The people's interests lay in having political parties that are democratic, constitutionally run-not illegally run-'-and in a way that allows full participation in the policy making process and, in particular, the most relevant to the processes of parliament, in the selection of candidates. It is my view that the sooner we get to a system of a plebiscite of members of parties in order to be able to determine candidates the better. I believe that system is the most democratic and the closest to the people. I am a constitutional monarchist. I am a person who believes our system has worked very well to the extent-I qualify this-of the development of the Westminster system. In overall terms, looking at the large picture, the Westminster system has provided Australia with it stable, democratic, essentially decent and civilised society. That is a good thing. Winston Churchill once spoke of the British system. He said that it was the worse system in the world apart from all others. That was a very telling description. It means there are a number of faults and a number of things need to be changed but, at the end of the day, it is a system that outranks and beats most of its competition around the world. Before I conclude, I want to make a few comments in relation to the Prime Minister's proposal. I might also add some matters relating to the people's convention. It is critical that we reform the abuse of executive power and, through that, the use of the external treaties provisions of the constitution to change legislation in Australia without recourse to the people. We need to thoroughly overhaul the relationship between the executive, parliament and the judiciary to make this a system that more closely resembles the checks and balances that are useful in the United States system. I am not advocating a total movement to that sort of system, but that system would allow for a check and balance between the various components in our system. The system between the executive and the parliament obviously needs to be looked at, in particular the way in which we select ministers from the body of members of parliament. That means that those members who might have very strong views about the relationship between the executive and the parliament may well have those views subsumed on their way to becoming members of the cabinet or the shadow executive because of course they then become committed to the executive. At the end of the day if there is to be a proposal for the election of an Australian president, the list of candidates ought to be prepared by the Australian parliament with a two-thirds majority. There ought to be strict qualifications on those entitled to be on that list. Candidates ought to be over the age Of 40 years and not have been an MP for the last five years, and there ought to be no participation by political parties in a national election to elect a president. Partisan activities in the election should be restricted or prohibited by law and public funding should be allowed to ensure all those candidates are able to run for election in a fair and equitable manner. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: This has been an interesting debate, and I welcome the opportunity to make a contribution. To say that I support the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of 7 June that Australia's head of state should be an Australian and that Australia should become a republic by the year 2001 is somewhat of an understatement. I overwhelmingly endorse it. For me, it is the realisation of a dream I have always had. From an early age I could never understand our system of having a foreigner as our head of state. I have always believed that not only should Australia be a republic but we should have an Australian as our head of state. Anti-republic people always think that being pro-republic is in some way being antiBritish. That is certainly not so in my case. I lived for 12 years in the United Kingdom. I went to university there and, dare I say it, some of my closest friends are British. Indeed, I am a frequent visitor to Britainalthough, I must say, to enter Britain now I must go through the gate marked 'aliens'. So much for those Australians who want to enter their so-called motherland. Being pro-republic does not equate to being anti-British. So much of our culture, our heritage and even our traditions in this place stem from the Westminster system. Those traditions will always remain. It angers me somewhat that those opposed to a republic somehow question one's loyalty. No-one has a monopoly on loyalty. I have never been a flag-waving person who constantly talks about loyalty to Australia or anywhere else. That does not mean that I am not loyal. I just do not parade it all the time. I have always been very suspicious of those who find the constant need to wrap themselves in a flag and go on and on about their loyalty. Why are they so unsure about their loyalty that they have to constantly talk about it? Those who would choose a foreigner, however charming, gracious and kind, to be our head of state must have a problem regarding their own royalty because, try as they might, Mrs Betty Windsor is not Australian. Not by birth is she Australian, and, to my knowledge, she has never been naturalised. She does not reside here. The final irony is that she is now paying British taxes. She does not even pay Australian taxes; she pays British taxes. So Mrs Betty Windsor is a British citizen and a British taxpayer and in no way could it be claimed that she is an Australian. When the Queen goes abroad for holidays or on a bit of a sales promotion tour, it is Australian goods and services that she is promoting, but British goods and services. I have absolutely no argument with this but I wish people could accept that she and her wayward children are not Australian and do not represent the hopes and the aspirations of Australians. Show anyone in Finland, Chile, China, Japan or any other place a photograph of Mrs Betty Windsor and ask: 'Who is this lady?' and the immediate reaction will not be, 'She is the Queen of Australia.' I suspect the immediate reaction will be: 'She is the Queen of England' or, to be more precise, 'She is the Queen of Great Britain.' The point is that noone abroad and few in Australia except older Australians belonging to National Party branches and, I guess, the CWA represent her as the Queen of Australia. It is time that Australia and Australians believed in themselves, in their own identity and had an Australian as their head of state. Since the Prime Minister presented the government's preferred option to the parliament, the old campaign has been waged by the defenders in this place of the constitutional monarchy. We have all been told that life as we know it, our society, our system of government, our institutions, will all somehow be completely uprooted and changed. Australia's constitution, our system of government and our institutions will change very little because the government has preferred a minimum of constitutional change. The government on 28 April 1993 established a people's advisory committee to prepare an options paper which would set the minimum changes required to create a repub-. lic. Since that committee reported to the government, the republic has been widely debated and discussed in the media, in this place, in schools, in universities and in various community groups. All Australians are being exposed to this debate. In the process many Australians believe that the time is right for Australia to become a republic. Importantly too, many Australians believe that Australia becoming a republic is inevitable. Like most honourable members, I have met not and talked with hundreds of people about this issue. I have heard, read and talked with many Australians who are totally opposed to Australia becoming a republic. I have asked each of them: 'What possible reason do you have as an Australian to oppose a fellow Australian holding the position as this country's head of state?' I have never received a satisfactory answer to this question. I do not believe that I ever will receive it because no fair-minded Australian can oppose a fellow Australian occupying this country's most important position. Today, if we were charged with the brief, as the founding fathers were almost a century ago, of establishing this country's constitutional arrangements, there would be no thought of having as Australia's head of state someone who resides in another land 12,000 miles from our own. We would not give a second thought to ensuring that, Australia's head of state would be an Australian. So what is the difference now? In proposing that our head of state should be an Australian, the government is proposing nothing more than the obvious. At the moment, under the constitution, the Queen is Australia's head of state, and her heirs and successors in the sovereignty of the United Kingdom. Any fair-minded Australian should shake in anger at these words. They are not appropriate, they are not representative and in my view they are offensive. It is often said that the thing the Americans pride themselves on most is that anyone can hold the most important position in that land; anyone of them can become President of the United States, the head of state of the United States. Why should Australians not pride themselves on the very same thing? Why should it not be possible for an Australian citizen to hold pride of place in Australia's highest national office? The simple fact is that it is not possible because of words: 'Australia's head of state is the Queen and her heirs and successors in the sovereignty of the United Kingdom.' These words should be changed, and I believe they will be when the Australian people vote in the referendum in either 1998 or 1999. The changes announced by the Prime Minister show that Australia is ready to complete a historical cycle. A century ago the founding fathers put together a collection of colonies to make up one nation. Throughout this century, Australia evolved from a collection of British colonies. We became a single nation with somewhat limited independence. From there, we became a dominion in the British Empire and, finally, we became a sovereign nation in all circumstances, except that we allow another country's head of state to also be our head of state. I am old enough to remember the debates when the Governor General ceased to be a representative of the British government in Australia and became a representative of the British monarch only. I can well remember the debates about the abolition of all remaining rights of appeal to the Privy Council in London. It was only in 1986, with the introduction of the Australia Act, that Australian courts became the final arbiters on Australian law. With the passage of this act, the British parliament finally relented the last of its powers to make laws applying to Australia. I can also remember when it was suggested that an Australian occupy the position of Governor General. The debate was almost ridiculous-just as this debate about whether or not we should become a republic is. All of these issues caused some kind of controversy. They were peddled by those who still long for the return of the empire, by those who say that an Australian republic would be the end of the world as we know it. That is the same kind of scare campaign that the opposition is running around with now. Twenty years down the track, people are wondering what is happening now. I remember the debate about whether an Australian was fit to become Governor General. People were saying, 'We should have some minor, illegitimate lord from Britain as our head of these state.' Twenty years from now, people will look back on these debates and laugh. They will roll about with laughter at the ridiculousness of us wasting the time of the Australian parliament and the community with all this nonsensical debate about something which will be inevitable anyway. It really is inevitable that Australia will become a. republic with an Australian as our head of state-as it should be and as it should have been a long time ago. As I said earlier, the changes the government seeks are minimal. The essential constitutional conventions, principles and practices will remain untouched and in operation. I suspect that, under a republic, this place will operate much as it operates today. The only difference perhaps will be that Mrs Betty Windsor's photographs about the place will be removed and replaced with photographs of the new Australian head of state. I believe that the role of this chamber and the Senate will remain largely unchanged. Australia will be a republic and continue to be a member of the British Commonwealth of nations. The only area we seek to change is the wording of the constitution. We would change 'Governor General' to 'President of the Commonwealth of Australia', ensuring that the person who holds this office is an Australian citizen. This president will perform much the same duties as the Governor General. As happens now, these duties will be carried out on the advice of the government of the day. The president will perform ceremonial duties around Australia and represent Australia abroad. The president will also retain those few powers now held by the Governor General which may be exercised without, or contrary to, ministerial advice. The so-called 'reserve powers' - the power to appoint the Prime Minister and the power to dismiss the Prime Minister and the government-will remain untouched. There has been some argument about why we in the Labor Party should support this. We support the fact that those reserve powers are there, because we realise that it would be in only the most extreme of circumstances-as it was in 1975 when they were illegally used-that those powers would be used. There is some debate about how the head of state should be elected. I favour election by parliament, but I can see merit on both sides. I can see the merit of the president being elected by the people like, say, the Irish President and the French President, and I can see the merit of the president being elected by the parliament. So I am not going to the wall over this one. But I do think that, if we are going to have a non-political person in that office, it is inevitable that he or she be elected by the parliament, because once there is a campaign, as we saw in the recent French election campaign, the president becomes a very political person-and it is a political act electing that person. We as members of parliament are elected by the people. I think that a president who is elected by the parliament would be elected with the agreement of both sides of the parliament. As with the appointment of governors-general, it takes that political aspect away from the role of the president. If we want people in that position who command the respect of the majority of the population, I believe that it is only by having them chosen by a two-thirds majority in a joint sitting of the two chambers that we will get that. We, the members of parliament, are elected by the people and in that way we would be representing the people. I cannot for the life of me see how a constitutional convention of 200 elected people and 200 appointed people can be seen to be reflective of the Australian point of view. The 200 appointed people would obviously be reflective of whoever appoints them. The real difficulty that the opposition has in this whole debate is that fundamentally it does not believe that an Australian should be this country's head of state. I know there is some division there, but in the main its problem is that it does not believe in an Australian occupying that position. Australia is making its way in this complex world. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs BISHOP
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Mackellar) (1.02 p.m.)The question of an Australian republic is not something that is new on the agenda. It has been around since the time that Federation itself was considered. It has been to date a concept which has been rejected on a basis of argument that has been both logical and . sensible. From my own point of view, I have always asked two questions of those who would bring about change to achieve the end that they desire. The first is: what is the nature of the change that those people who propose it wish to have? The second is: how will that make Australia a better place? From my own perspective, I have heard no sensible answer to the second question, and only recently have we heard from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) an answer to the first. Having heard his answer to the first, I am still of the opinion that our present system serves us very well. But, if we are to have a debate-and I am never one to run from a debate; I am always anxious to take part-I think we have to have a fulsome debate and look at what flows from the possibility of change. I do not have a crystal ball, I have never pretended to have a crystal ball, so I do not know what may happen in the future and I do not know what event may act as a catalyst for change. I do know that at the present time we have not got one, and when you bring about change in a vacuum you usually get it wrong. If you bring about change when there is a catalyst, you can usually see the direction that you ought to follow. Had we lost World War II and not been the victors, we would be operating under a very different system indeed. We would not be the constitutional monarchy that we are today which ensures freedom of speech for individuals, which ensures the right to achieve maximum potential and enables us to conduct ourselves as a truly multicultural society where the contribution of every individual is acknowledged and important. I have not seen any riQts in the streets by people saying, 'We haye to:bring about change to our constitution because, we are. not free.' I have heard the arguments put forward in a manner that reflects, I think, prejudice of a different sort, perhaps in the manner of one of the speeches we might have heard earlier this day. The proposal that has come forward starts from a premise which is fundamentally flawed. The opening premise is that a very small change-a minimalist change-can be made and nothing else will change. The system will continue to function as it is. That is a flawed proposition. It will be argued that there can be an election by the parliament: that is, a collegiate election of a head of state and that this person somehow remains above the political process. Nonsense. Once that person is elected-it does not matter whether the election is by collegiate system, as in the United States of America where the president is elected by a college of votes, or whether the head of state is elected by the people in a plebiscite-the bottom line is that the head of state is an elected person, and an elected person always has a mandate. Under our current system, appointment by Her Majesty the Queen is the method by which we select a head of state who is truly above politics. Very simply, the Prime Minister of the day selects an individual and makes a recommendation to the Queen. That nomination may be rejected-convention has it that it is not-and the appointment is duly made. Bill Hayden, when he was appointed to the position, acted up until that moment entirely as a political person. After he was appointed to the position he has behaved, as have all governors-general, in an apolitical way and has carried out the responsibilities in a non-political way. The other day, when the Governor General chose to speak his mind on a number of subjects, his remarks were of interest for people to read, but they had no political clout because he is a man without a mandate. Had the same person been an elected president and made that speech, it would become politically relevant. The difference is quite substantial. To' say that there can be a minimalist change and that all things will continue on as they are is like saying that you can be a little bit pregnant. You cannot-things flow from the change. If the time comes that there is ever to be an elected president, my view is that the people should do the electing. That is the view that the rest of Australia seems to have-if the polls are any guide. Although I do recall that in 1988 we were faced with a referendum to change the constitution and in the opinion polls, about 80 per cent of people said, 'Yes, this change is excellent and we must have it,' but once we got into the detail of it and what it was really entailing not one single state passed the referendums. It is important that we look at the detail and what is really involved. Let us suppose that the people had their way. If there were to be a change and a president were to be elected by the people, what would flow from that? Currently, we operate under what we call the Westminster system, although I suggest that under the current government we do not. Under this government we see instances where ministers who have been found wanting and in error have refused to resign until they are virtually forced from office-for example, Mrs Kelly over sports rorts or Graham Richardson over the infamous Marshall Islands affair. There have been many instances where people have not behaved in accordance with the Westminster principle. Under the Westminster principle we should have an apolitical Public Service; that is, a public service which merely serves the government of the day to the best of its ability with the best research and effort that is possible. Unfortunately, that is no longer the case either. Although there are first-class, splendid public servants who wish to perform in that way, through the influence of the current government we have public servants in senior positions who are very political in the way they behave. So we look at what is an alternative to Ii Westminster system should we have an elected president. One model we can look at is the congressional system in the United States. There it has a true doctrine of the separation of powers, not as we have here. Here, although we have the judiciary separate from the legislature and the executive, we do not separate the executive and the legislature. Our ministers come from the legislative body, in this chamber and across the way, but under the congressional system, where there is a true doctrine of the separation of powers in operation, the executive comes by way· of appointment by the president from people outside the elected congress. It may well be that, if we were to move to an elected presidential system, the people of Australia may also consider that to move to an appointed executive outside the elected membership may be a better way to proceed. It is often heard in debate from people who criticise the calibre of the ministers-and anyone who sees this chamber on B-day when the B-team is in can see it-that there is a lot lacking. The point is this: if we are to embrace the thought of change and have a true debate, we need a forum where it can be held honestly. This is not the place for that debate because here, under our Westminster system-altered and perhaps corrupted as it is-we still have the system where the Prime Minister, the person who says he has a majority in the House to support the passage of the appropriation bills through both houses of parliament, is given a commission to form a government by the head of state, the Governor General, Bill Hayden; and he looked pretty Australian to me last time. I took a look. That government then consists of the people chosen by the Prime Minister, the man to whom the commission is given. He currently selects about 30 people to become members of the Executive Council. Those people and those people alone form the government. The Labor Party backbenchers are no more members of government than I am. Their responsibility is the same as mine; that is, to provide laws which are for the peace, order and good government of the people of Australia. Their positioning on the right-hand side of the Speaker's chair is merely to indicate that they are giving support to the government to ensure the passage of its legislation and particularly the appropriation bills-the granting of supply. We saw in 1975 that it is the Governor General who is the head of state in this country, who holds the reserve powers, who has the power to sack the government of the day, which simply means he or she withdraws the commission that has been given because that government can no longer carry out its undertaking to ensure the passage of supply. So that is the way the system works. But, if we are to have the change to the president, we could see the situation where the president of the day has been elected by two-thirds of the parliament, as the Prime Minister would wish, and he sends his legislation up to the head of state and the head of state says, 'Veto.' The Prime Minister says, 'You can't do that to me.' 'Yes, I can,' says the president, 'just watch me. Now get two-thirds of the parliament to sack me.' It might be a piece of legislation like the new 12 per cent wholesale sales tax with regard to building materials that might be chosen to be vetoed, and two-thirds of the parliament might think that is a jolly good idea. There are lots of questions that have to be addressed. There are lots of queries and uncertainties that need to be debated, and the place to have that is in a people's forum, because in this place it is only the government of the day that can introduce the bill for the referendum. It is only the government which would have input into what goes into that bill and it would be a take it or leave it scenario. But, if you have a people's convention, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has proposed and given an undertaking to have, the people who are not truly represented in their view, as they see it, will have a say. The government of the day has said it will only offer a president who is elected by the parliament, and the people of Australia have shown that they do not want that, and it is only the government of the day which will have a say as to what goes into that bill that brings about the referendum. However, under our system, there is even a fail-safe mechanism. There is the people's convention, and then there is a plebiscite. The plebiscite would have the following options: elected by the parliament, elected by the people, status quo, et cetera. So a whole range of things could come out of that. Depending on the outcome of that plebiscite, the referendum would then be formulated. It would not be formulated by the government of the day. It would not be formulated by the now Prime Minister saying; 'I, me, myself, personally, Paul Keating, am going to dictate that that is the choice you will be given,' but by the option being given to hundreds of Australians to have the opportunity to take part in the discussion process. I have always said that, once we got into the detail, the nature of the debate on the republic would change dramatically, and it has. We are now looking at the detail in earnest. We are looking at the ramifications. We are looking at what we want-from now and forever more-as our system of governance. The government has answered the first question by putting up a proposal. It is one which I reject. The opposition offers a more acceptable alternative. The second question-how it makes Australia a better place-remains to be answered by those who say they want to bring about the change as manifested in the Prime Minister's greater wish. As we debate this, we know that the option is one of choice. The government offers none. The option is to take what the Prime Minister of the day wishes it to be or to allow the people of Australia to have a say in what happens to their constitution. The bottom line is that the constitution of Australia belongs to the Australian people. It does not belong to the Prime Minister or to the government of the day. It is not their plaything. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: MCEwen) (1.17 p.m.)The honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) should know that no-one suggests that the Australian constitution is anything the property of the Australian people. For any person in this House to suggest that any member of this House has a different view is an outrageous lie. It is simply not true.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Mr Andrew)I think the honourable member for MCEwen should

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: If it offends the House, then I withdraw the expression 'lie' and I will say that it is an 'untruth'.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I would be grateful.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I withdraw 'outrageous lie' and say 'outrageous untruth', which is within the forms of the House. It is an untruth. It is a nonsense to suggest that a constitution of the type that Australia has is anything but the property of the people. It is the same as suggesting that this parliament is owned by the politicians who inhabit it. It is not. It is a product of the will of the Australian people. I reject the nonsense spoken by some members on the other side of the House. The honourable member for Mackellar has, like other members of the opposition, put up this furphy that the Governor General is the head of state of Australia. It is an absolute nonsense. Either they do not understand what the Australian constitution is or they have not read it. The Australian constitution is, in fact, a bill of the British parliament. It clearly defines that the head of state of Australia is the monarch of Great Britain whom, in some strange way, we call the Queen of Australia. However, the reality is that the British monarch is simply that-the British monarch. Queen Elizabeth II is a fine and upright woman. I have met her, and I have nothing but admiration for her. Nevertheless, she is the monarch of Great Britain. By some strange legal reasoning, Australia has decided to adopt her and call her the Queen of Australia. Clearly, the head of state is the British monarch. So no-one in the coalition should try to promote this nonsense that somehow the Governor General is the Australian head of state. The Governor General's role in the Australbut Ian constitution is as a representative of Australia's head of state. The role of the Governor General is to represent the Queen in Australia and to be the representative of Her Majesty in the Executive Council under the formulation and the rules which exist in the Australian constitution. When we have a debate such as this, the lack of understanding in this House on the nature of the Australian constitution is also something that worries me. The constitution is a document which is vacant on most of the important things that matter in running this parliament. For example, most Australians do not understand that there is no such thing as a Prime Minister mentioned in the entire Australian constitution. It is not mentionednot once. It is a convention that there is a Prime Minister. It is not written into our constitution. It is a convention, because we understand that without the conventions operating we would not have a constitution which would work. So the Australian constitution is lacking in almost everything that a modem constitution needs. We are only talking about one part of it-a minor part of it. I must say that, if I my way, I would rewrite the entire constitution, because it is a terribly deficient document. Can you imagine having a constitution which does not recognise the position of Prime Minister? It does not mention the word once in the entire documeqt. It operates only on the basis of what we call conventions. Conventions are simply unwritten rules which people in the political system accept as being proper and reasonable so that the system can in fact run. Without the recognition of the conventions, we would not have a parliament that would work. That is how bad the Australian constitution really is. To some members opposite it is some sacred document written in blood-something magical and special. The fact is, of course, that when it was written it was written in conflict. It was a compromise. It is not a perfect document. It was a compromise between six competing colonies who were not particularly interested in a federation. They wanted to maintain their own separate political identities. There were free traders and protectionists. Again, I do wish some people in this House would actually pick up a book on Australian history and read it. I do wish they would actually learn the background to how the Australian constitution came into existence. The vast bulk of conventions, so-called, were held to draft the Australian constitution were not elected. Only one was elected-the last one. But the conventions that actually drew up the constitution were not elected because, in most locally held referenda, the Australian people did not want to federate. It was the leaders of the day, who understood the great need for Australia to become a great nation, who led the arguments and brought the general feeling of the people with them. That is what needs to be done in changing a constitution. You need leaders. You need all people to stand up and put a proposition to people and say, 'We believe we need change and this is the change we believe we need.' That is called leadership. It might be that the Australian people reject that view. Nevertheless, the fact that it has been brought into the public domain, that it is now a topic which is had being publicly debated, is only because there is a leader-the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is not the sort of thing we would ever get from the other side of the House. There is never any leadership from that side in terms of change. The Australian constitution was developed by people such as Deakin, despite the general lack of will in the then colonies to federate. We eventually got federation because there were leaders back then who were prepared to carry the people, take some political flak and run the argument. So it is important that the argument be put. It is important that we debate it. It may well be that the end result of change to the Australhm constitution may not be what I necessarily agree with because, ultimately, it will be Australian people who make the decision-not me, not this parliament, not the Prime Minister, but the Australian people. However, it is proper that views are put on what sorts of changes we, collectively or individually, see as necessary. I have probably given more oaths to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, her heirs and successors to title than most other Australians. From the cubs, the scouts and the venturers, to the police force, the citizen's military forces and local government, as a justice of the peace and on being admitted as a barrister and solicitor of Victoria and of New South that Wales-I have given oaths to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II, her heirs and successors to title so. how many times that I have lost count of them. Why? It is because she is the nominal head of state. But, as an Australian, I have always wondered why I am being asked to pledge my loyalty to Queen Elizabeth II of England. She is a nice person. Mr Hollis-Likes dogs.

Speaker: Mr CLEELAND
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Likes dogs, corgis. I have got no beef with her. I have been privileged to meet with her on more than one occasion. On the other hand, she is not an Australian citizen; she is a foreigner. That is an unarguable fact. She does not have Australian citizenship. She is a foreigner. I have often wondered when I have taken multiple oaths over the years why I was being asked as an Australian to give an oath of loyalty and allegiance to a British monarch. I am pleased that finally I am getting the chance to say in this parliament that I am an Australian first, an Australian second, an Australian third, and I would like to have an Australian head of state. There is nothing wrong with that. Some people can disagree with it. Some people can say they are happy to have a British citizen as the head of state of Australia. That is an acceptable view if that is what they want. But I am an Australian, and I want an Australian head of state. I do not want to be represented by a foreigner-be that foreigner British, American or whatever. If people want to criticise me for that, let them. If they want to be represented by a foreigner, let them stand up and say that. That is the major issue that has to be first answered: do Australians want an Australian head of state or do Australians want a foreign head of state? We can debate all of these things, but until members of the opposition answer that principal question we will not get to first base because their proposals, quite frankly, avoid the issue. The whole philosophy behind the approach of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) of having a convention of which 50 per cent would be elected and 50 per cent appointed by him-no doubt, as Prime Minister-is to avoid the issue. It is to avoid having to put a question to the people in the first place. It is the way the conservatives of this country want to avoid the debate. It puts it away, puts it aside, and does not solve the issue. Why is there a fear of the debate? Are the conservatives of this country and in this parliament frightened of the debate because they have not got the numbers out there? Is that the reason they would go for this quite nonsensical approach of having 50 per cent appointed by the Leader of the Opposition, no doubt, and 50 per cent elected. We do not know how they are going to be elected or what the franchise would be. We do not know anything about how the other 50 per cent would be elected. We do not know what reference the convention would be given. We do not know what they would be asked to discuss, what the details are of what the convention would be asked to do. Assuming this convention accepted the view that Australia should change to an Australian head of state, we have no guarantee at all from the opposition that it would do it. If the opposition is elected, puts up its convention and, despite having 50 per cent of its members appointed so 'that it can control them, the convention recommends that there be a referendum, a minimalist position, and accepts an Australian as an Australian head of state, there is no guarantee a conservative government would put it to the Australian people. It is a nonsense. What is' their fear? Why are honourable members frightened of asking the Australian people? I frankly do not understand it. I do not understand why anyone in this parliament would be frightened of the Australian people having the choice. The proposition put forward by the Leader of the Opposition denies that choice, takes it away from people and stifles the process. I am totally baffled as to why the opposition is frightened of the Australian people and frightened of why they should not have that choice. I noted that the member for Mackellar was talking about the Public Service in Australia and the apolitical nature she thinks it should have. The implication of what she said is that the Public Service in Australia is politicised. That was the allegation she put to the House in this debate. If there has ever been a politicised body in this country it was wh-n Barwick went to the High Court, as Chief Justice Barwick. When Barwick was the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia the Australian taxation system was totally tom asunder. Under section 260 of the tax act, a very simple section-I would say a five-year-old child could tell you what it meant-tax avoidance was illegal. That is all it said, but somehow or other the Barwick court managed to rule that that did not mean anything. Under Barwick, people of privilege and people of wealth were given the option of paying no tax. Professor Russell clearly demonstrated in a report to this House that, under Barwick and under this apolitical system that the honourable member for Mackellar suggests applies when the opposition is in government, the taxation system was destroyed. Who was the Treasurer who did nothing to stem the rapid outflow of revenue at the time? The now Leader of the Opposition. Let us have none of this nonsense, this waffle, from the member for Mackellar about this government criticising the Public Service. We know full well how it is done because over the years we have seen just how good the opposition is at destroying legislation through its mates getting the jobs. I support an Australian republic; I have long supported an Australian republic. My ancestors came here in 1776; they were British; they married into Irish stock on my father's side. No-one has better credibility this debate, and I support a republic. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: The speech of the previous speaker, the honourable member for MCEwen (Mr Cleeland), was somewhat lacking in credibility when he was starting to presume what the opposition position is. It is quite clear that a people's convention will be called and that it will decide which questions go to a referendum. The Australian people will have the chance to decide whether we remain a monarchy or move to a republic. Nothing could be clearer than that. I find it quite bizarre that we are having this debate in the chamber for most of the day when there are other issues out there that are concerning my constituents more than this. We have a debt in this country, for example, that is greater than Mexico's. It is unbelievable that we have been reduced to that status under this government. A debt· greater than Mexico's is something that we ought to be ashamed of, something that we certainly should be doing something about, and the government will not even allow us to have a question time tomorrow to talk about the current account deficit figures when they come out, let alone have a debate on the debt that this country is carrying, which is now greater than Mexico's. In this country we have public hospital health queue numbers which run to six figures, the federal government has virtually halved federal road funding, and we have three-quarters of a million unemployed. We are just, hopefully, coming out of one of the worse droughts in history arid, while farmers are still being denied a basic, civilised type of welfare system because of a government that could not care less, it seems, about people who are destitute, even though they are people who are contributing to the country, we are here today having a debate on the republic. A debate on the republic will cost the parliament, depending how long it goes, something like $200,000 or $300,000 today alone. I would like to have that money, for example, for three kilometres of bitumen between Bourke and Wanaaring. I am sure in my constituents out there would prefer that. But why are we having this debate? We are having it because the government is using it as a diversionary tactic from the problems, some of which I have just mentioned, that are besetting this country, and apparently because of the apparent paranoia of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about anything that is British. In the 11 years that I have been a member of parliament I have not had one constituent come to my office and request that Australia move toward a republic. I have not had one person telephone me and I have not had one letter on the subject. I do not deny.that there may be people out there who hold this view, which is quite right and proper to have in a democracy, but it is obviously not a burning issue with them. There are 80,000 voters in my electorate and 110,000 constituents when you count those under 18 years-and never in 11 years has anyone approached me on this particular matter. They certainly are not tossing and turning in their sleep about this issue; I can assure the government of that. Despite that, this government is going ahead with the proposal. The referendum alone is going to cost about $50 million. doubt literature will go out to every hold in Australia putting the for and against case beforehand and that will cost several million dollars more. We have a debt worse than Mexico's debt and yet these are the sorts of things being proposed. Why are the Australian people not demandbehind ing that this happen in the same way as the government is demanding it happen? The that reasons are that they have other problems which they give a higher priority to and that they are relatively happy with the system that we have in this country. We have a stable system of government that is envied by the rest of the world. We live in a very free country, a very tolerant, multicultural country. We have a system that has delivered a very high standard of living. It is a country that has allowed us to express the unique AustralParkes Ian characteristic that this continent has bestowed on all of us. We are even a member of the Commonseem wealth of Nations and it is interesting to note that 22 out of the 51 members are still monarchies; the others are republics. It is a little ironic to me because I have always felt that in a sense Australia really is a republic. know we call it a monarchy but to all intents and purposes, given the way the system works in this country, we already are a republic. not know what the percentage would be but Australia would be very close to 99 per cent a republic anyhow. We have only got this little bit tacked on the end, this one per cent, this monarchy bit tacked on the end, and it totally harmless. It gives the Queen no tive power whatsoever over the running of this country. If the Queen had some power to the time. direct us how to conduct the laws of this nation or our daily lives, I too would be arguing that that link be cut. But the Queen has no power whatsoever to direct us in how we conduct our business in this country. Even if she did, while we might listen we would look not respond. Concerning this little bit tacked on the end, the poms pay for it anyhow. It is not as though it is a cost to us, for heaven's sake. They pay for it. It seems to me that we are getting the best of both worlds. We have the No best of both systems. We have the best of a houserepublican system-which essentially we the are-and the best of a monarchical system because of this little bit tacked on the end. I can cast my mind back to the experiences that I have had. Two or three years ago the Queen came to Dubbo. I was walking a step her for most of the day during the activities and I was staggered at the welcome the people on the footpaths gave her and the emotion they showed. It amazed me. A year or so ago, Prince Charles had some dreadful difficulties in his private life. At that time, he visited Parkes and Forbes for a day. I was curious to see how the public would react to him after all the adverse publicity he had received. However, it did not seem to make any difference. There were crowds the size of which had never been seen before in and Forbes, and those people were all willing to wish Prince Charles well. I thought, 'This costs us nothing. The public seem to love it. Why deny them the pleasure they to get from this sort of thing?' In the mid-1980s, when I had been a member of the House for a short time, I attended a peace conference in Bulgaria. In those days I Bulgaria was probably the most repressive communist country in the world. It is a wonderful country and, fortunately, that I do system has now gone. I had never been to a communist country before, and apart from the stark, colourless concrete buildings and streets everywhere, and the people with blank looks on their faces, the thing that horrified me the is most was that on the buildings were enormous effecphotos of Marx, Engels, Lenin and Todor Zhikov, who was the president of Bulgaria at The monarchy had been banished in Bulgaria. It had been made illegal. Religion had also been outlawed. It dawned on me for the first time in my life that the average man and woman in the street likes to have someone to up to. It can be argued that it is illogical. It is illogical, but the average man and woman in the street likes to look up to someone. If the monarchy is banished and religion is banished, all that is left is the politicians. What could be more unhealthy than to have people looking up to politicians in that way? I found it quite repulsive. The system we have in Australia-even though I have said that it is essentially a republican one already-allows us, because of this little bit we have tacked onto the end, to avoid the worse elements of a republic that exist in many other countries. Those elements are ugly, costly and colourless, even in the world's great countries. I have recently returned from looking at the political system in America. When I was visiting the White House, President Clinton drove past. I was standing on the footpath with hundreds of people when he drove past. Some women standing in front of me were almost swooning because the President had driven past. Yet he is an elected representative. It was not an edifying spectacle. It is wrong that elected representatives should be looked up to in that way. It is best to have non-elected representatives fill those positions. It needs to be asked, if we have a republic-and to be frank, I do not lose any sleep over it one way or the other-what will it give us? I dare say it will give a warm inner glow to those on the other side of the chamber. If that is something that they cherish, then good luck to them, but it is not going to affect my life much one way or the other. It is no guarantee that things are going to get better. Let us examine republics around the world. One that we would have admired-France-is letting off nuclear explosions. Germany does not have a system that I admire. I would not like to transplant America's system here, having just had a look at it. The system in other republics-such as Russia or Ethiopiais not for me. The system we have today, with this little bit tacked on, reflects our history. I do not want to deny our history. I am proud of it. The system of justice in this country emanates from Great Britain. The system of democracy that we have in Australia, which I think is the finest in the world, comes from Great Britain. The system of education in this country, which we cherish so much, comes from that part of the world. The language that we speak also comes from that part of the world. This country has the best systems in the world. Yet the government says that we have to become mature, take that final step and totally cut the links with Great Britain. I can see some logic to that argument. But it is a little like a child leaving home who refuses to have his or her parents come and visit once in while, or to let them have any influence whatsoever, even of a symbolic type. I think it is a sign of maturity, not a sign of immaturity, that we still have this. It adds colour to our lives. I just gave the example of the socialist republic of Bulgaria, which was totally colourless in the mid-1980s. If we want to take away the system that we have got now, well and good, but I think we will be at least a little diminished by it. There will be significant changes, even down to the trivial things. I just looked at my local telephone directory, which is mainly based on Dubbo, and found there were 24 royal prefixes in the telephone book. In the Sydney phone book, there were 189. I see that Senator MCMullan, in a press release of some time ago, said: It is inappropriate for national organisations to be seeking to add themselves to the list of those with royal titles. This is the sort of directive, no doubt, that will be emanating more rapidly from the government when we do become a republic. Is it such a crime that we call a yacht club 'The Royal Yacht Club', or a blind society 'The Royal Blind Society'? What are we are going to change the name of the flying doctor service to? Will we call it the 'Republic Flying Doctor Service', instead of the 'Royal Flying Doctor Service', so we can keep the same initials and not add the cost of changing the emblem? Mr O'Keefe-What's wrong with calling it the 'Australian Flying Doctor Service'? What is wrong with you people, for heaven's sake?

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: There is nothing wrong with calling it 'Australian'. If the people, of their own free will and volition, choose to call it that, what is wrong with that, in a democracy? What is wrong with that? To be frank with you, it does not trouble me much, one way or another. But here is the government giving directives that one must not call the flying doctor service the 'Royal Flying Doctor Service'. I think it is a farcical stage that we have reduced ourselves to. What is next? Are we going to change the name of Queensland, for obvious reasons, or change the name of Victoria because it resembles 'Queen Victoria'? Presumably, New South Wales will be next, because it resembles somewhere in Wales. Where do we end with this? Is the Prime Minister embarrassed when he is overseas, because we have a so called queen as head of state? Is he going to be embarrassed to go into a pub to have a beer because it is called the Royal Hotel? Is that what the government has next in line for us? What a farce. One wonders where it will all stop. The solution that the government has put up is the Tippex solution: we will cross out 'governor-general' and write in 'president'. It is much more complicated than that. I am sorry I do not have time to elaborate on those arguments. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Werriwa) (1.47 p.m) My first memory of the monarchy comes from 1 May 1970, when, as a nine-year-old student at Ashcroft Primary School, I lined the street to watch Princess Anne pass by on her way to opening the Green Valley Community Centre. I was there because the school had made it compulsory. For me, it was a curiosity. For a schoolboy standing on the streets of working-class Green Valley, nothing could have been more curious than the idea that we were, in any way, associated with a familythe royal family-founded on the worse traditions of social hierarchy, elitism and class distinction. For a schoolboy born in Australia, knowing nothing of Britain other than from school books, nothing could be more foreign than the idea that we were in some way affiliated to Britain. For Australians of my generation, without memories of or emotions for Britain, Australian independence is a natural feeling. That is what makes the Republic so inevitable: the natural feeling of Australian independence. This is what makes this debate, and the historic statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), so compelling. There is something special about feeling proud of one's country. In most respects, national pride is at the heart of this debate. To feel proud of Australia-to feel strongly about this country-is to want Australia to be strong. We are stronger when we stand on our own two feet, when we do things our way and when we express ourselves in an independent way. Let there be no doubt-we would be stronger; as a people and as a nation, if the Australian head of state were an Australian citizen. Indeed, the move to the republic is part of Australia's growing maturity, and part of our passage from adolescence to adulthood as a nation. If I can continue the analogy further, the formulation of the Australian constitution from the 1890s led to Australia's birth as a federated nation in 1901. In this debate it is very important to get a feel and appreciation for the national mood and the politics of that era, now 100 years ago. Australia had, as its earliest and strongest emotion-this goes back as far as 1788-the need for protection, the need to shelter the colony, as it was at that time, from what was regarded as a vulnerable place in the world. It is not surprising, if we consider how insecure those early Australians would have been at the thought of being part of a penal colony. Two hundred years ago Australia was a convict colony at the bottom of the world, isolated from what, at that time, was the homeland in Europe. As a result of those feelings of insecurity at the very first time of white settlement in Australia, this feeling of protection was woven into our culture, our institutions and our system of government. The sense of insecurity and the need for protection was given expression through tariff protection, the attempt to shelter Australian markets from overseas goods. It was expressed through the White Australia policy which enjoyed bipartisan political support for so long, giving expression to the feeling that we needed to lock out people from other races and other nations, particularly in Asia. The sense of insecurity was expressed through our foreign policy: our reliance on the protection of, firstly, the Royal Navy and, during and after the Second World War, the United States of America. It was also expressed through the cultural cringe: the feeling that the only worthwhile items of culture and expression could come from Britain. Robert Hughes, in his outstanding book, The Fatal Shore, captures the mood so well: The idea that whether or not England should feel ashamed of creating the [convict] system, Australians certainly had cause to be proud of surviving it and creating their own values despite it, was rarely heard. In Australia at that time, and indeed for more than a century, Britain was seen as the only source of social respectability. Again, according to Hughes: Nothing could be allowed to diminish the gratitude Australians were meant to feel for the imperial umbrella. The essence of colonisation was that they could claim no history of their own . . . educators played their part, with the result that it became impossible to find in any history book in any Australian schools up to the mid-1960s, a satisfactory or even coherent account of penal Australia. In this respect, British trade, British arts, British literature, British symbols, British institutions and, most of all, the British monarchy, were used by Australians for so many decades of our early history as part of the search for respectability. For the tories of that time-and for the tories of this time-it was all about touching the hem of the British monarchy, that feeling of cultural insecurity and cultural cringe, and the search for what was regard as social respectability. The popular culture of those years of course reinforced the view of the British as a superior race of people. The royal family stood at the pinnacle of that system. The republic is about breaking the cultural cringe for all time. It is about recognising, for all time, that Australia should assume in all aspects of our social and cultural fabric the responsibilities of an independent and mature nation. The cultural cringe extended far beyond the realm of the arts. For so many years, it made the country wary of assuming proper responsibili ties. But we have broken free and matured and picked up responsibilities in so many areas. We show confidence in the way we have internationalised our economy; we no longer feel insecure about pursuing a place in the world economy. We have matured and picked up responsibilities through an independent defence and foreign policy. We have picked up responsibilities through transport and communication improvements which have integrated Australia as a nation. We have picked up responsibility in culture, in the arts and letters, with a distinctive and . a very proud sense of Australian cultural identity. We have picked up our proper responsibilities towards Aboriginal people with the historic decision of the High Court and the legislation of this parliament for native title. The republic and constitutional change in the 1990s' is about topping up that process, breaking the cringe for all time. In our constitutional arrangements we should exercise the proper responsibilities of a mature, independent nation by making an Australian our head of state. Breaking the cringe says something about Australia's identity and our sense of worth. The republic in many respects should be seen as a celebration of the Australian achievement. Far from cringing, we should be telegraphing it and informing the world that we are very proud of what we have achieved in this nation, to settle a harsh country and build economic prosperity. To do it within a tolerant, progressive, egalitarian society is one of the great achievements of the Western world, and constitutional independence can top it off. Constitutional independence would be the full expression of nationhood and the ultimate celebration of the great Australia achievement. The Economist magazine said it well in June of last year: Only colonies continue to borrow the monarchies of other lands.
