I would urge the Liberal and National party representatives in this house to take a look acr?ss the Tasman, where a small trading natIon at the bottom of the South Pacific, led - n that instance by a conservative government, IS breaking free of the colonial mentality. Jim Bolger, the New Zealand Prime Minister, is trying to advance the cause of a New Zealand republic. Let me quote Bolger: I see it as completing the journey from colony to nationhood. New Zealand is in similar circumstances to Australia in the broad sweep of history. Its Prime Minister, a conservative Prime So, - inister, sees the republic as completing the Journey from colony to nationhood. As it in New Zealand, it should be in Australia. More than that, the republic represents great opportunity to rectify some of the problems with the constitutional monarchy. the end of the day, in a modem, liberal, Bill 1953: progressive, egalitarian society, the monarchy can be regarded, and I think broadly is reThe - arded, throughout Australia as unrepresentatIve and undemocratic. There across the nation to filling public offices in a fashion which relies on inheritance. It is contrary to the belief that all people are born equal in status, dignity and opportunity. rules of succession for the monarchy as we have them in Australia discriminate on the basis of religion, sex and birth. Section 116 of the Australia constitution prohibits the imposition of any religious test as a qualificaAustralian tion for any office under the Commonwealth, yet our head of state, the British monarch also serves as the head of the Church. Further, our own Sex Discrimination Act would render the rules of succession unlawful in Australia, because they discriminate activea ly for men and discriminate against women. Fo- - ustralians interested in social equality, relIgIOUS tolerance and equal opportunity between the sexes, the monarchy has become an unrepresentative, unsuitable, divisive institution in our society. It has been used in the past to show that Australians were of British stock. That is clearly no longer the case. The monarchy is perhaps well suited a class ridden society like Britain, but it totally unsuited to Australia's egalitarian traditions. Francis Adams in his Australian Essays put it best as long ago as 1886: The people. in Australia breathe free. They do not feel the weIght of the great divisions of the middle class that is above them, the well-to-do and the gentlemen. Working men here do not go slouching down the streets, as they do in England, crushed under - e sense of their inferiority ... This is a true republIc, the truest, as I take it, in the world. In England the average man feels that he is inferior: in America he feels that he is superior: in Australia he feels that he is equal. That is indeed delightful. if we have had in our social status, in our social fabric, this feeling of republic egalitaris ianism, it should be fully confirmed now in the 1990s in Australia's constitutional arrangements. For once, on this matter I can a a-ree with the founder of the Liberal Party, SIr Robert Menzies. He said in the second At reading speech on the Royal Style and Titles plain truth is that Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second sits on the throne not because of some law of Australia but because of the law of the is an objection United Kingdom. Menzies thought that was acceptable because he regarded himself as British, as of British The stock. But now, when Australians no longer regard themselves in that fashion, it is no longer suitable for the Australian head of state to be determined by British law. The Australian head of state should be one of us. The head of state should be determined by Australians under Australian laws passed by this parliament and confirmed at a constiAnglica- tutional referendum. The truth of the matter is 'that an Australian citizen, under the current arrangements, can never be the Australian head of state. That is decisive breach, an unacceptable breach, of Australian sovereignty and independence. It is interesting to note that Prince Charles himself acknowledged as much in June last year when he said that, as an heir and successor, he would rather be seen as a defender of faith than a defender of 'the faith'. That is, he acknowledged that all citizens are equally important irrespective of religion. It is divisto ive for the monarchy to be associated with is just one form and one expression of faith. Prince Charles also said that it is absurd the monarch should be prevented from marrying a Catholic. So if Prince Charles believes the monarchy, as presently structured, does not represent all Britons, how can it represent all Australians? Prince Charles is saying that the head of state in Britain must be representative of British society. In Australia, surely that means the head of state must be an Australian. A republic is a state in which sovereignty is derived from people, not from inheritance, and in which all public offices are filled by persons ultimately deriving their authority from the people. The only Australian office incompatible with a republic is the monarchy, and the only change required to overcome that shortcoming is to remove the monarchy from our constitution. When the Queen visits Australia she is seen more as the Queen of Britain than the Queen of Australia, otherwise she serves as an absentee head of state. When the Queen visits other nations, she is seen as the Queen of Britain .. Australia does not have a head of state who can represent this nation overseas and be seen by foreign citizens as our head of state, as an Australian. That, in their eyes, makes Australia look like a colony. Some of the comments of the British head of state when she travels overseas could potentially contradict Australian foreign policy and trade interests. The truth is this: not only is the monarchy unrepresentative and undemocratic by the standards of the 1990s but also the royal family itself is discredited. I noticed in the Australian newspaper earlier this month that the British Scout Association has decided to disaffiliate itself from Prince Charles, saying, 'It will be hard for some people to promise'that is, to swear-'their allegiance of duty to an adulterer.' What a telltale sign-that the British monarchy in the 1990s cannot sustain the support of the British Scout Association. For the monarchy as an institution, particularly in this country, it is five minutes to midnight. Time is up for the monarchy. It is time for Australia to express itself as a mature, independent, egalitarian and progressive nation. It is time we had an Australian as our head of state. We need to make sure that our head of state is one of us.

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: It is an interesting debate that has been taking place today with regard to the speech made on an Australian republic by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). The state of play between the political parties involved, as far as that goes, is the main area I want to address in speaking on this matter this afternoon. At this stage, it has predominantly been a political debate. It is far too important an issue to contemplate it being controlled by politics. Mr Latham interjecting

Speaker: Mr VAILE
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: It is. You have had your go. We should be empowering the people of Australia to participate in the whole process of developing the models if we are going to go down this path. The government of today will present to the people of Australia the option that they vote either yes or no on how to go about this, how to develop it, how to structure this move. As has been indicated in the polls, the majority of people in Australia do not agree with that system either. The government should be very cognisant of that fact. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), served a fairly lengthy time in local government, where people demand a say. I also have a background in local government. He was probably elected to the mayoral position, which he held before he came into this place, by popular vote as well. It is the absolute basis of the democratic process of Australia. You cannot devolve the power any lower than to give all the people a say in who leads them or in what happens in the country. It is interesting to note that the government speakers in this debate today have been running the line that the Prime Minister has been running-that is, we want an Australian as our head of state. That is an interesting argument when the occupant of the position of Governor General has, since 1965, always been an Australian. That is the political angle that the government is trying to put on this debate. It is trying to generate a bit more antiBritish emotion. Earlier this year I had the opportunity to visit the United Kingdom with a group of young Australian people from the Labor Party, the National Party, the Liberal Party and the Democrats. When talking to different people throughout the United Kingdom, the one dominant question was: is the government's push or the notion of moving towards a republic in Australia purely born out of a hate for the British? That is the feeling that they are getting in the United Kingdom. We had to dispel that myth and point out that it is not born out of a hate for the British. We pointed out that, unfortunately, that is the line the Prime Minister of Australia is running. We have heard this line from some of the government speakers in this debate. There are a lot of people in Australia who believe that we should be moving towards a republic, but who do not hold the same views as the government. Some people hold the view that maybe Australia has reached the stage where it is going through puberty blues or a change in identity and therefore it is time to revisit the issues. It is really the people Australia who should be having an input. It should not be the 148 representatives in this parliament who make a decision and make this into a political debate between now and when the Prime Minister decides he wants to hold his referendum and ask the people of Australia whether or not they are prepared to accept his option. The coalition's position is that the people of Australia should be involved in this discussion from the beginning. We believe that they should be involved all the way through. The people of Australia should make the decision when we have the constitutional referendum before the tum of the century. What is wrong with giving the people of Australia a decent dose of democracy? It is about time that a few more people around this placeparticularly those on the government siderecognised that we do live in a democratic society and that we should be giving the people of Australia a dose of democracy in relation to this issue. What are the positions at this point? The government has declared that Australia should become a republic by the year 2001. It keeps running the line that the head of state should be an Australian. The opposition says that since 1965 the Governor General, as the Australian head of state, has been an Australian. The key proposal advanced by the government in terms of the establishment of a federal republic is the election of a federal president. It says that the president should be an Australian and elected by a two-thirds majority in a joint sitting of both houses of parliament on the nomination of the Prime Minister and cabinet. The government also believes that the question of Australia becoming a republic should be put to the people in 1998 or 1999. What is the coalition's position? The coalition proposes the establishment of a people's convention in 1997 which would examine not just whether or not Australia should become a republic but other important issues as well. One of the issues is the role of the head of state in the Australian constitution. Another issue is the implications of a change in the role of the states. There is an underlying of complication in this debate which relates to the states. The conundrum could arise where the Commonwealth as a whole wants to head down a certain path but one of the states does not. Other issues that should be addressed at a people's convention are the allocation of legislative and executive powers and functions between federal and state governments, including areas of overlap and duplication; whether we should introduce four-year instead of three-year terms of parliament; and the basis on which new states, in particular the Northern Territory, would be admitted to the federation. Other matters which the people's convention would determine itself would also be discussed. The people's convention would consist of 50 per cent of members who have been appointed by the government of the day, 10 per cent of whom would be between the ages of 18 and 25, and 50 per cent of members who have been elected. The arguments for a people's convention, as put forward by the coalition, include enabling a range of community views to enable proper examination, gauging the mood for change in the Australian community, and providing a forum which unifies rather than divides the community. As I said earlier, we need to devolve power to the lowest possible level and empower the people of Australia with the ability to participate in the development of this debate from start to finish. This provides a forum which unifies rather than divides the community. The Prime Minister says that you are either for the republic or you are against it. He says, 'Either you stand over there or you stand over here with me.' That is not unifying this nation. If that is what the republican debate today is all about, I do not believe it is going down the right path. We should allow the people of Australia to decide the questions and the options for the referendum. We should involve all Australian people at the beginning, the middle and the end of the process. This would create a unifying position for the people of Australia. We should have a broader group of people than the government of the day deciding the arguments for and against, putting the propositions for and against, and developing the questions to be asked in the constitutional referendum. The crux of this whole issue relates to how much say and how much democracy the government is prepared to give the people of Australia. By 'say' I am not just referring to what is written in the newspapers; I am referring to constructive criticism about this whole debate and the direction we are heading in. The current constitutional arrangements have served Australia well, delivering great stability, cohesion and tolerance. Those points cannot be undermined or debated by the government. Australia is one of the most stable countries in the world today, and this is because of our constitutional arrangements. The Prime Minister's comments about an Australian head of state are an attempt to imply that anyone who opposes a republic is a lesser Australian. The reality is that, over the past 30 years, the Governor General has become Australia's constitutional head of state. That position has been occupied by an Australian since 1965. It is unthinkable that anyone but an Australian would occupy that position in the future. Despite the success of the present constitution, many Australians are attracted to the idea of a republic. The coalition believes that the matter should be fully debated and that ultimately a vote should be taken on the issue before the tum of the century. In government, the coalition will in 1997 establish a people's convention to debate the whole issue. Other matters will be discussed at the people's convention. However, the issue of Australia's head of state will be debated first and separate from all other issues. If a consensus emerges from the people's convention regarding the head of state, that consensus will be promoted by the government at a constitutional referendum. If no consensus emerges, then the Australian people will be asked to vote on a series of options for changes to establish which of them they desire. These options for change will include that of electing the president by direct popular vote as well as by a parliamentary vote as proposed by the Prime Minister. Another method of election could also emerge as an option from the whole process of discussion. Naturally, the option of retaining the present system would be included in any vote. The fact is that the government, particularly the Prime Minister, is facing a bit of a problem at the moment. As has been indicated in some of the polls that have been conducted since the speeches of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on this issue, the level of support around Australia for a republic is about 50 per cent. Yet there has been another interesting element to the poll; that is, the question of how we arrive at that position, whether directly via the Prime Minister's approachcome and vote on my development for a republic, on how I want to have it-or via the Leader of the Opposition's process of a people's convention, having a broader base of discussion and debate. It is interesting that 38 per cent supported the approach of holding a people's convention to discuss constitutional reform compared with 36 per cent support for the Keating republican blueprint. What does that tell you? That tells you that, although there is a view across the nation-as yet not a majority view-that Australia should head down the republican path, the people of Australia want to have more involvement in the early stages of the debate. They do not want to be just dished up with a yes or no answer, whether you have this type of republic and we will select or elect the president this way or the head of state this way. They want to be involved in formulating the arguments on both sides of that debate. They want to be involved from the start, through the middle and towards the finish of that debate. I think it flies in the face of everything we stand for in this place as members of this federal parliament, as representatives of the people of Australia, to deny the people of Australia that democratic right in what could possibly be, and arguably will be if we do end up at a constitutional referendum, the most enormous change that we are going to make to the way this country runs, to the constitution of this country, since Federation. I do not believe that the government has the right to deny the people of Australia from having that broader input into that debate in developing those questions. The challenge is there. The cards are quite clearly on the table. On the one hand, there is the proposal by the government of the day, the Prime Minister's blueprint for a republic, to push towards a constitutional referendum in the latter part of this century. On the other hand, there is the very clear position of the coalition-that in 1997 we head for a people's convention so that we can devolve the debate, devolve the power, and empower the people of Australia to have a much broader input into the development of the arguments for and against the question, and the development of the debate, as to whether we should go towards a republic, whether the head of state should be selected and elected by a two-thirds majority of this parliament, or whether the head of state should be elected by everybody in Australia. The people of Australia have the right to have that decent dose of democracy dished up to them, so they can have input in this debate from the start, through the middle as well as at the end.

Speaker: Ms CRAWFORD
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Forde-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development) (2.18 p.m.)-I start with the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating): ... we are all Australians. We share a continent. We share a past, a present and a future. And our Head of State should be one of us. We have heard much in this discussion about a republic, and it seems that some people feel the very fabric of Australian society is being challenged. Let me say to you that surely the issue of an Australian head of state does go to the heart of the Australian government. It that is surely an issue about equality. We need to look at the role of the constitutional monarchy and ask ourselves: who is a monarch? Where do monarchs come from? What gives them authority to rule? What gives them authority to rule is an accident of birth. I think most of us now would recognise that there are values and attitudes within the British monarchy that most of us as Australians would not wish to emulate, nor would we wish to espouse. When we look to our own nation as an Australian we see the kinds of things that make us Australian. At the heart of it is the issue of equality. At the heart of it is the right-more importantly, the obligation-of all Australian citizens to exercise their democratic right to vote. There is no question of a notion of birth, of where one comes from or of who one is. It simply states that as Australians, as citizens of this nation, we have equality before the law and in the role of this government. It is interesting to hear members of the opposition talk about the notion of stability which comes from a constitutional monarchy. I suggest to members of the opposition that one of the great things that leads to stability within the Australian democratic process is the fact that we all participate, that there is a role for each and every one of us. Contrary to very many other industrialised nations in which small groups of people who happen to be better educated, happen to have more money or happen to be able to buy votes are the people who rule, all Australians vote and we in this parliament represent our electors. In fact, once that election has taken place, we then represent all of those people who reside within that area. I say to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile), who was talking about doses of democracy, that he should run his own discussions on the constitutional monarchy, that he should represent the kinds of views he believes are abroad in his electorate. I suggest that he will find more than half the people with whom he mixes are enamoured of the idea of an Australian head of state and an Australian republic. We have also heard comments by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) on this notion of a people's convention. The coalition is the same lot of people who say, 'Get government off our backs' and 'Don't have government interfere.' Suddenly the role of a people's convention, to which it appoints 50 per cent of the people, is now some sacred cow. It is an extraordinary claim that a people's convention to which it appoints half the delegates will be the forum for open and free discussion. What a lot of nonsense. If we are talking realistically about the notion of a head of state being elected by two-thirds of both houses of this parliament, we can say almost categorically that that person will not be from the field of politics. If, however, we are to have a universally elected head of state, we can absolutely and categorically expect that that person will be either party political or extraordinarily rich. We will be looking at someone who has to gamer the votes of 8,000, 9,000 or 10,000 Australians and who needs the wherewithal and the financial capital to do that. If that person is not a member of one of the two major political parties, which have the structures within our community to do that, that person will have to be a media owner or some other person who is extremely rich. We have seen what has happened in places like Italy where this universally elected president has, by definition, to be somebody who is extraordinarily rich. Look at the American President. He is someone who needs to be extraordinarily rich or have rich and powerful friends. The election by two-thirds of the House of Representatives and the Senate means that the president will not be a member of either of the major political parties. This person will be chosen in a bipartisan manner. The potential president will also be somebody who is looked upon in the light of the checks and balances which operate within this community and within this parliamentary process. It will also be somebody who then gets his or her that power from the elected members of the parliament. The Australian citizens as a whole, who elect all of us here, then have their representation and can move the issue along. This notion of a people's convention is particularly extraordinary. Firstly I draw people back to the 1890s conventions which were proponents of change. They were concerned with only one question: how to create, from separate Australian colonies, a Commonwealth of Australia. More than half of the Australian population were non-participatory in that early people's convention. Most people will know that no female had any role in any of those conventions. Indeed, school children upstairs in the gallery may be interested to know that women were required to sit up there and watch the proceedings while the men decided what the Commonwealth of Australia was to be about. I am not suggesting that a people's convention as proposed by the Leader of the Opposition would exclude women, but I do know that he is appointing half the delegates. In my summation, that means, 'I have control of the numbers.' I find it quite extraordinary to dress this people's convention up as something which is open and free to all people if 'I am appointing half the people'. To me, a convention is no sacred cow. I see the 1890s convention as having brought about the Commonwealth of Australia but having excluded me and all those other women who go to make up the other half of the Australian population. I look at the 1973-85 conventions in Australia and I see that none of them were able to come to any conclusion at all. All of us here know the jokes about committees. I believe that the proposal for a people's convention on this issue represents the attitude: if you cannot come to a decision, you have a committee. Indeed, that is precisely the path which the Leader of the Opposition is taking. He cannot I,"·.lke a decision. He does not want an Australian to be head of state. He does not want Australians to determine who they are and where they are in the 21st century. What an extraordinary state we have got ourselves into: we have a monarch in Britain making decisions about us when, in fact, in many aspects of our lives we no longer have very close ties with Britain. If an Australian were to be head of state in an Australian republic, it would not deny the fact that very many people in Australia trace their roots back to Britain-England, Scotland and Wales. Some of us trace our roots back to Ireland. Now, many Australians trace their roots back to other places which are much closer to home-the Philippines, Cambodia, Vietnam, parts of eastern Europe, Romania, and so on. All those people claim Australia as their own and look to Australia and the Australian government to provide them with their own head of state in a system which gives them a say. Many people who have come to Australia's shores are being provided, through their taking up of Australian citizenship, with the right to vote for the first time in their lifetime. That is important; it is at the heart representative government. We are here representing people and offering leadership. We often hear tell of the role of the Prime Minister-about the need to lead our people, the need to offer direction. The Prime Minister of Australia is talking of an Australian head of state in order for all Australians to share a future together. But now, somehow, that is not about leadership but about telling people what to do. How far from the truth this is. Republicanism and an Australian head of state are simply saying to the world, 'We are Australian, we rule ourselves, we make our own decisions.' Quite simply, in a society which espouses equality and diversity, how much more correct is it for us to have an Australian head of state? The kinds of spurious arguments we have heard on the constitutional monarchy pale into insignificance when we look at the nature of the British monarchy and when we look at the kinds of checks and balances which operate within this parliament and within this parliamentary system to ensure that there is stability and representative government. I say to those opposite: if we are to take and if you are to take representative government seriously, then it is up to each and every one of us to represent quite clearly the views of the 70,000 or so people who are in our electorates-not our personal views on this matter, but the views across the spectrum of what is happening. As I move about my electorate, I find that the majority of people are in favour of a republic and an Australian head of state. Some people are in favour of a republic but not a change in the flag. Some people are confused about the notion of a republic and some other symbols which go with that. Some people stand for the monarchy, although the number is very small and diminishing; by and large they tend to be somewhat more elderly. Young Australians and the young Australian population with whom I mix and meet have a very clear view about who they are, about the kind of government they want and about where they are going in the 21st century. They are joyful about the Sydney Olympics. They are joyous in the notion of being part of a great industrial democracy. They are joyous of in being part of a country in which representative government gives them a whole range of opportunities, and checks and balances. They are joyful in the notion that at last there are people who will stand up and say, 'Being an Australian is something of which to be proud.' This is unlike what happened in the 1950s and 1960s when people cringed over to Britain to seek their education, to seek their artistic talents, to seek publication for their works or whatever else. No, the height of joy is here in Australia in a dynamic community and in a healthy artistic society-a society which people can be proud of and in which opportunity is very much part of the role. At the heart of all of this is the notion of who we are, where we are going and who we represent. I know that all Australians agree that in future our head of state should be one of us, with the checks and balances that being elected by two-thirds of the House of Representatives and the Senate will bring to the role of an Australian president in an Australian republic in the year 2001.

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: Tangney) (2.32 p.m.)Listening to the member for Forde (Ms Crawford), one can see that the republican debate has a long way to go. There will be plenty of time to debate the serious and important constitutional issues involved in the proposals for a repUblic. In my short contribution at this stage I do not want to delve too deeply into that, but I do want to ask a few questions about the methods and motives of the government in pursuit of its republic, particularly about the actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). To change the constitution it is necessary to go through all the formalities under section 128 of the constitution. This means that there must be a referendum proposal passed by a majority of this House and of the Senate, and that it must be put to the electors. It will only be passed if it is approved by a majority of electors in a majority of states and by an overall majority of electors voting. Since Federation, some 42 proposals have been put to referenda, but only eight of those 42 have passed. None of the eight has involved major constitutional change. In fact all the larger proposals for change have failed. No proposal which has been seen by the smaller states as a threat to them has been approved in a referendum. Very few referendum proposals involving an increase in Commonwealth power have been approved by the people. When we look at what is involved in a referendum proposal for Australia to become a republic, the changes involved to the Australian constitution are massive, even on a proposal that seeks to effect least change. In addition, it must be borne in mind that the Crown is also the symbol of each of the states. Each state has a constitution and, in order to change those constitutions, whatever is required under the respective state constitutions must also be gone through. In effect, in seeking for Australia to become a true republic, you are asking for seven sets of changes-all of them major-to be effected simultaneously. It would be very easy for such proposals to be defeated if there is any significant sector of the community which does not support it. There has been no referendum proposal passed since 1977. The most recent attempt, in 1988, failed because the proposals did not have bipartisan support. It is highly unlikely that any proposal put to a referendum would pass if it did not have the support of the major parties. It is highly unlikely that it would pass if it did not have the support of all of the states and, in particular, if it is seen as a threat to the smaller states. In the light of that, one might wonder why the proponents of an Australian republic do not seek to make the issue a bipartisall one, because it is only if it becomes bipartisan that it will be approved. The Australian Labor Party has had the subject of an Australian republic as part of its platform since 1981. So far as I am aware, absolutely nothing was done between 1981 and 1992, except in 1987 when the platform was amended to set a target date of 200 1. The matter seems first to have been raised by the Labor Party in the public arena during the 1992-93 election. It was raised in a very odd situation--obviously, a partisan situation where the parties were contesting an election. The Prime Minister came up with the extraordinary proposition that it would be good for the economy if Australia were to become a republic. I fail to see any relationship between the nature of the constitutional arrangement at the pinnacle of our government and economic conditions. Subsequent to that election, there commenced what was referred to-erroneously, in my belief-as the republican debate. It was somewhat pointless because it seemed to raise the question: do you want Australia to become a republic? If not, why not? It did not descend to the question: if yes, what sort of republic do you want? That debate went on, promoted by journalists, for some considerable time until April 1993 when the Prime Minister decided to appoint a Republic Advisory Committee. . The Republic Advisory Committee might have promoted a bipartisan approach had the question of the appointment of the committee been approached by the Prime Minister in a bipartisan way, but it was not. He pointedly appointed a former Liberal Premier who was a pro-republican to the committee, invited the then Leader of the Opposition to nominate one person to a lO-person. committee and required the states, each of which has a different and significant interest, to appoint one representing larger states and one representing smaller states. The result was that there was a committee which was seen right from the outset as being the subject of a partisan appointment process. The Prime Minister seems to have thought it was also a relatively simple question to determine how to become a republic because he gave the committee a very short time frame within which to report. In fact, it could not report within that time frame and got a one-month extension. The government received the report in October 1993. The government then said, 'Well, we won't be announcing what we are proposing immediately. We will do that early in 1994.' However,the Australian public waited in vain for the whole of 1994 for a government response. In October 1994, the coalition proposed that there be a people's constitutional convention convened in 1997. That would have been to consider, among other things, whether there should be a republic, and, if so, what form that should take. The response of the Prime Minister to that was hardly bipartisan. He was asked a dorothy dixer in question time in this House in November last year, to which he answered: Let me say this to the Leader of the Opposition: the government will be holding no dialogue with the coalition until it declares a belief in the for an Australian head of state-none whatsoever. If you do not accept the need for an Australian head of state, there will be no constitutional convention and no contribution and attendance at it by us. There the Prime Minister is foreshadowing what he sees as the simple question for the resolution of the republican question: do you want an Australian head of state? The republican debate will not, in my view, be advanced while arrogant, censorious comments of that sort emanate from the government and generate a partisan approach. The government must not have found it very easy to develop a response to the Republic Advisory Committee report, because nothing emanated from the government until 7 June. So it took all of 18 months and heading towards the better part of two years for a response from the government. The timing of that really raises another question. The response was given at a time when there was frequent and loud talk of the prospect of an election. The response by the government, to promote a head of state elected by the houses of parliament jointly, is no doubt a valid proposal worthy of consideration by the Australian public in the course of the republican debate that will no doubt continue for some time. But there are partisan aspects to the proposal. First, the proposal does not deal with the situation of the states. It would be ludicrous to contemplate an Australian republic without the states being involved in the transformation from a monarchy to a republic. Second, in the context of public opinion, the proposal adopted runs strongly counter to the public's substantial majority view that the head of state should be elected by the people. Third-and I have already mentioned thisthe response to the Republic Advisory Committee was not quick and it was not done in the course of 1994. The response from the government was not put until as late as this month in the context of a possible early election. In the course of announcing the government's proposals, the Prime Minister also said that what we have is a simple question. He need asserts that the only question involved in the republican debate is: do we want an Australian head of state? He camouflages the real issue, because in order to get a true Australian head of state-the Governor General effectively being an Australian head of state-we have to ask how we get one. It is not, therefore, simply a question of: do you want an Australian head of state? It is: do you want an Australian head of state elected by the Australian people? Do you want an Australian head of state elected by the parliament? Do you want one appointed by the Prime Minister? Do you want one who is elected by the state governors, or is one of the state governors appointed to serve for a limited time, as has been seriously suggested? Mr Bevis-This is obfuscation and you know it, Daryl.

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: No, it is not. It seems to me to be highlighting the fact that this proposal is being put in an election context. The Prime Minister is reported by people in the press gallery as having said that he can win an election on the republic issue. If that is his have to do. attitude, I am very disappointed, because the issue is far too important to be treated like that. But so many signs are pointing to that being the way the Prime Minister in particular is approaching it. In the few minutes I have left to speak I will contrast the coalition approach. As foreshadowed in October last year by the member for Mayo (Mr Downer) when he was the Leader of the Opposition, the coalition will, on being elected to government, convene in 1997 a people's constitutional convention. Half the delegates will be elected; half will be appointed. They will be elected on state and territory bases, with parliamentarians disqualified from running for election. The election process will recognise that young people, women and people from non-English-speaking backgrounds are currently underrepresented in decision making processes. Strenuous efforts will be made to encourage them to stand for election. The remaining half of the delegates will be appointed from federal, state and territory parliaments. The Prime Minister, premiers, chief ministers and attorneys-general will be delegates. Federal and state oppositions will also be represented. There will also be representatives from local government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. Ten per cent of those at the convention will be in the age group 18 to 25. If a consensus emerges from the people's convention as to what should be done about a head of state, the coalition has undertaken that that will be promoted by the government at a constitutional referendum. Mr Bevis-What do you think?

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, who is at the table, asks me what I think. I am one of 17 million people. I believe, as the coalition does, that the question ought to be asked of the people, the issue debated at this convention and the consensus that emerges be put to a referendum. We have in contrast the government approach, which is that we as a government have decided what we want to do and we will tell the people that is what they . The coalition also provides for the possibility of there being no real consensus, just as there is in the community at the moment, on a particular form of republic. In that event the coalition would put a series of options to the people for them to vote on. Those options would be put in the form of a plebiscite, not a referendum, and if a consensus emerges from that it would be put to a constitutional referendum. That is a two-stage process. The virtue of the coalition approach is that the people will be consulted. It makes sense in the context of the need for a constitutional referendum, bearing in mind that so few constitutional referenda have been passed by the Australian people. They apparently treat their constitution very seriously, and proposals for change-they have been for only small changes-have been treated very seriously to the extent that most of them have failed. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr ADAMS
Title: MINISTERIAL STATEMENTS
text: I believe it is about time Australia had its own head of state. We are approaching the 21st century and our centenary of nationhood, and it is about time we made our own way in our region and in the world. At a time when we are attempting to become closer to our Asian neighbours through trade and culture, they are amazed that we still have a sovereign head of state who lives 10,000 kilometres away. Some of these people are pretty amazed that, when the Queen of England visits Malaysia, for example, she is usually assisting or leading a delegation of English trade people who are working on trade balance for England-certainly not on trade balance for Australia. It is time we showed our own colours and our own way as a nation. The Queen of England has been with us for a long time, and it is now time we are able to elect our own Australian head of state. That is what this debate is really about: Australians having their own as the head of their nation. The Queen of England in reality now only acts in her role as Queen of Australia when she is in Australia. That is not very often these days. Most of the time in touring other countries she is the Queen of the United Kingdom. When talking about those interests she is talking about the interests of England and the trade of England and the economies of the United Kingdom. That is fine. That is the way it should be for her as the head of England, but it should not be that way for the head of Australia. When we have a head visiting another part of the world that head our country should be promoting this country, Australia. When our head of state visits those countries, it should be an Australian. We may ask why we have hung onto these remnants of the past for so long. There are a lot of reasons. Our history, our early European population, was British based. The economy was geared to the European market until relatively recently and certainly until postwar in Australia. Maybe it was tied too close, maybe we should have broken the ties earlier. Our population is English speaking, with an accent somewhat equivalent to cockney English. Therefore we were seen as an easy place for English migrants to settle. We do have some strong ties, and some of us have strong memories. My wife is English born, so my mother-in-law is English-a great woman. She came to live in Australia in 1983, was naturalised in 1984 and at 78 now firmly believes that Australia should have its own head of state, should be able to state its own case with its own head and should be proud of the fact that it has a head of state born and bred in Australia. As Australia's population has grown through its migrants, especially its postwar migrants, through those changes Australia has come away from the European economy. Many more nationalities have settled in Australia and we have changed from our early roots. Those changes in trade were very easy to see in Australia in the 1950s and 1960s when England went into the Common Market and basically destroyed the Tasmanian apple industry. It was the right thing for England to do but it certainly did not do anything for Australia's trade and it certainly did not do anything for a major industry in Tasmania. In England now the Prime Minister is having a few difficulties in convincing his more conservative colleagues in his own party that England should be going into the European Union in a fully fledged way, as all the other nations are. That is probably right for England and that is probably where it should be in its trading bloc, endeavouring to gain the best out of that. But Australia's future is in the Asian region, the Pacific rim. That touches everything from South America to the of Americas, North America and Canada right through Japan, right down to China, right around Asia and even across to South Africa and the Indian rim. We have great trade opportunities emerging in those areas in the future. To make the most of them we need to have someone who can go there as the head of Australia, someone who is an Australian. I believe we will be seen to be a country that has finally reached its full maturity. Our early relationship with Britain, our heritage and our affection for that country do not need to change. We have grown up with them. I personally have many English friends who will not change a bit when Australia becomes a republic. They will still be my friends. I will still enjoy their company and be proud to know them. The head of state in Australia should embody and represent Australian values, traditions, experiences and aspirations for the future. We should incorporate the dreams and aspirations that the indigenous people of Australia have for our nation. I would like to see us becoming one Australia, but it will rely on a decision of the Aboriginal people-will they help us develop our nationhood in a way that is acceptable to their people? That is something that I do not think could ever happen under a head of state who was born somewhere outside Australia. Every Australian should be able to aspire to be the head of state, chosen because of a particular achievement or outstanding service. There is no reason why we should not look forward to having an Aboriginal as the head of state some time in the future. Many Aboriginals have contributed to building our great nation, and many more will do the same. Under the current constitution, the head of state is the Queen. Most of her responsibilities are carried out by the Governor General. The only power she retains is the appointment of the. Governor General which, by convention, she does on the advice of the Prime Minister of the day. The historical aspect of that in 1933 the Governor General ceased to be the representative of the British government in Australia and became solely the representative of the Queen. In the same decade, it was accepted that the British monarch would act on the advice of the Australian government, not the British government. Also Australia assumed responsibility for its own external affairs-its foreign affairs as we call it today. In 1980 all remaining rights of appeal to the Privy Council in London ceased. Australian courts became the ultimate arbitrator of Australian law. There has been a move towards our becoming a republic over the years, and we have divested ourselves of a connection to British law, its courts and its appeal system. In the Australia Act, the UK relinquished the last vestiges of power, making only Australian law apply to Australia-a small but. important step and the last in a process which began about 100 years ago. If we take the minimalist approach, the only thing that we will need to change is the position of the Governor General and how he or she is appointed. All the constitutional principles and practices will remain the same. The role of the House of Representatives and the Senate will be the same, and we will still have a federation of states. The functions of the head of state will be that of the Governor General---except in the most external circumstances-although we will still have this ongoing debate about the reserve powers and that aspect of control. I know that the polls have shown that within our country people would like to vote on the head of state. I think as we emerge from this debate-although I am sure there will still be a lot of debate before there is a referendum-people may come to realise that changing the way we electthe head of state from a two-thirds majority of both houses of parliament would require a major change to the power structure that we presently have in this country. Hence, we would have to rewrite and change the power of the Senate. We would have to look at the power of the Prime Minister, the Executive Council and the executive government. A major change would have to take place, and that process would is that involve enormous changes to the power structure. If we had a popularly elected head of state, we would need to change the power structures that we presently know in our country· today. An example could be that people would be able to make representations to the president-whether or not he is popularly elected-to override government decisions. If a president tried to pursue an issue like that, it could bring us into a constitutional crisis.

text: We are seeing again the value of an agreed basis of income determination between the work force and the government of the day. Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: After eight accords over 12 years-each accord covers a period of about 1Y2 to two years-with Accord Mark VIII we can see for the first time the development of a permanent perpetual wages system whereby, having used the accords to move away from the centralised wage fixing structure, we are now moving to a decentralised wage fixing structure. In that decentralised wage fixing structure, enterprise bargaining is growing apace throughout the community. Those working Australians who cannot avail themselves of an enterprise bargain will be protected by the safety net being proposed by the government. In other words, we have had accords which dealt with award restructuring and flexibility within awards and we have had accords which were predicated on the amalgamation of major unions under a system of award restructuring. That now largely having been accomplished, we can focus on a permanent wages system with low inflation. I imagine that it is a matter of some substantial comfort to the community that the AeTU, on behalf of the work force, said that, for the period of this Accord, the wages system will be based on an underlying inflation rate on average of two to three per cent over the cycle. I ran into an employer's representative yesterday and he said to me, 'I grew up with automatic wage indexation. For my whole working life there has been automatic wage indexation.' To see an underlying rate of inflation of two to three per cent-in other words, running the wages system, including the enterprise bargaining stream to produce two to three per cent inflation-is a quite remarkable and revolutionary change. It means that we can run the Australian economy faster than we would otherwise be able to were we relying simply on interest rates to curtail inflation. In those countries where we have seen only a reliance on fiscal and monetary policy we have generally seen a much slower rate of employment growth and economic growth than in Australia. Having the three instruments of policy-fiscal, monetary and wages policy-with some weight on each rather than a heavy preponderant weight on anyone really means that we can run the economy much faster and more safely in terms of inflation and, at the same time, spread the benefits. I told the House last week that since 1983 we have had an increase in household disposable income of 40 per cent or, in per capita terms, an increase of over 19Y2 per cent. There have been over two million jobs created. That is a fairly remarkable record. We have a system which takes account of the core need for competitiveness. We hear a lot from the opposition about the current account deficit. It is now the only thing that those opposite harp on. Mr Costello-You are going to hear more too.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: There can be no doubt that Accord Mark VIII is a framework for another four years of low inflation, high growth and high productivity for the Australian economy. It certainly continues our tradition of industrial harmony-the one we are so pleased and proud to boast about. And what better day to show it off than the day the ABS statistics have been released, showing that for last year, 1994, the lowest number of industrial disputes in any year since 1940-the lowest number of industrial disputes for 55 years. What a sensational performance! Just have a look at what we inherited in 1983 and compare it with what we have today as a result of the Accord. Here we have the graph. Here we have Everest. Who was presiding over the economy then? Who was right up there, scaling the dizzy heights? The Leader of the Opposition, the then Treasurer of Australia. His former Prime Minister has left the chamber, I notice. Where are we today? Right down here, with the lowest level since 1940. These reductions have been even more dramatic as a result of the conjunction of the Accord process and the 1993 Industrial Relations Reform Act. It was only a few days ago that the publication Workforce published an article dealing with this question of industrial disputes, days lost and protected bargaining. What it had to say is very revealing. Workforce said: The introduction of a legal right to strike has failed to produce an upsurge in industrial action, confounding employers' predictions that the new laws would create industrial turmoil. In fact, in the 12 months following the introduction of the new federal laws allowing unions to stage protected industrial action, the number of working days lost due to industrial action declined by more than 46 per cent. It went down in that first year by more than 46 per cent! All of this is great news for Australian business. It is great news for Australia's exports. It is great news for Australia's economy. Of course, it is all thanks to the Accord and it is all thanks to those industrial reforms that this government has driven home. There is no doubt that, under Labor, that exceptional performance will continue. Accord Mark VIII, after all, guarantees it. All working people in Australia have their standards fundamentally guaranteed through the four safety net adjustments provided under Accord Mark VIII, the $8 increase from Accord Mark VII and the three annual adjustments-$9 to $12 for each of the following three years, 1997 through to 1999. In the case of low paid workers, it is a bigger increaseAustralia recorded from $11 to $14. Consistent with the budget, there is a better retirement income guaranteed under the Accord for all workers through the introduction of employee superannuation contributions, contributions which will be met, dollar for dollar, by this government. We have improved this area. We have driven home the reforms. We have provided additional assistance for families. We have a comprehensive package we can truly be proud of. That is in stark contrast to the promise of what members of the opposition have in store if ever they are elected to government in this country. There is no comprehensive award safety net under them whatsoever. There is an absence of a no disadvantage test against which enterprise bargains can be measured. There are no safety net increases. There is a single miserable hourly rate of pay. How do we know this when there has been no release of the federal policy? It is worth noting that yesterday the Leader of the Opposition went to Queensland and released the Queensland state opposition's IRpolicy. It provided all of these things-each and every one of them. The approach of the opposition to industrial relations.is no different now from what it was in 1993. It destroys all workers' protections. It would return us to the industrial turmoil, shown here so graphically , of the early 1980s. Indonesia: Diplomatic Representation

Speaker: Mr MACK
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, some two years ago, in reflecting the concern of a substantial section of the Australian community, I indicated to the House that, regrettably, you were coming dangerously close to becoming the Neville Chamberlain of South-East Asia in respect of our relations with Indonesia. Does not the agreement of the government to the appointment of Lieutenant General Mantiri as Indonesian Ambassador to Australia, whose view is that the Dili massacre was 'a quite proper response', reinforce the view that the government is following a policy of appeasement to a military dictatorship? Given the fact that this appointment flies in the face of Australian public opinion since 1975, why have you allowed this ambassadorial appointment to humiliate this country in the eyes of the world and to hold up to ridicule any human rights statements this country may make in world forums?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am at a loss to understand the reference to Chamberlain. Does the honourable gentleman think that Indonesia is about to declare war on Australia? Does he think we have a relationship of that character?  Mr Smyth-You want peace at any price.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Order! The member for Sturt and the member for Canberra.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: This is our nearest largest neighbour of just on 200 million people. It is a country whose fortunes are inextricably linked to Australia's, and ours to theirs. a relationship which is absolutely central to Australian foreign policy. For that relationship to be operated only on the basis of a for-lgn policy relationship, or one that takes .the opportunity of simply expressing exclusively an Australian view or a sectional Australian view as the basis for the operation of tl1at policy, would be doing the wrong thing by Australians. It is more the pity that, for a very long period of time, so much of the AustraliaIndonesia relationship has centred around Timor; it has because of what has happened there. Australia has made clear that it has condemned the denial of liberties and the denial of human rights in that province and has sought a better order in that province. But it wants to conduct that conversation about East Timor in the context of a broader conversation with Indonesia about the totality of the relationship and our relative importance to one another. That is now what has happened. We now have a broad relationship with Indonesia that sits on many foundations, whereas in the past it was exclusively a foreign policy relationship where, were that to crumble, the whole relationship would have crumbled. I can only repeat what I said earlier: we have made our views very clear about Timor. We are constantly saying to the Indonesian government that there needs to be an approach to the development of Timor to give the people of that province opportunities and to give them, in their own view, a role in the way in which their province and their society functionMr Cleary-Are you going to write a letter to the ambassador to tell him that he is wrong? Mr .SPEAKER-Order! The member for Wills!

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: And, as a consequence, try to see that this does not remain the issue for the East Timorese people or the issue in this relationship. I think we can see that there has been a substantial change in the way in which Indonesia accepts the Australian view, deals with It is the Australian view. One should remember also the changes which are taking place in Indonesia. About eight years ago 65 per cent of Indonesians lived below the poverty line; that is now 15 per cent. There has been a substantial distribution of the wealth in Indonesia. 'One can see the changes taking place there perpetually. Asa consequence, there is a lot of improvement in living standards and, with it, the general human condition in that country. They are advances which I think Australia should encourage and applaud. So, while we will always take the view that wherever liberties are constrained or human rights violated we will forcibly put our view'::""":which we have done and will continue to do with Indonesia-that we do' want to maintain a broad relationship with that country. I do not see the character of General Mantiri's appointment being such as to rupture that relationship. In saying that, I say that in the broad interests of the Australian people. Mr Cleary-What about the racial vilification bill?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr SAWFORD
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister able to advise the House of the principles which have underpinned government policy formulation since 1983? Is the Prime Minister able to assure the Australian people that his government will continue to involve the Australian people in all aspects of policy development and implementation?

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Virtually from day one the government changed the model of governance in Australia by a process of consultation. This began with the Economic Summit in 1983, the prices and incomes accord, and consultation with employer groups and the peak union bodies under the Accord to curtail prices and to see wages come back to be within affordable levels. That process has continued right down the years, and Accord Mark VIII is a further development of that process of consultation. You can see it again more recently in the consultations that the government had with the peak farm bodies last year and iIi the consultations we are still having in relation· to such questions as land management and soil and water conservation. By and large, the government has believed that, on a basis of talking and listening to interest groups, one can secure policy solutions which advance the country more rapidly and more fully. As a consequence, we advance ourselves in a way that we might not otherwise. In the last two months, the government has delivered a number of profound reforms. In fact, I doubt whether any government has been quite so productive in such a short period of time, and the process of consultation that we have had has encouraged it. Let me remind the House that the budget delivered, amongst other things, a budget surplus, a new maternity allowance and a revolution in national savings via 15 per cent being put away for Australians in award superannuation. Since the budget we have seen the Justice Statement; we have seen the completion, at last, of our oldest national goal-a standard gauge rail link linking the mainland capitals via Melbourne-we have seen the beginning of a national civics education program; we have seen the government's proposal for an Australian republic with an Australian as our head of state; and we have seen Accord Mark VIII which was delivered last week

Speaker: Mr OCONNOR
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Is the Treasurer aware of proposals to loosen fiscal policy? Treasurer, can you tell the House where these proposals have come from and what their implications are?

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am aware of a continuing stream of proposals to loosen fiscal policy which keep coming from the opposition. We saw in the reply to the budget from the Leader of the Opposition that the opposition was determined to oppose various tax measures, which would have meant a loosening of fiscal policy to the tune of $1 Y2 billion this year and $2Y2 billion the subsequent year. Since then the opposition has proposed one expenditure measure, that is, in relation to non-work related child care. Now we see another, in relation to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The opposition is taking the view that various measures proposed by the government to stop the rapid growth of one of the fastest growing expenditure items in our whole array of outlays should be opposed. The opposition has taken the view that in regard to our attempts to clarify the eligibility criteria and to prevent various claims which have been made on the basis of an application of the law which we never intended, such as, for instance, to diesel fuel used in maintaining council parks and gardens or in quarrying activity, there should be no retrospective application of that legislation to prevent claims being made on a basis which the government never intended them to be made. That is, the opposition wants the companies which are making these claims to be able to get money out of the government on the basis of an application of the law which was never intended by the legislature. The money involved in this is substantial. It is about $160 million, if all the court decisions were to go against the government. That is the amount of money at risk and that is the addition to outlays which would come from the opposition being successful in its attempts to prevent the government from restricting outlays in this area. It does not stop there. The opposition is also trying to prevent us from eliminating quarrying prospectively as an area which would not qualify for the diesel fuel rebate. That would cost an extra $20 million per annum approximately. So what we are looking at here is, across the forward estimates, something in the order of $240 million of additional outlays-that is, $160 million for the various claims and an annual $20 million for the inclusion of quarrying. It should also be noted that of the $160 million of claims, $90 million would go to three companies. Those three companies, of course, have charged their customers in the past for the full amount of their costs, including the diesel cost without the rebate. Do you think those companies are going to hand back the $90 million to their customers? If you do, you have another think coming. If you really believe that,you are totally naive. This will just be $90 million straight into the pockets of three companies, to their benefit and to the benefit of their shareholders. What we have had in this budget debate so faris opposition members opposing outlays in the order of $400 million, and thereby trying to increase outlays to that extent. That is just on two measures-the only two outlays measures that have so far come before the parliament. At the same time, we have this ranting from opposition members about the need to tighten fiscal policy. Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The cross-media ownership rules passed by this parliament are designed to encourage diversity of ownership in the media. The changes which the government announced on Tuesday night will strengthen and buttress the cross-media ownership rules, and that is something which we believe will limit cross-media holdings, whether it be print, television or radio. These changes are a considered response to the report to the government from the Australian Broadcasting Authority. Despite claims by the Leader of the Opposition, they are not directed at any individual because the 15 per cent cap applies just as much to News Limited's investment in Channel 7 as it does to Channel 9' s investment in Fairfax. What it does is provide more certainty for the industry because it provides, for the first time, a tightening of the net for the definition of 'quasi equity' and puts the cap at 15 per cent and also maintains that control test for less than 15 per cent. For all of these reasons, the government believes that these changes are the right policy response to the ABA's report. That can be contrasted with comments that have been made in the last 48 hours by certain members of the opposition. Senator Alston, the opposition's official spokesman for communications, was asked on Tuesday night whether a coalition government would reverse these changes. He said, 'Well, there's not much here to reverse.' Yet on Wednesday morning the Leader of the Opposition said,  He said, 'It's just a KO Kerry exercise.' But the previous night, according to AAP, Senator Alston said our proposals were expanding the types of shares covered by the act and that was overdue. But on Wednesday morning the Leader of the Opposition said that this was Packer specific and prejudiced, biased legislation. But on Tuesday night Senator Alston said, 'It's a step in the right direction.' On Tuesday night what was long overdue and was, according to Senator Alston, a step in the right direction, was, by Wednesday morning, according to the member for Bennelong, prejudiced, biased legislation and  ing to feel a bit sorry for Senator Alston. Is it any wonder he gets tangled up when the opposition, after 12 years, still does not have a media policy? So is it any wonder that Senator Alston is getting confused? The only firm statement we have on crossmedia owership from the opposition is the Leader of the Opposition's commitment to abolish the cross-media ownership rules. He thinks we should only rely on the Trade Practices Act-the Trade Practices Act that he weakened and the member for Holt had to strengthen. And when the member for Holt introduced the changes to strengthen it the Deputy Leader of the Opposition opposed the changes. So the Leader of the Opposition says that we should only rely on the Trade Practices Act, even after the chairman of the Trade Practices Commission says that means there are no limits on cross-media ownership.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I will give you my answer now. In the course of the afternoon whilst question time was going on I did give some thought to it and I find that the member for Flinders generally has raised a valid point. I will endeavour to act accordingly. Question Time

Speaker: Mr WILLIAMS
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: My question is on the exact same point as that raised by the member for Flinders. If the precedent applied today to the question of the member for Throsby, which was outside standing orders, is applied, then I or any coalition questioner who asks a question of a minister which is outside his responsibility is entitled to ask a replacement question.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
