Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Title: COMMITEES
text: On behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, I present the report entitled The workforce of future, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr BARRY JONES
Title: COMMITEES
text: by leave-The committee's inquiry into the work force of the future has reviewed demographic and labour market trends to draw attention to the future challenges and possibilities for Australia. Challenges and possibilities have been forced upon us by changes in demography, technology and the development of a global market, a market without frontiers. It will be futile for governments to fight rearguard actions against change, but there can be substantial benefits in seeking to understand the directions where already apparent trends are leading. The committee's report on the work force of the future examines demographic, economic and labour market developments and makes recommendations for government to assist workers and employers to adapt to structural and social change. The past 21 years have been marked by striking changes in the composition of the Australian labour market. For reasons that are not entirely clear, the year 1974 stands out in international labour force statistics as marking a sudden end to what has been called 'the golden age of full employment' which ran for 30 years from the end of World War II. A variety of explanations have been put forward including the impact of the oil shock of 1973; general use of the contraceptive pill, which changed the whole pattern of fertility and led to increased female labour force participation; a loss of confidence in government intervention, Keynesian style, in the economy, leading to a revival of neoclassical economic theory and practice; and a clear indication of the postindustrial phenomenon with sharp declines in manufacturing employment, now down to 14 per cent, and demand for manual labour. Before 1974 Australia's unemployment rate was one of the world's lowest, far lower than that of the United States or Britain. Since 1974 it has generally been higher than that of the US, and sometimes higher than that of Britain. However, our wage levels have maintained value better than in the US. The committee emphasises that the composition of the 1995 labour force is radically different from that of 1974. Since 1974 female participation in the labour force has increased from 41 to 51 per cent. The postwar Beveridge-Chifley concept of full employment being defined as 'one adult breadwinner per family' has been overtaken by events. Another important development has been the growth of part-time work. In 1973 only 12 per cent of workers were employed part time. By 1993 this had doubled to 24 per cent. A high proportion of part-time jobs are performed by young people between 15 and +4 years of age and by married women. The number of jobs created in Australia between 1973 and 1993 was 1.8 million, or a growth of 32 per cent. However, over a million of those jobs were part time, which was an increase of 164 per cent in part-time employment. Largely due to these factors, Australia, in common with most OECD nations, is now experiencing the unprecedented phenomenon of high employment and high unemployment simultaneously. It sounds like a contradiction in terms. All it means is that many of those, mostly males, who were traditionally in work are now out of it and unlikely to return while those, mostly women, who were traditionally not in work are now in it. Apart from the high employment-high unemployment paradox, the age and gender composition of the labour force has changed dramatically. So has the length of working life, at a time of increasing life expectancy in Australia and most comparable economies. The 35-year working lifetime is likely to become the norm, replacing the 50-year model. Many more jobs have been created but, at the same time, labour force participation rates have never been greater. At 63.7 per cent, they have stayed close to their historic highest levels since 1974. While the composition of the labour force has changed, a revolution in the work force has also occurred. Far more people work with telephones and computers than with traditional tools. Technical innovations have transformed every area of work from manufactur-. ing processes to transport, warehousing and retailing, transforming the range of tasks performed. The regional impact of employment changes is extremely varied. Along with changes to tools and techniques, there have been far· reaching shifts in the leading employment sectors in Australia. Since 1974, the fastest growing employment sector has been the information related employment sector-including the whole range of media and entertainment, market research, consulting, administrative, management, clerical, education and financial services. This sector is estimated at 42.5 per cent of the labour force. The second fastest growth has been in domestic and quasi-domestic work including 'hospitality' and tourism, essentially paralleland ing work which used to be carried out at home without a wage. These sectors between them now employ the bulk of services employment. Services in total comprise 79 per cent of the labour force. These developments have been lost in the statistics produced by the Department of Employment, Education and Training and by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The committee accordingly recommends that the government request the Australian Bureau of Statistics to review the appropriateness of its existing data collection methodology and to indicate significance of information and domestic or quasi-domestic service employment. The committee took on Peter Drucker's important argument about the decline of hierarchical work, that management structures have been flattened out. He argues that the coming post-industrial society is 'the first in which not everybody does the same work. This is far more than a social change. It is a change in the human condition'. In a knowledge society, having a hundred or a thousand people performing the same task, as was characteristic of agriculture or manufacturing, would be pointless. The committee also drew attention to the formation of dual labour markets. The primary labour market is characterised by high skill levels, comparative security of employment and a full range of award related working conditions. The secondary labour market· may be characterised by insecure work, low skill levels and a deteriorating range of award coverage. There is also increased wage disparity between the primary and the secondary labour markets. The domestic services and tourism and hospitality sectors are where most new jobs are now being created. Some 55 per cent of all work is estimated to be unpaid or informal work, once almost exclusively done by women, now increasingly outsourced. Evidence to the committee indicated that an additional two million potential jobs were waiting to be created by outsourcing services such as food preparation and ddivery, home maintenance and gardening, cleaning, security child minding. Of course, such outsourcing would be dependent on the restoration of the two income family with higher levels of discretionary spending. Australia is now exporting a range of services, including tourism, educational, financial, legal, marketing and management consultancy services. But we still import more services than we export. Other areas where employment growth and wealth generation may be expected to occur include a number of industrial sectors such as construction, mining and value added manufacturing, together with agricultureespecially value added horticultural exportsinformation technology, knowledge related information services, health related services and tourism. The unprecedented growth of the information and quasi-domestic services sectors of the economy has led to the displacement of one group of workers and its replacement by another group. There is now a relatively high demand for skilled and professional workers and a relatively low demand for unskilled workers. Across a wide variety of white-collar occupations, new computer technology enables some workers to attempt more creative or intellectually demanding tasks. There are now fewer opportunities for process related and middle management white-collar workers. During the 1980s, for example, many traditional clerical jobs have been lost in the banking and financial sectors, but now new financial products are creating employment downstream. . There has been high growth in the low skilled part-time hospitality and tourism sectors of the economy. Structural award conditions in these industries have resulted in substantial cost .advantages for the employment of part-time labour. In 1993 nearly 80 per cent of all part-time workers were employed in services. The changes outlined in the committee's report have caused substantial dislocation in the lives of many workers. The challenge for any government is to ease the impact of the process. As we said in paragraph 1.21, recognising that outsourcing will be a major contribution to employment, the committee recommends the government examine measures which may facilitate tendencies to outsource work from the home, government administration and industry, including primary industry. There is general agreement on the part of political parties, employer groups, trade unions and industrial tribunals on the basic objectives of work force change, but not the same degree of consensus on the range of measures needed to improve Australia's penetration of global markets. As we wrote in paragraph 2.31, one of Australia's greatest economic problems, although insufficiently recognised, is the inventory problem. This is the conspicuous lack of an inventory of brand name goods for which there is international recognition and demand, leading to a willingness to pay a premium price. Canada also lacks such an inventory, which is in significant contrast to Sweden, with Volvo, Saab, SKL and L. M. Ericsson; Finland, with Kone and Nokia; the Netherlands, with Philips and Shell; and the Republic of Korea, with Hyundai, Gold Star and Daewoo. All of those countries have such an inventory. I have already pointed to the tendency towards labour force demarcation between high skilled jobs with high pay and low skilled jobs often with low pay. High skilled jobs require an educated work force that is adaptable and flexible and which can acquire new knowledge quickly. Not all workers can possess those qualities. Governments must ensure that those who do not are not marginali sed and are provided with opportunities to participate in the economy in a productive way. Access to information technology for all is essential if Australia is not to be divided into the information rich and the information poor. The committee repeats its 1991 recommendation that the government adopt a national information policy which sets out a series of principles which anticipates the social, economic and cultural implications of the information revolution rather than having decisions made piecemeal, on the run, responding to situations such as the adoption of new technologies or changes in ownership suddenly arising. The committee notes that those countries which have moved to a high-tech knowledge based economy have also been most successful in creating employment. According to EPAC and the Hilmer report, at present Australia's efficiency levels in the business sector are 10 to 15 per cent below the average for OECD countries, and the average Australian enterprise operates at 30 per cent below world best practice. It is recognised that the priority for industry must be to improve competitiveness and productivity in order to succeed. At the same time, Australia must stimulate market demand for its goods and services by building up a high value added inventory. The cover of the report reproduces a famous photograph of Charlie Chaplin on the wheels of a huge machine, wielding a spanner, and is taken from his film Modern Times. As one of the committee members thoughtfully observed, the cover should not be taken as evidence of a weakened commitment to work safety. I take this opportunity to thank members of the committee, especially the deputy chairman, the member for Cook (Mr Dobie), for their contributions to understanding this vital subject. I also thank all those who made written submissions, gave evidence or took part in workshops, and especially the admirable but depleted staff of the committee-Dr Margot Kerley and Ms Helen Collins. We owe them a great debt for their professionalism and dedication.

Speaker: Mr DOBIE
Title: COMMITEES
text: by leave-Perhaps this is the last report that I will help to present to this parliament. It is fitting that it should be a report from the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, which has maintained its independence since Prime Minister Hawke created the committee in June 1990 with the proviso that the chairman would have to be the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). Having presented many reports to this federal parliament, as I have said, it is appropriate that I should be speaking for only a few minutes on this report. Because of the valedictory nature and atmosphere for me after-I might tell the chairman-42Y2 years in the work force, I would like to pay a tribute to the chairman of the committee. This is not just a formality; it is my deeply felt attitude. At all times, since the committee was created five years ago this month, the chairman has sought, and I believe has always obtained, a parliamentary attitude to whatever subject we were studying. This may not mean much to new people in the parliament but, before the present government assumed office, all parliamentary committees decided by themselves what they would report upon. Prime Minister Hawke allowed this committee to be independent, and we have chosen our own references in the last five years. I believe that the quality of our reports reflects this. I believe that, in the next parliament, whoever wins-I will not be here-will come back to the position that parliamentary committees should always report on what they believe is significant, not what has to be referred to them by this chamber, therefore the government, or by a minister in charge of a subject, which we have had in other committees I have served on-with disastrous effects, I must say. I hope there is a change in committee attitudes in the next parliament. No government can survive if it determines what parliamentary committees shall talk about. I am not trying to forecast the result of the next election, but you will understand my hopes in this regard. While I am paying tribute to the chairman, I would like to pay tribute to Dr Margot Kerley, who has at all times shown a professionalism, which I think many other people in the parliament building should follow. It has not always been easy for her because our committee consists of people with changing views and changing attitudes. I commend to the House this committee report, which has this splendid cover that the chairman has referred to. I will not go over the issues he has raised. There are just a few he has not. Recommendation 2.35 states: The Committee acknowledges the increasing importance of service employment to the future economic development of the nation ... The chairman talked about that at great length. I think we have to enhance the training of the work force, as the report says, and the further development of its export potential. Recommendation 5.40 states: The Committee recommends the setting up of a peak body for TAFE, analogous to the Australian Vice Chancellors' Committee ... I commend members of the House to read the whole background to this recommendation. The recommendation that impressed me, though I had nothing to do with the writing of this particular one, is recommendation 6.25, which states: The Committee recommends that the concept of mandatory retirement (with its implications of 'statutory senility'which I do not have

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Moncrieft) (6.20 p.m.)Earlier today, I spoke to a motion moved by the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile). In the course of my speech I detailed the extraordinary difficulty I was having in getting any information at all with respect to a particular government program operating in my electorate. I said that the trail of trying to find out what was happening in my electorate-a perfectly reasonable request for informationended with the office of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), where I had been directed by the department. . When, as I had been told to, I asked a certain person for this information, I was told that person was on three weeks leave and that the minister's office would follow up and let me have the information. That request was made some time prior to 10 o'clock. As at 11 o'clock when I came to the House to speak, no call had been received from the minister's office. I subsequently received a message, taken in my office, at 3 o'clock this afternoon, from a Ms Susan Smith, who I understand works in the office of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). I was informed that my request for information, for details about new work opportunities programs in Moncrieff, had to be put in writing to the minister and then I would get an answer. Put in the context of the speech I gave today, people will see just how extraordinary that request is. There is another subject. I feel a little diffidence about raising but, since this is probably the last adjournment debate before the parliamentary recess, I would like to put the record straight on-a personal matter. I emphasise, for the record, that I am not saying this in a 'heavy' way. I have been aware for some weeks now that there has been a story circulating in my electorate that I have a serious health problem. The story, put simply, is that I have a terminal disease and it is expected that I will resign from parliament in a certain period of time. I want to assure my constituents that that story contains absolutely no truth whatsoever. I treated it as a joke for some time. However, I was rather disturbed today to hear the story from someone who lives in Victoria and to discover that this story has apparently spread well past my electorate. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) laughs, and that is certainly my reaction too. The only comment I make is that, when I told my husband, he did not laugh. He was very angry indeed, because one could ascribe some quite evil motives to a story like that. When I was told the story and I laughed, I said, 'They are going to be disappointed when· I don't die, aren't they?' That was my reaction to it. I say that just to make the point that I am not being heavy about this. However, when I realised the story had a widespread currency, I thought it was time to reassure my constituents that I am in excellent health. Mr Richard Evans-Full voice.

Speaker: Mrs SULLIVAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Full voice, as has been commented by the member for Cowan. I have never been in better health and, contrary to this rumour, I am not 'returning to hospital' this recess. I have not been to hospital, so cannot return. I look forward to many years representing the very worthy residents of Moncrieff-in government. Member for Cowan

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I have just come to the chamber after taking a phone call from a constituent of mine who lives in Castlemaine. I do not wish to name the constituent; it will simply suffice to say that it is Mrs Joy H. She made a complaint to me I that she had recently learned that the Minister more for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) was about to receive legal assistance to enable her to appear before the royal commission. This lady who contacted me said that she had applied for legal assistance some years that at that time she had three children and was on social security, but that she was a found to be ineligible for some reason or for any form of legal aid. She told me that she had to borrow money to pay for her legal services. In fact, the money which she received as child endowment went straight to pay back her loan for those legal services. She was very distressed, and I can underany stand why. Her question to me was: why are there two sets of rules-one set for people who are in power, and another for people who in some way or another are disadvantaged? I was at a loss to understand this myself, and certainly at a loss to explain it to her. In fact, many people in the community are in asking the very same question-that is, how that the federal government can provide legal assistance to someone when the matter is in signed a state jurisdiction. I can understand the thoughts of my constituent. I see that a man of much legal standing is at the table, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker). I understand that he is a Queen's Counsel. Perhaps after the adjournment debate he could enlighten me on the circumstances surrounding this of issue. This lady was most distressed to find that someone in that position would be getting legal assistance when she, in fact, with three children and on social security, could not get any legal assistance at all. Love, Mr Brian

Speaker: Mr CAMPBELL
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: In Western Australian journalistic circles it is well known that there are some journalists who receive leaks, preferential leaks, from Mr Ayton or Mr MCKechnie: to that matter. Margot Lang of the West Australian, Alison Fan from Channel 7 and, of course, Tony Barrass also of the West Australian. Tony Barrass had a very snide article in the inside cover of yesterday's paper in reference to a document which I lodged in this parliament on the previous day. His account is full of inaccuracies and it clearly indicates that takes the matter about which he wrote very lightly. I might add that he quotes Mr Love's brother completely out of context, appears that Mr Barrass thinks it a matter of lightness and jest that a man spends three years in gaol for a crime he did not commit. The tabled document to which I have· ment referred does not reveal any new evidence simply goes to existing statutory documents. By combing those documents, it is proved beyond doubt that Mr Love could not have committed the crime of which he was, in fact, convicted. Mr Barrass also stated that this man appealed to the Supreme Court and the whatsoever. High Court, and that the charges stuck like glue. That too is not true, as a lot of his evidence was not even admitted in the High Court. He also tried to paint a disparaging picture of a man whom I hold in the highest regardamongst David Macdonald, who did this painstaking work for me. He has many inaccuracies there too. Mr Macdonald resigned from the police force. Out of the blue, two days resignation was due to take place, he was charged with five offences going to corruption and stealing. When these five cases went to court, he was simply viewed as having no case to answer by the magistrate, who threw the whole lot out and had some very caustic things to say about the charging. It was example of the very thing I have been complaining about in Western Australian circles. It does Mr Barrass no credit at all that is so disparaging about that document, obviously he is peddling the convenient line. This is a very serious matter. I had the reviewed. Speaker: Mr FILING
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I want to make a couple of comments on the protests and sentiments of many Australians, particuhe larly those in my electorate, about the French nuclear tests. I was interested to hear the comments of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr and it Campbell) last sitting. Obviously, as has been conceded in the recent statements of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), the governhas conceded that the efforts it has made but to convince the French government of the protests and the opposition of the Australian community to the resumption of French nuclear weapon tests have failed miserably. It is quite clear that the French do not consider those protests to be of any significance However, by and large Australians are heid in pretty high regard in France. In fact, for a long time, Australians have enjoyed a fair amount of popularity when the subject of Australia and Australians has been raised ordinary French people. It is interesting to note that, when one visits France or speaks to French people, they do generally feel that Australians and French have a before his number of empathetic views. There is a tremendous opportunity for the protests of the Australian community to be brought home not just at the very high level of President Chirac and the French government but also more closely and more directly to the French people themselves. In view of an this high standing that Australians have . enjoyed, and the tremendous standing in which Australian sports men and women are he held by the French community, and reflecting and on the contribution made by· Australian servicemen and servicewomen during the First case World War and the Second World War on French soil, one can see that there is an opportunity for the Australian government to that, initiate a comprehensive program within France itself of informing the French people of the opposition of the Australian people to these tests. It is my view, on a positive note, that the Australian government could do this by initiating a program of public relations within the French media, both print and electronic, to show just how strongly the Australian people feel about the tests. It is something that can be done relatively cheaply, and in a little more compelling and influential way than has been the case in dealing with the French President himself. On a local note, I would like to congratulate a couple in my electorate who have just enjoyed their 50th wedding anniversary. The reason for bringing them to the attention of the House of Representatives is that they have been very prominent community activists for a long time in the electorate. I refer to Charlie and Beth Bail, who were amongst the first people to settle in the new suburb of Heaththe ridge some 15 to 16 years ago. Since then they have played a very important and subpolitical stantial role in the local community, particuitself larly in the activities of the Red Cross and raising money for the Australian Red Cross in the local area. I know that from time to time opportunity in the adjournment debate to congratulate and talk of local people and contribution they have made to their local community. But, in the case of Charlie and Beth Bail, they have been very strong piogreat neering participants in the northern suburbs my electorate. When the area of Heathridge was being developed-an area at the northerly tip of the northern suburbs-they played very important role in establishing a closepolitical knit community. I would like to warmest congratulations on their 50th wedding anniversary last Friday. I would also pass on my thanks to their daughter, Margaret Long, for keeping me informed of this imwould portant event in the community. Nuclear Testing in the Pacific

Speaker: Mrs SILVIA SMITH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Bass) (6.34 p.m.)Tonight I too wish to speak briefly in regard to the French nuclear tests in the Pacific and the reaction to that announcement in my legislation electorate of Bass. There is no doubt that will of Australians is starkly against the resumption of this testing. A rally was held in Civic Square, Launceston last Saturday against the resumption of these tests. At this rally I circulated a petition with the following wording: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the widespread community outrage throughout our nation at the decision of the French government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific. Your petitioners therefore ask the House to note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision. We ask further that the House call upon the government of France to reverse its position and abandon completely any further nuclear tests in the South Pacific. That petition, with its 312 signatures collected in a very short time at that rally, has been submitted by me today and will be tabled in House at our next sitting. That rally and this petition were things which united all interests in Launceston. The rally was organised by the Tasmanian Greens in and, although Bob Brown's speech was a plea to elect him to the Senate, at least it was an issue which he cared about and which Launthere is an ceston cared about. My own petition was in fact signed by the none other than my political opponent Warwick Smith. I can assure you that the battle for Bass is a tough one. It must have taken a deal of effort for him to bring himself of to sign a petition of mine, but nonetheless he did. I commend him for it. The point I make is that Australian abhorrence to French nua clear testing cuts across all-I repeat allboundaries. In the electorate of Bass, pass on my this is no different. Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I like to advise the House in this adjournment debate that tomorrow I most certainly will be voting against-I have officially informed the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer)-the Competition Policy Reform Bill, which I think is one of the most pernicious pieces of that I will see in my lifetime come the into an Australian parliament. I seem to be very isolated in that viewpoint on both sides of the House, although I suspect that there are many people sitting opposite who would agree very strongly with my point of view. I suspect there are a number of people on my side of the House who would oppose very strongly the legislation. I am in fairly good company-Trevor Sykes, probably the best writer on finance Australia today and the editor of Bulletin magazine for many years; Tom Fitzgerald, who gave the Boyer lectures in 1990 and also the finance editor at the Sydney Morning Herald for some 17 years; Bob Santamaria; Doug Anthony; Malcolm Fraser; and, for those sitting opposite, Ben Chifley and Ted. Theodore, those great Labor leaders, who would tum in their graves if was happening-in opposing the passing by a Labor government of the Competition ed Policy Reform Bill. We have seen how the BBOs have worked. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) comes in this place and skites about the BBOs. It appears to me to be a mechanism by which the wages of the average Australian will be driven down. We continuously hear the phrase 'world best practice' in this place and in other places. Quite frankly, world best practice is South American and South African wage dropped levels. A lot of people that are imposing this upon us are companies and corporations that have mines in South Africa, employing South Africans who come over here, and American companies that are now operating in Australia. When people talk about world best practice and they put into effect mechathe nisms such as the BBOs, may the Lord help the workers of Australia. In my home state, we have already seen rates massive strikes. We have seen the worse strike in the last 20 years in the sugar industry and the worse strike in the last 20 years in the mining industry. These were through BBOs. Disruptions are taking place. In Queensland we have seen average weekly earnings down in the last three years, which is probably the first time since the Second World War. They were already the lowest in Australia. Queensland is particularly susceptible to the deregulatory policies of this government. A statutory marketing authority as an arrangement is an industrial award for farmers. We have seen those smashed to pieces right across the board. Let us have a look at these wonderful, clever people who are imposing this bill upon the Australian public. All of the conditions, pay and arrangements that have been fought in over for 20,30,40, maybe even 100 years of Australian history are being swept away. Statutory marketing of wool was swept away was and we saw the income from wool drop from $6,000 million a year to about $2,500 million a year. We lost $3,200 million per year in the wool industry alone, including about a third of our wool growers. The nation's greatest asset was the sheep herd, and now a third of they saw what that asset has gone. Another area of the economy we deregulatwas petrol marketing. It was estimated by the MTAQ at one stage that around 500 service stations a year were closing. Most certainly, over 1,000 service stations and small proprietors went broke and went out of business in that period of time. So the small businessmen were wiped out and, as a result, the oil companies had a far greater grip on the Australiat:t marketplace. The net result has been that, although the world price of oil has by half, the price in Australia, in the same period of time, has more than doubled. That is costing the Australian public about $5,400 million per year every year-another South great victory for deregulation. In his book Bold Riders, Trevor Sykes estimated that $28,000 million was lost out of banks in a period of four years. Of course, that does not account for the estimated $70,000 million to $100,000 million that was taken off the Australian public, with interest in excess of 20 per cent, to try to rescue the banks for the money they threw away under the deregulatory policies of this government. So the dead are many. If this proceeds, the pharmacists, taxi drivers, rriilk vendors, newsagents, hoteliers and sugar farmers will go be wiped out. (Time expired). (;reen - ove-ent - r ADA-S (Lyons) (6.42 p.m.)-It is about time people realised that the dark green groups who have dominated the Australian environment debate have no room for compromise. As one can see by their comments after the Pedder report findings were handed down, it really would not have mattered what was said. If they do not get their own way, they just want to bag the result and stop talking to those who might be able to influence process. The editorial comment in the Mercury on 28 June was well made. It sums up the view that many of the darker greens have to umpires and to compromise. Simply, it is that umpires are people whom other people are expected to obey and that greens take notice of only when the decisions go their way. Compromise is what the other side is required to do to make a democracy work, but what the greens do only as a temporary measure to allow the regrouping of troops and energy. These are the words of the Mercury editorial, but I thoroughly agree with them. The dark greens display the same ruthless attitude when it comes to the forest argument. Look at the press articles on 24 June. The Herald Sun broadcast the fact that 30 green groups had withdrawn from consultation with the federal government on regional forest agreements. That is great, is it not? When they cannot get everything their way, they take their bat and ball and go home. They cannot even be bothered to listen to other people who might-just might-have an equally valid point to make. Dark greens say plantations are the only way to go for timber supply, and everything else must be locked up. That is their line. There is no thought for anyone who may have a little knowledge that might dispute some of the wilder statements made. There is no consideration of the alternatives to the ways forest harvesting can contribute to forest conservation. I remind people that not all greens are dark greens. There are some sensible and forwardthinking green groups, who, I believe, should be part of the debate to help us deal with those issues that are environmentally sensitive. International organisations such as Greenpeace and the World Wildlife Fund, which are much more scientific than some of our parochial Australian groups, should be brought into the debate. I thank the World Wildlife Fund for this comment-at least there is some thoughtful being out there: WWF does not see the need to completely end logging in native forests. In particular, WWF believes that well managed secondary forests, with a sustainable harvesting regime, should be of higher conservation value than the sterile "tree-farms" so familiar in much of Southern Australia. I could not agree more. Let us hope that we have people in Australia who still wish to preserve their living environment and who wish to take part in the broader debate. Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I want to briefly touch on the comments made earlier by the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) about some agreements I might have. I have many agreements with many people. I have an agreement with my wife called marriage. Part of that agreement is to develop a family. She will be developing our family further on 22 August this year, so honourable members will have to excuse my non-attendance on that day. I also have an agreement with my electorate, which voted me in in the last election in the hope that I would represent it better than its former member. I am doing that. Part of my role is serving my constituents better, and I am serving my constituents better than the member for Perth is serving his. In continuing my role I have great pleasure in presenting a continuation of last night's speech about Quenton Peake, who is the winner of the Qantas-Cowan essay competition this year. Honourable members would know that for the last two years I have brought young students to Canberra who have won essay competitions sponsored by Qantas, a good airline. This year's topic was 'Australia's future as a prosperous multicultural society depends on the development of a new national ethos'. Last week Quenton Peake of Woodvale, a year 12 student from Kingsway Christian College, was on work experience in my office. I hope he enjoyed himself. This year's topic is quite relevant to this period, especially when the Prime Minister (MrKeating) and the government have announced their preferred republic model for Australia. The Prime Minister might be interested in what a young Australian has to say about his society. Quenton starts his analysis of Australian society by stating: Reference to traditional Australia and the distinguishing spirit which embodied the population conjures images of survivors, people who would continue struggling against the elements. National pride resides with explorers, pioneers and those who fought for Australia's independence, providing the romantic yet tragic picture of those at Gallipoli who were willing to die for their mates. On these qualities has Australia been built and to the courage and personality of previous populations we owe our modem lifestyle as we know it. Success and prosperity has been achieved through not simply the battlers, but their unifying distinctive disposition which forces future generations to acknowledge the presence of and benefits of emulating such traits. Quenton continues: In the light of a changing society, resulting alterations to ethics and standards, and new international directions, one significant aspect of Australia's population is multiculturalism and the continuing expansion of this trend. This raises intriguing such as whether the traditional Australian ethos exists and functions in a modem urban, multicultural society, whether the state of our society dictates the need for a reviewed and updated ethos or whether the individual successfully contributes to the nation's prosperity without the need for a linking characteristic between races, religions and cultures. I hope that all young Australians are thinking about their future and where Australia is headed. Their opinion should be sought by many people within this place. I try to do that. I have a youth advisory committee in Cowan. Quenton continues: The diversity of cultures present in Australia's society has led to governmental policies granting equality as a right all citizens should be able to claim. This played a significant role in improving the attitudes of society towards all races, most significantly towards Australia's indigenous people, the Aborigines. An increased awareness towards inter-racial relationships helps towards a peaceful established level of functioning in which society should be a representation of national law.

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I think we should give Quenton preselection.

Speaker: Mr RICHARD EVANS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: He will be working for me, I can assure you. Quenton concludes his essay by stating: Multiculturalism ... benefits to the nation should constitute the need to preserve, but also put into effect, the qualities of honesty, integrity, equality and hard work. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), who is at the table, I guess should note those words. Quenton continues: The development of Australia's society has seen new racial awareness, granted new opportunities to Aborigines and all non-Europeans, with new steps in land rights and the scrapping of the white Australia policy. Future change will have its greatest chance to work for the good of the society if the traits on which the nation was built are not denied. The utilisation of national standards, practices and ethics to incorporate all cultures is a challenge which must be acted upon by each member of society if they desire to create a functioning and thriving basis from which Australia's future will not be constricted. Mr Speaker, I think you will agree that the comments of Quenton Peake, a young Australian who obviously cares deeply about his country and its future, deserves attention, as issues do the hopes and fears of all young Australstill ians. I thank the secondary schools in my area for being involved in this project. I thank the Wanneroo Times, the Eastern Suburbs Reporter, and particularly Qantas-I think there has been some bad news about Qantas recentlywhich has supported this competition for two years. (Time expired) TAAATS Project

Speaker: Mr HOLLIS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Throsby) (6.51 p.m.)Yesterday under parliamentary privilege Mr Dick Smith made a scathing attack on Ian Macphee. To his credit he repeated these comments outside the House and challenged Ian Macphee to sue him, which I hope Ian Macphee will do. As a person who called for the inquiry into the whole business that Ian Macphee was involved in and having myself been criticised by Dick Smith, 1 want to put a few things on the record. The Public Works Committee, of which I am the chair, was dealing in 1992 with The Advanced Australian Air Traffic System project. It was very controversial, between two competing tenders, Hughes from the USA and Thomson from France. We were getting all sorts of information. Mr Speaker, as the chairman of a committee you know that you get all sorts of information. I was getting anonymous telephone calls day and night and letters. All sorts of accusations were being put before me. We had the CAA before us. In my eight years of chairing a parliamentary committee I have never witnessed a more incompetent and disgraceful exhibition. The then chair of the CAA wrote me a letter saying that I had exceeded my authority-the most impertinent letter I have received as a member of parliament. Dr Edwards, who also lost his position there, was the most incompetent witness I had ever experienced. We held hearings in Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth and two in Canberra. Many of these hearings were in camera. The two hearings in Canberra were in camera. In Perth I warned the witnesses that I considered that they were in contempt of parliament. I went as far as to threaten to bring them before the bar of the House. In Brisbane I let the witnesses know I was not happy with them. But we kept trying to get information. We were dealing with a project worth, from memory, something like $160 million of Australian taxpayers' money. We never actually said that there was anything wrong or that anyone was getting a take from the tendering process. What we did say was that the impression we had was that the normal procedure had not been followed. In the end, it became clear to my committee that we were going to get absolutely no information out of these people and in that way we could not make a recommendation to parliament. The inquiry went from April until June of 1992. On 3 June I stood in this House and said that my committee, the PWC: . . . has decided to take the unprecedented step of recommending that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Cook) set up an independent panel to carry out a thorough review of all aspects of the awarding of this contract to Thomson. This review should be completed as a matter of urgency so that the CAA can appoint a final contractor with a minimum of delay. The Public Works Committee stresses that this issue is too important for it not to be settled as soon as pos- 1988. sible. The committee feels that, because of the serious concerns it has regarding the T AAATS project, it cannot report to the Parliament until this review is completed. Dick Smith always opposed that. He opposed an independent inquiry being set up. One of the reasons he opposed it was that the very people whom we were inquiring into were people he had appointed to positions. At some other time, I will go into more detail about that inquiry. As I said, those appearing before us, including Baldwin, Edwards and others, were the most incompetent and worse briefed witnesses who had ever appeared before the Public Works Committee, and we, have dozens of hearings every year. I think Dick Smith has exceeded all the bounds of propriety and decency in making this totally unwarranted attack. I hope that Ian Macphee sues him for as much as possible. Question resolved in the affirmative. Main Committee adjourned at 12.16 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: Lake Eyre Basin (Question No. 2311) Mr Wakelin asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 9 May 1995: (1) Have the assessment costs of nominating the Lake Eyre Basin in South Australia for World Heritage listing been published in Commonwealth budget documents; if not, why not. (2) What criteria does the Government use to determine whether an Australian region is a potential World Heritage site.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: REPRESENTATIVES MAIN COMMITTEE
text: The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question: (1) Three assessments are being conducted to determine whether World Heritage values are present in the Lake Eyre Basin in South Australia. These three assessments will cost approximately $125000. Funds for these studies are not separately identified in the budget documents but form part of the appropriation to the Environment Program. (2) The criteria used by the Government to determine whether an Australian region is a potential World Heritage site are set out in the "Operational Guidelines for the Implementation of the World Heritage Convention", released by UNESCO. The Operational Guidelines require the region to be assessed against criteria which relate to the identification of "outstanding universal value" in terms of the cultural and natural environronment, ment. A copy of the Guidelines has been forwarded to the honourable member. A copy of the Guidelines is filed in the Table Office of the House of Representatives where it may be read or a copy of it obtained. Family Services Council (Question No. 2323) Mr Andrews asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 May 1995: Further to the answer to Question No. 1947 (Hansard, 9 May 1995, page 91) concerning the Family Services Council, who were the experts in the field consulted about appointments to the Council. NA

Speaker: Mr LAVARCH
Title: ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: Consultations regarding possible appointments to the Family Services Council were made on an informal and confidential basis. The experts in the field referred to in Question 1946 were acknowledged leaders in the Family Services field including senior academics, senior professional people and leaders in family and social policy. Records of goods imported are maintained under the items in the Australian Customs Tariff. The tariff item for specific goods is generally determined by their nature rather than by the material of which they are composed. There are no specific tariff items for goods of hemp-based non-narcotic materials.
